Author: chrshlsll1812
Content: https://discord.gg/T9dxeRmY

Author: chrshlsll1812
Content:
Hi Everyone, 
By popular request this Discord Community has been created for everyone to share ideas, contribute, ask questions, and bask in the awesomeness that is the maker community.
I released the OG solder reflow plate design (sw 1.0, hw 2.4) on GitHub (https://github.com/AfterEarthLTD/Solder-Reflow-Plate) and had it featured on an episode of GreatScott!'s DIY or BUY series (https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=QarizoUnRfk&t=1s).
Since then the community response has been fantastic!
Lets carry on and build the new future!!!!

Author: chrshlsll1812
Content: Please feel free to post, create channels for discussions, and development groups. This is our playground!

Content: Hi, you're better off keeping to 1oz. 2oz will reduce the resistance by quite a bit and throw out the MOSFET PWM values. Good luck!

Author: chrshlsll1812
Content:
Seems like we're all having trouble getting hold of ATmega328p microcontrollers.
I have added a new board version to the github, Ver3.0, that is based on the ATmega4809 microcontroller which is a little more available at the moment. 
I'd advise having a look at that if you are burning to build one right now.
I've not finished the code for this version as I have yet to have a board to test on, but when they arrive (late March) I'll post the updated code.

Author: merlin.shaw
Content: I feel the IP2721 IC is the best/simplest option for USB C PD as it uses far less circuitry and doesn't have to be programmed, but they are not the most available and drive the cost up.  I wonder if it would be smart to just put the headers in so if people want to buy the easy to find ZY12PDN Boards that use this chip as a hat.  https://www.amazon.com/MELIFE-Type-C-Voltage-Trigger-Module/dp/B0953G14Q2

Author: merlin.shaw
Content: But for those that don't need or care about USB C PD, it keep costs of the overall project low.  Thoughts?

Author: vamatis
Content:
Could also be a good option..I'm not really into cheap Chinese components because they tend to disappear haha but it would work. 

Programming could be done automatically by the firmware though

Author: merlin.shaw
Content: We could also just include a XT60 Connector on the PCB so people can build/Buy their own TS100 Flex-C-Friend.  - https://hackaday.io/project/172187-ts100-flex-c-friend

Author: vamatis
Content: Yes that would work too :)

Author: merlin.shaw
Content: Just trying to keep it simple, doing the programming of a STUSB4500 from the firmware would work, but it adds a lot of complexity and circuitry.  All for a feature that some people will never use or even want.

Author: derspatz
Content:
From my (limited) understanding, the relevant specs of the MOSFET are:
- Current rating: should be high enough for the heating current
- Voltage rating: should be high enough for the input voltage (max 20V), plus some buffer (25V in total)
- Rds(on): Should be as low as possible, as the MOSFET resistance forms a voltage divider with the resistance of the heating bed, so the heat in the MOSFET is directly proportional to the heating power of the device
- Gate charge: should be as low as possible, but not that relevant, as you could lower the PWM frequency - mostly affects heat in the MOSFET

the heatbed has two main properties:
- internal resistance: should be neither too high, nor too low. too low also causes more heat in the MOSFET, if power output is constant
- necessary power output: the larger the heatpad, the more power you need. with constant voltage, the important factor is current, which is also heating up the MOSFET via the Rds(on).

as I see it, an overspecced MOSFET should be usable for all sizes of heatbeds, as long as it is in its current and voltage range, and Rds(on) is low enough

Author: derspatz
Content: I am asking because I am planning to make a design for a modular board, and I need to find out which part needs to be on the heatbed side of the two boards

Author: merlin.shaw
Content: @derspatz - I have also watched videos were folks say for high current, a Gate Driver is nice because it basically does all the calculations and takes a lot of the guess work out.  Here is a good video on why they are better for high current than Logic Level Mosfets - https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=56p3_aORiJ0

Author: merlin.shaw
Content: I used a Gate Driver in my through hole version of this board and tried to match the Mosfet as closely to the one that Chris uses in his

Author: derspatz
Content:
In my understanding, a gate driver has the following function:
The internal resistance of the MOSFET depends on the accumulated charge stored in the gate pin of the MOSFET.
When the gate is fully charged, the MOSFET is either fully blocking or fully conducting (depending on NMOS or PMOS).
Problematic are the phases inbetween: While the charge is pumped into or out of the gate pin, the internal resistance is some higher value than Rds(on), and with the current flowing through the MOSFET, this heats up the MOSFET more than necessary.
That's why you want the current (and thus charge) flowing in and out if the gate as high as possible: to keep the inbetween-staes of the MOSFET as short as possible, to reduce heat.
That's what a gate driver does: he provides a sufficiently high voltage and current for the gate.
A MCU is not able to provide these currents and votlages, but a simple 74xx logic gate (dual inverter or something like that) should do the job for this use case.

Author: merlin.shaw
Content: I use logic level shifters in my LED Controller and I have gone through several types as they have their own quirks and specifications.  I will though let you know how the gate driver works on my version of the heatplate.  I just got the ship notification so I should have my PCB's next week.

Author: derspatz
Content: btw: I assume there's enough thermal mass in the heatplate that using high frequency PWM is probably pretty useless, I assume turning the MOSFET on and off can be done with a much lower frequency (a few Hz, maybe even less), so a PID style control should be pretty sufficient and less stressful for the whole electronics (flyback voltage spikes, EMI, MOSFET heat, etc.)

Author: merlin.shaw
Content: I agree, I don't think it needs to be switched on and off that quickly.  Once it hits temperature, it will shut off until it drops below temperature.  Seconds would work let alone nanoseconds.

Author: derspatz
Content:
Soo, here's my take on the heatbed:
**Mechanical Design**
- modular design
- main PCB: 100mm x 29mm
- replaceable heat PCB with few cheap parts
- XT60 for power connection (overpowered but available at LCSC)
- PCB is further stabilized by the inductor and the DC jack on the back
- thermal sensor is thermally coupled to the heat bed with a fuse holder and thermal paste/pad
**Power Input**
- DC barrel jack with plug detection
- USB C (footprint needs to be changed to power only USB-C) with IP2721 (currently not available at LCSC)
- supports input voltages from 12V to 20V
- high power diodes for polarity protection
- LM2940 LDO for 5V, as 78L05 does not tolerate reverse polarity (plugging in USB for programming could damage a 78L05)
**MCU**
- ESP32 DEVKITV1 board with all necessary peripherals
- wireless functions not yet needed
- 12bit ADC
- 8bit DAC
- cheap and easy to obtain, even during the chip crisis

Author: derspatz
Content:
**Power Output**
- TPS55340 boost converter
- output voltage controllable with the MCU's DAC (by injecting voltage into the feedback pin)
- output voltage from 15V to 30V
- output current up to 5A
- more granular control over the output power, can be adjusted for different input supplies and heatbeds
- no high frequency PWM control (enable pin needs 1ms to trigger)
- flyback diode to prevent voltage spikes on the output
**Power Control**
- measures input voltage, output voltage, output current and temperature
- can obtain very exact information about power consumption etc.
- temp sensor has an opamp for more ADC resolution
**User Interface**
- 128x32 OLED
- +/- buttons
- 3 LEDs: POWER, HEATING, HOT (above 40¬∞C)
**Misc**
- nearly all parts available at LCSC (IP2721 listed but sold out, ESP32 and OLED need to be bought elsewhere)
- easy to solder, min part size is 0805, no QFN parts etc.
- Board and schematic are not fully done, some small things are missing

Author: derspatz
Content:
Btw, have you guys considered placing a copper fill under the whole heatbed that is connected to the heating traces only at one point close to the temperature sensor? This way, no current would be flowing through it, but I would expect the followings effects:
- slower heat up and faster cool down, due to the additional thermal mass and greater surface
- more even thermal distribution
- better thermal couling to the temperature sensor
- less warping of the heatbed
Besides the longer heat up time (or more power needed), I assume only advantages when doing this

I think combining planes would do the same.

Author: derspatz
Content:
In my eyes, the additional measurements are not done to show more flashy numbers on the screen, but to help this device do better what it was designed for.
See, the calculated resistance for the heating trace in the current PCB is 0.7 Ohms (1.4mm wide, 35¬µm thick, 206 cm long, https://www.allaboutcircuits.com/tools/trace-resistance-calculator/) at 20¬∞C.
At 12 Volts, this results in a power consumption for the heating bed of 205W (17.1A!). At 200¬∞C, the resistance has nearly doubled to 1.2 Ohms, which results in a power output of 120W (10A). As you can see, the output power is only half as much on operating temperature. If we could ramp up the output voltage, we could keep the output power steady.
But this is not my main concern, ‚ö†Ô∏è ‚ö†Ô∏è ‚ö†Ô∏è **my main concern is safety**: ‚ö†Ô∏è ‚ö†Ô∏è ‚ö†Ô∏è  17A is nearly 3.5 times higher than what the power supply can deliver, and what the DC plug is specified for. For a short moment, this might be okay, but a cheap power supply is likely to explode, or cause voltage drops that might cause the MCU to brownout, leaving the MOSFET in a permanent on state, thus causing the DC plug and the PSU to burn.

Author: derspatz
Content:
A heat plate with such a low resistance would reach 2.6 Ohms (which would be the minimum safe resistance for PSU and connector) at 700¬∞C, so the heat bed plate resistance **MUST** be higher if you want to drive that heat plate safely.
Maybe PSU and plug could even be run with higher power for a very short time if the heat plate reaches a safe resistance fast enough, but you could not guarantee that, maybe someone places something very large on the heat plate which would slow the heating process (like use it as a cup warmer for fun).
So, we have to raise the cold resistance of the heat bed to a level that is safe to run for extended periods of time. At 2.6 Ohms we have an output power of 55W (4.6A), but at 200¬∞C that would drop to 32W (2.7A).
Remember, all these calculations were only done with 12V, at 15V or 20V from USB C, the output power would be even higher, as P = U**^2** x I. The only thing you would fry is your USB power supply.

Author: derspatz
Content: And I have also not yet taken tolerances in the PCB into account, that could shift the situation even worse.

Author: derspatz
Content:
So, we need to start at a much lower voltage and higher heatbed resistance and ramp up the output voltage when the resistance rises to make use of all the juice the PSU can deliver.
That's why my design also measures Vout and Iout, to adjust the voltage level so that the PSU can work in it's specified area at all times.
Plus, by measuring and knowing the resistance and voltage, we can calculate the heatbed resistance, and by comparing the resistance at 20¬∞C and when hot, we can easily calculate the temperature of the actual heatbed. Electronic cigarettes in temperature control mode work like this.
The thermal probe would then be more like "probably the temperature of the heated item on the heat plate".

Author: derspatz
Content: Measuring Vin is mostly done because it only needs two resistors in its simplest form, we can detect power delivery failures and adjust accordingly, and we can assume the kind of power supply depending on the input voltage.

Author: merlin.shaw
Content: Sounds like a programming nightmare but everything you said makes sense and it's nice to see your math and considerations.

Author: derspatz
Content: I'm pretty sure, a MCU can do those calculations much faster than I can üòâ

Author: derspatz
Content:
Basically an algorithm could look like this:
1 START
2 DETERMINE OUTPUT POWER BY Vin AND USER INPUT
3 PULSE MEASURE Vout AND Iout, CALCULATE  RESISTANCE
4 SET SAFE VOLTAGE LEVEL FOR HEATING PHASE WITH CURRENT RESISTANCE
5 HEAT FOR 1 SECOND
6 PULSE MEASURE RESISTANCE, CALCULATE TEMPERATURE
7 REPEAT STEPS 4-6 UNTIL TARGET TEMP IS REACHED

Author: chrshlsll1812
Content:
Evening everyone! You're all a busy bunch! 
Spatz, the MOSFET is being driven by PWM in my design. I've tuned the frequency and duty cycle such that the heater element current is limited to what it can handle. The big electrolytic capacitor is there to smooth out the current and prevent the large inrush current from tripping or overloading power supplies. This leads to a max power usage of 60W (12V, 5A), and only for brief periods during the last push towards maximum temperature.

Author: derspatz
Content: Sorry, but the design as it is is pretty unsafe and if the pwm control fails for any reason, the whole thing could catch fire. Basically, you need a 160W input with extremely low PWM duty cycles. I assume this only works right now as the PSU only sees very short pulses of very high power draw and because of that does not go into protection mode, if it has any.

Author: derspatz
Content: Basically, if you expect a power draw of 5A, and a 5A fuse blows, there's something wrong with your design, and leaving out the fuse is not the solution

Content:

Author: derspatz
Content:
we can see some things:
- the mosfet resistance is pretty high because it only driven with 5V
- this results in less current use than expect, but still around 10A
- the mosfet will heat a lot from this
- the capacitor does not do any filtering at all, for actual filtering we would need a few hundred Millifarads
- the power supply is delivering short pulses of over 11A
- assuming we'd have a large pack of capacitors at hand, the maximum duty cycles with those caps (250mF) would be around 40% to be under 5A current

Author: derspatz

Author: derspatz
Content:
"I've tuned the frequency and duty cycle".
Sorry, but I have looked at your code, and this plain wrong. The PWM frequency is the usual 490Hz from analogwrite, there is no tuned frequency.
And if I understand your code correctly, the max duty cycle during warmup phase is close to 50% when 180¬∞C is selected.
Even if the filter caps are large enough (and to be clear, they should at least be 1000 times larger) this would result in a current draw between 5 and 6 amps, and that's only because the MOSFET's resistance is too high.

Content: The current board version is a fire hazard. Leaving the information online so people can build this a liability. Every person who builds V3 and uses it might get hurt. This is no funsies "haha, I know what I'm doing", this is an actual risk to the well being of people.

Author: derspatz
Content:
first thing would be to at least make the people aware that the PSU should be able to supply short pulses of over 11A, best would be to say that the PSU needs at least 11 A current delivery, otherwise it could fail (catastrophically).
of course a 120W power supply as requirement would make this whole project less attractive.
then we would still have the problem with the dc plug current at duty cycles over 40%, so there's still a risk of burning the plug

Author: derspatz
Content:
the pcb as it is would fail catastrophically if the code has an error.
errors in the code can't be expected to not happen, especially in an open source project. and right now no comment in the code shows there's a significant risk to changes in the output values.
I would not trust this device to be connected to power permanently, but some might assume it is safe (as it should be), and have it powered on (but not heating) in their hackerspace or something.
No device should be able to self-destruct just by writing a wrong line of code, but this is such a device.

Author: derspatz
Content:
Hey folks, I spent some time to revise the original version.
Here's what I've changed (I tried to keep as much as possible from the original design:
- made the board larger (100x100mm)
- made the heat plate larger (83 x 68 mm)
- added a  resetable fuse
- added a lot of filtering capacitors
- adjusted the voltage divider for a lower Vref, this gives more ADC resolution for the analog temperature probe
- added the option to run analog or digital temperature probe, or both
- changed the capacitors for the LDO to electrolytic caps, as the AMS1117 might be unstable with ceramic caps
- added I2C pullup resistors, might not be needed, but this way you can add them if necessary
- moved some pins around for easier routing
- changed the switches from pull down to pull up
- added a simple NPN driver for the MOSFET
- added a flyback diode to reduce voltage spikes when switching the inductive load (heat plate)
- added some very important information for firmware to the schematic
- reduced the number of different resistors/capacitors on the BOM
- increased the heat plate resistance to a safer level
- switched some parts to parts that are easier to hand solder or easier available
- new routing with better grounding, only small interruptions in the ground layer, higher current capacity
- added a copper pour on the bottom layer under the heatbed, for better heat distribution
- this copper pour can be connected to ground close to the temp sensors, this might help with temp readings, but might impact EMI, even though I can't tell whether this will be positively or negatively

A simulation of the power consumption can be found here.
https://tinyurl.com/yb7d636w

Author: derspatz
Content:
I would still not deem this design totally safe, as you can still write code that blows the physical fuse, but at least it blows a fuse and nothing else.
But this behaviour is necessary as the operating point shifts with the resistance/temperature, and we need to start a bit too high to still have enough power at higher temps.

Author: pilo1337
Content: hey dudes! Nice project, one short question: is 200C the max temp of this plate? i got a very "crappy" solder paste, which has a melting point at around 220C. do i have to buy a low temp paste?

Author: derspatz
Content:
this is a question of two factors: durability and power. we know fr-4 can withstand these temperatures for some time, but we don't know how much the PCB degrades after several soldering processes.
regarding power, the board I designed and @Merlin.Shaw ordered (thanks!) and @strangeLoops changed the code for is designed for a temperature up to 180¬∞C, beyond that point, PWM is turned off and the MOSFET is conducting all the time. this means that there is still current through the pcb, but this current will get lower as the resistance of the copper rises with temperature. at some point an equilibrium between system power and dissipated power will be reached, but we don't know what temperature that will be, as it depends on mamy factors

Author: julspower
Content: and what about aluminium substrate for the heat plate?

Author: derspatz
Content:
this would only work for version with separate heat plate, as otherwise the whole board would heat up
but i don't think this would be a good idea, I assume the lacquer and the glues degrades before the actual PCB material
and I assume the aluminium would work as a heatsink, lowering the actual temps
and as the whole heatplate would get hot, the risk of burning yourself would be much higher

Author: strangeloops
Content: Steady state temps can be tricky to calculate for real world models, but simpler ones exist.  Here's a doc that covers it: https://www.sfu.ca/~mbahrami/ENSC%20388/Notes/Staedy%20Conduction%20Heat%20Transfer.pdf see page 11 for a simple calculation.  Basically Tsurface = Tambient + (power_per_volume * volume)/(heat_transfer_coeff * Area)

Author: strangeloops
Content: probably better to just ask someone to crank up the temp and see how much power it draws (though that may destroy the board)

Author: derspatz
Content:
@Merlin.Shaw ordered a few boards of my redesign (basically the same form factor as the V3, but with betterpower supply and safety features), and will give one board to @strangeLoops, who is reworking the code. This version also uses the ATMEGA4809, which is in short supply now.
On my HDD I also have another design, which uses a STM32G030 TSSOP-20 MCU, has some additional features like current measuring for more exact power and temperature measurements (and some other gimmicks), and most importantly, it has a replacable heatplate and a more stable table design made from PCBs. I assume this would be my final take on the heatplate design, but I want to wait for the other redesigns to work (or not work) before releasing the next design.

I can see that you kept about the 5 cm length

Author: merlin.shaw
Content: How do we get it to pull the full 5 amps into the hot plate (60 watts)

Author: wronggame
Content: You need a low resistance hot plate and a switching power supply, basically you need a microcontroller with logic

Author: wronggame
Content: the system will do whatever it can, but it's limited by the physical circuit properties

Author: merlin.shaw
Content: The boards have a microcontroller, is it not being used for the purpose?

Author: wronggame
Content: It is

Author: wronggame
Content: If you are wanting to pull 60 watts into a hotplate with a 5 Amp maximum, then the maximum resistance of your hotplate is 2.4 Ohms

Author: wronggame
Content: That's assuming no losses and 100% duty cycle

Author: merlin.shaw
Content: i'm not sure the wattage is as important as just getting the entire plate to heat up quickly, i'm just assuming the amps need to be ramped up to achieve this.

Author: merlin.shaw
Content: the exact wattage I mean

Author: wronggame
Content: I mean, heat is power, losses are from current and not votlage, for any power you input it will eventually settle at a specific temperature (specifically the change in temperature from ambient given specific conditions) the more power you dump in the more heat you will produce and the quicker it will heat up

Author: wronggame
Content: you are correct that the specific power isn't really what you need to worry about until you look at what you want to power it with

Author: johboh

Author: johboh
Content: Yes (24C). I didn't do any measurements at 180C.

Author: wronggame
Content: fair enough, thanks

Author: johboh
Content: How does the size of the heat plate affect things? Given that the total resistance is the same.

Author: wronggame
Content: basically, the heat power lost to the atmosphere is based on temperature and surface area, most of the time what I'm looking for in a design is the heat power divided by the area times the temperature,

Author: wronggame
Content: so, the smaller the area the less heat will be lost, but the quicker it heats up, it ends up basically being a trade-off between input power, surface temperature, surface area, and time to heat

Author: wronggame
Content: Where are you measuring the current? is it the total from the supply?

Author: johboh
Content:
Make sense, thanks.
Yes it's total power from supply.

Author: wronggame
Content: Yeah, so, ignore my previous statement about the 3.6 W, that's wrong, switched mode power supplies are really nice because they can be REALLY efficient, some even reach up to 99.5% efficient, it's actually dumping all of that 14.52 W into the heat plate

Author: wronggame
Content: besides whatever power is used for logic or switching of the FET

Author: johboh

Author: derspatz
Content:
for my version with replacable heat plates, I designed two heatbeds, one with 100x100mm, and one with half the area (72x72mm), so you can decide whether you need lots of power in a small area, or more power in a smaller area
the resistances of both heatplates are more or less the same

Author: derspatz
Content:
generally, an adjustable voltage source (step down with low resistance heat plate or step up with high resistance heat plate) in combination  with current sensing for power consumption regulation and no PWM would be the best solution from a technical point of view.
this would allow us to have different input voltages and be less strict about the heat plate resistance, as long as it can be driven well by the dc-dc converter.
less complicated is the solution with pwm. but with this solution, to have a safe device, we need to adjust the heat plate resistance so that the hot head bed will not overload the power supply at full PWM duty cycle (worst case, software error etc.; the heat plate gets hot and stays hot, but the psu can handle it). for the colder heat plate, the current consumption can be controlled by pwm. this also has the disadvantage that we need a lot of capacitors to filter out the current spikes for the PSU.
by measuring the input voltage and current, we can also calculate the actual heat plate temperature via the resistance change.
the original design has neither large enough input capacitors nor a heat plate resistance that is high enough to be considered safe. it just draws pulses of very high current directly from the PSU.

Author: derspatz
Content: i also have a design for a step-up converter type on my HDD, but I think PWM and larger caps is the way to go, mostly because of less parts and probably less complicated software.

Author: chrshlsll1812
Content:
Hello ALL!!!! 
My you have been a busy lot!
Apologies for my absence the past month or two. I've been really focussed on getting my last year of University completed and so have had little time to think of the SRP project.

I can see lots of fork designs have been made which is great. The Spatz version is great and does indeed include many more safety features than my original!
There are also a couple of designs with difference microcontrollers about which is awesome.

An update on my order of Ver3.0s with the ATmega4809......
I'm having trouble getting the final boards out of China. They have been short on workers due to covid and parts (despite it all being in stock when I ordered it).
I will continue to chase.
In the meantime, some of you have the Ver3.0 boards ready. Are you all still waiting for software?
If so, is anyone available to help with this? I can do the software side but I need someone with the finished Ver3.0 boards to test the software.

There are a lot of issues and pull requests on the Github. Apologies if you have been waiting for my response on these.
I'll crack on with them over the next few days. 

In the meantime, well done everyone!
Keep making!!!!

Author: ayman1_1
Content: guys...do you think an aluminium PCB is bettter than normal FR-4 forheating issues?

Author: serpent10i
Content:
PCBs from most of the low cost manufactures are just aluminum clad, instead of being a pure chunk of aluminum, so you'll still have some FR4 which is likely to degrade with too much heat, so that may still cause issues

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=fbBXPeC-FPQ
This guy tried used some other PCB materials and had generally poor results, perhaps there are some lessons for this project in his findings
It was suggested in the comments to try an Al PCB but I don't see him ever following up on that
So it'd definitely be worth trying, but it might not end up being a perfect solution

Author: brettski74
Content: Has anyone got a V3.0 board working with the vonryan firmware? I have one running that I flashed with the firmware that @Galvan linked above. It seems to be running ok - screen comes on and looks right, but buttons don't work. Nothing happens when I press or hold them, although probing at C12 does show them swinging from 0 to 5V when pressed, so I'm thinking software issue.

Author: brettski74
Content: I see @orberon0001  said something about buttons. I guess I need to search and read a bit...

Author: brettski74
Content: Actually, I think I know my problem. I think it's me... sorry for the noise. Does anyone know the proper way to get PIN_PC3, etc defined properly. The Arduino IDE complained that they were undefined and I did a quick hack to try to fix this but I guess my haste didn't pay off.

Author: brettski74
Content: In case anyone else does the same as me, I compiled the firmware using the Arduino Nano Every core. Since I was also harvesting my 4809 off a Nano Every, I thought I might be able to cheat and program it while still on the Nano Every board, then transplant and happy days. Maybe I still could have if I'd compiled it right. I'm assuming I should have used the MegaCoreX core. It certainly seems to compile and not complain about PIN_PC3, etc being undefined that way.

Author: brettski74
Content: Does it bug anyone else that the lower button goes up and the upper button goes down?

Author: brettski74
Content: I've forked the vonryan repo and updated the documentation for building and programming the V3.0 hardware. I also made some minor tweaks to the code to make the interface more intuitive - at least IMHO. https://github.com/brettski74/Solder-Reflow-Plate

Author: brettski74
Content: I've created a pull request to merge mine and vonryan123's changes into the main AfterEarthLTD repo.

Author: brettski74
Content: Looking at the V3.0 schematic and wondering about C7 and D2 across the heating element. I'm assuming it's intended to snub out any inductive spikes from the heating element when the MOSFET turns off. If so, why the zener and not a schottky or freewheel diode or am I missing something? I'm assuming that the heating element doesn't have much inductance anyway, so maybe not overly important.

Author: orberon0001
Content: Hi everyone ! I'm hitting a wall with the board. I have been able to compile the software (using @brettski74 sketch and MegaCoreX board), and I can program it to the board using Atmel-ICE with Microchip Studio 7. I can read the device, and as soon as the ICE reads it, the firmware comes to life... but only as long as I don't restart.  The board WORKS after I connect the programmer. I can turn  the heater on (BTW, I guess the chopping frequency is pretty audible!). However, If I unplug the device and reconnect it, the LCD is dead. I've checked that the voltages are ok (5v and the voltage divider is around 2.89V). Do you happen to know what it could be? Maybe de uCPU fuses??  Is the Reset line configured as GPIO? Any suggestion is welcome. At this point I believe that it's more a software issue (or the device configuration) than hardware.

Author: brettski74
Content: I'm no expert on AVR fuse settings and I've never seen an Atmel-ICE or Microchip Studio 7, so not sure if there's some settings there you're getting wrong. I programmed my board using the Arduino IDE and a UPDI programmer made from an Arduino Nano with JTAG2UPDI loaded on it. In the absence of any better ideas, if you have a spare Arduino lying around, maybe try using that to program it to see if it makes any difference.

I ordered a couple out of curiosity but frankly, I can buy an in-stock Arduino Nano Every from Digi-Key for about the same price as the AliExpress chips and a few dollars cheaper than one from LCSC and Digi-Key gets it to me next day, so... Not sure where you are, but you might find harvesting one off an Arduino might be cheaper and quicker and better chance of genuine parts - plus you get a free SAMD11!

Author: oltdaniel
Content: My first SMD project assembly. Any special tips?

Author: brettski74
Content: I would recommend reflowing the board. Unless you've modified the layout and used larger components, there are some very small components (0402) in the BOM which may be challenging to solder. There are also parts that don't have exterior pins or wettable sides which may also be hard to solder with an iron unless you've replaced them with a different package. Hopefully you got a stencil with your board/s but it's still possible without one.

Author: oltdaniel
Content: I'm using the board from @derspatz which is easier to hand solder.

Author: brettski74
Content: Have plenty of flux and desoldering wick ready to go.

Author: oltdaniel
Content: Yea ordered an 1mm desoldering wick. Hopefully I won't need it as much. Thanks for the tips btw. I'm trying to get into PCB design step by step.

Author: brettski74
Content: If you have any issues with bridging - especially around the MCU, be patient. Also, I find cutting the wick to give you a fresh end and pushing that into the pins sometimes works better than dragging the wick over the top. It tends to get the strands of the wick in between the pins better which might draw out the excess solder better.

Author: derspatz
Content:
The hardest part will be the mcu, so I'd start with the soic-8 to get a feeling for the soldering process, and do the mcu after that and check for bridges
After that, do the passives
Generally, work by height, going from flat to high

Author: brettski74
Content: I've been wondering if PCBWay might be a better fab for the heater plate. JLCPCB's standard material has a Tg of 130 celsius. PCBWay's standard material for their $2 for 5 boards has a Tg of 155 celsius, unless you go for an Aluminium board, then JLCPCB seems the better value option again. The boards I have are standard boards from JLCPCB and so far they seem like they're coping just fine with temperatures up over 200 celsius, but I've hardly used them yet and mostly for testing and experimentation.

Author: derspatz
Content:
https://github.com/DerSpatz/PCB-reflow-solder-heat-plate
I have updated my GitHub to v1.0 of my heatplate design. v0.9 worked without problems, so v1.0 should work without problems, too.
Software was written/modified by @strangeLoops and testing was done by @Merlin.Shaw , thank you to them!
My design is safer than the original design, and can be hand soldered. @Daniel made it his first SMD project and soldering was doable.
So, check it out and feel free to make you own PCB heat plate.
I will soon order a handful of PCBs and parts, and I live in Germany.

Author: brettski74
Content: There have been more developments since the original design. If you're looking at an ATmega4809 based board, you'll need to look at one of the forks - perhaps mine - for some working software and instructions. That hardware design has some issues, though. There's also a newer hardware design by @derspatz and others that fixes some of the issues and some improved software that came with that as well. There are links to these in the discussion on here. It would probably be handy if we collected some of this information in an easier to find spot.

Author: derspatz
Content:
Hey folks! My first board is soldered, and now I want to flash the software.
I have in front of me:
- the target board with the ATMEGA4809
- an Arduino Nano clone (Arduino Micro clone also available) with USB cable
- three wires
- a 4.7kOhm resistor
Can someone please run me through the firmware flashing process?
As I've always said, I'm more of a hardware guy... ü§∑‚Äç‚ôÇÔ∏è

Author: _jcm_
Content:
1. Download/Clone this project: https://github.com/ElTangas/jtag2updi and rename the folder "source" to "jtag2updi" (otherwise the Arduino IDE won't like it)
2. Open jtag2updi/jtag2updi.ino in your Arduino IDE
3. Configure the flasher options for your Arduino Nano and flash it
4. Connect D6 of your Arduino Nano over the 4.7kOhm resistor to the UPDI pin of the board and 5V to 5V and GND to 0V
5. Add the MegaCoreX hardware package to the Ardunio IDE (see https://github.com/MCUdude/MegaCoreX#how-to-install)
6. Install the Adafruit_GFX, Adafruit_SSD1306 and Debounce2 libraries with the Library Manager (you might not need all of them depending on which firmware you plan to use)
7. Download and open the ino you want to upload to the ATMEGA4809 (I used this one: https://github.com/vonryan123/Solder-Reflow-Plate/blob/main/Board%20Versions/70mm%20by%2050mm%20Ver3.0%20ATmega4809/Software/SW1.0_HW3.0_70by50mm.ino)
8. Select the options in the screenshot (not sure about BOD and Clock, it worked for me tho) and select the port of your Ardunio Nano as Port
9. Select Burn Bootloader and see if it runs through
10. Temporarily disable auto reset for the Arduino Nano: https://playground.arduino.cc/Main/DisablingAutoResetOnSerialConnection/ (not sure if it's needed for the Nano, it was for my Mega)
11. Select Sketch > Upload using Programmer (normal Upload will not work)

Content: Thank you!

Author: derspatz
Content:
https://github.com/AfterEarthLTD/Solder-Reflow-Plate/blob/main/Board%20Versions/70mm%20by%2050mm%20Ver2.4%20ATmega328p/Board%20Files/70by50mm%20Ver2.4%20Schematic.pdf
C7 and D2 were added to the schematic to filter out the voltage spikes that come from switching the inductive load (heating trace).
the correct way to filter these spikes is by using a single flyback diode, preferably a schottky diode.
maybe you can leave out D2 and C7 and replace them with a single flyback diode on the footprint of C7.

Author: derspatz
Content: oh, I see you're talking about D1. Yeah, you can probably leave that one out, too. It just protects the circuit from input voltage spikes on the barrel plug (which should not happen anyways)

Author: brettski74
Content: Got my boards from PCBWay today. Very similar to JLCPCB both in terms of resistance and variability. The JLCPCB boards were +/-2.85%. The PCBWay boards were +/-3.43%. I wouldn't read too much into the slightly higher variability of the PCBWay boards. It's only a sample of 5 boards from each fab, so the difference is likely well within the margin of error. PCBWay's board had a slightly higher resistance, which seems to correspond to a copper thickness of roughly 29.1 microns. JLCPCB's boards seems to correspond to a copper thickness of 29.9 microns. Again, small sample size, don't read too much into the difference. I haven't done any rigorous analysis of error margins, but I'd call those results close enough to identical given the quality of data available.

Author: brettski74
Content: If anyone cares about the raw data, the PCBWay boards were 1039, 972, 990, 970 and 1034 milliohms. The JLCPCB boards were 1009, 953, 970, 954 and 983 milliohms. These weren't final boards. I've made further changes to my design, but there it is. One thing I'd eventually like to get around to is to do some durability testing on the boards. The one reason I did try ordering some boards from PCBWay is that there standard FR4 material has a higher glass transition temperature. I don't know if that also means that the solder mask may also be more heat tolerant. That seems to be the first thing that fails from thermal cycling of a PCB hot plate.

Author: nothing4438
Content: That might be limitation of using pcb heater, not 100% sure

Author: brettski74
Content: I'm assuming you're trying to reflow typical tin-lead (SnPb) solder. There are lots of caveats with using a PCB based hot plate. Most of my testing thus far has been on the design of the hotplate itself, focusing on how to design a hotplate for more even heat distribution, solder profiles, safety, hotplate durability and how best to measure temperature. There ar e a lot of caveats. The good news is that some of my most recent results suggest that with a suitable board, PCB hotplates may be more capable than I first thought and maybe even capable of handling SAC305 and similar lead free alloys. The operative word there is "suitable"...

Author: brettski74
Content: If you want to work with SnPb solder, I would suggest sourcing your hotplate boards from PCBWay rather than JLCPCB. Keep in mind this is based on *very* preliminary results and a small set of tests done on one board, but the testing I've done on JLCPCB sourced boards has been pretty consistent in terms of material behaviour and durability, so I suspect the same will apply for other similar suppliers.

Author: brettski74
Content: Boards from JLCPCB start to show very light smoking from about 180 celsius. This is when new and once they've been burned in a couple of times seems to go away, so I'm assuming this is not yet affecting the bulk of the solder mask materials. It's possibly some component of the silkscreen material burning away. From about 200 celsius and up, you start to see smoking of the solder mask materials and above about 220-230 celsius you will probably see delamination (ie bubbling) of the solder mask material in the hotter parts of the board. On the PCBWay board I tested, all of these phenomena started at temperatures about 80-100 celsius higher. This is why I think that these boards would be far more suitable for SnPb work and possibly even SAC305/SAC405 and other alloys with similar melting/liquidus temperatures.

Author: brettski74
Content: All of that also assumes that you're accurately measuring temperatures on the hotplate, which I don't think any designs currently are. On a hotplate that's about 50x70mm with uniform distribution of power across the surface, you can expect the temperature in the centre to be about 50 celsius higher than at the edge at typical reflow temperatures (~180 celsius) for a low temperature alloy (eg. SnBi ~138 celsius melting point).

Author: brettski74
Content: You can expect the temperature measured by a temperature sensor off to the side to be another 20-30 celsius lower, so for the AfterEarthLTD design, if the temperature sensor is reading 180 celsius, the centre of the board may be as high as 250 celsius.

Author: brettski74
Content: Then you need to consider what the temperature is on top of your board, which is what you really care about because that's where you want to melt your solder paste. As a general rule of thumb, that seems to be about 20-30 celsius lower than the hotplate in practical use. So a temperature sensor mounted off to the side of the board is probably giving you a reasonable estimate of the temperature on top of your PCB near the edge of the board, but most other parts are likely much hotter.

Author: brettski74
Content: The best place to mount a temperature sensor would be the underside of the board. The temperature lag here is lowest by a large margin. I don't have great numbers, but from some of my testing, that looks to be somewhere in the 5-10 celsius range, but I'm less confident in those numbers. Mounting a sensor here gets tricky because at reflow temperatures, you'll almost certainly melt the solder securing it to the board unless you're using a much higher temperature alloy. Something like Pb95/Sn5 might do it. That said, for a small SMD component, the surface tension of the solder is probably enough to hold it to the board anyway - particularly if you have larger pads to solder it to.

Author: brettski74
Content: I first started with the v3.0 hardware. I haven't looked at how different the firmware for that is. I'm assuming they're similar. We had to do some fixes to get v3.0 working. I don't think Chris had had a chance to test it. I'm assuming the basic algorithms are similar, though. The firmware as provided seems kinda ok for low temperature solders (eg. SnBi), but like you I had to provide higher temperature options to get SnPb solder to reflow and getting SnPb to reflow does seem to push JLCPCB hotplate boards to their limits and perhaps beyond. That said, there are a number of flaws in that design - not just the firmware but in the electronics as well. With a suitable power supply it can be made to work, but things like the low PWM frequency and limited capacitance mean it will burden your power supply more than intended. There were also criticisms of it's lack of safety features. There is a better design by Spatz and others. There should be links to it further up in the chat. You may want to take a look at that.

Author: brettski74
Content: The air gaps are very effective at stopping thermal transfer and the narrow section of board doesn't doo much more, either. The all in one boards out there tend to do a pretty good job of isolating the electronics from the hotplate. The following thermal image of a v3.0 board should help illustrate this.

Author: brettski74
Content: Try not to read too much into the temperatures. Whether the centre of the board is actually at 230 celsius isn't guaranteed, although it's almost certainly above 200 celsius. Thermography comes with a few caveats when it comes to getting accurate results, although it is fairly precise, so relative temperatures from the same image are generally representative.

Author: brettski74
Content: You can see where the bridge across to the electronics is on the upper right next to the red on the color scale.

Author: brettski74
Content: For reference, the temperature shown on the screen at the time this image was taken was 144 celsius.

Author: brettski74
Content: He said that the programming reported ok. I'm assuming that if the MCU was dead, he should have gotten some kind of error during programming but I'm not an expert on that. I was assuming some bad solder joints or bridging or something preventing some of the pins from outputting a clear signal. If I couldn't find anything, I'd probably remove, clean up the pads, apply some flux and resolder the MCU anyway. Sometimes bad joints and/or bridging is hard to spot. If you have another one available, I'd also swap it in, in case it is a dodgy MCU just in case.

Author: timmc_
Content:
Does anyone follow Solder Reflow Profiles recommended by LED manufacturers? ü•µ

For example:
https://www.osram.com/ecat/KW%20CSLNM1.TG/com/en/class_pim_web_catalog_103489/prd_pim_device_2191206/ has a Reflow Solder Profile chart on page 15 of the data sheet that shows an appropriate temperature to use over five minutes.

I've just been chucking an MCPCB on a UYUE 946-1010 hot plate to swap LEDs in flashlights.

Author: weissnix4711
Content:
https://github.com/AfterEarthLTD/Solder-Reflow-Plate/blob/main/Board%20Versions/70mm%20by%2050mm%20Ver2.4%20ATmega328p/Software/SW1.0_HW2.4_70by50mm/SW1.0_HW2.4_70by50mm.ino#L252

it would appear this reflow plate does follow a very rudimentary reflow profile, which consists of a soak temp fixed at 0.75 * max temp

Author: weissnix4711
Content: you can edit the firmware if you like to change this logic

Author: weissnix4711
Content: but as is, no, you cannot follow such a specific profile

Author: brettski74
Content: It doesn't really do temperature control at all. If I recall correctly, it just set's the duty cycle at a set amount and waits until the temperature sensor reports the set temperature, then it turns off. PID control would be ideal, but possibly overkill. One of my early design goals in improving this design was to build something that could reasonably follow a proper reflow profile, but give what I know now, it's more of a nice to have rather than a required feature. There was some talk about accuracy above... Realistically, it doesn't need to be that accurate. It just needs to get the board, solder paste and components hot enough to melt the solder and form good joints. It's a hobbyist device, not something suitable for cranking out thousands of boards a day. Some degree of temperature control is required to do this well, but it doesn't have to be terribly accurate. It doesn't have to get there in the time required by most reflow profiles - you'll generally need higher power to achieve the specified gradient. You'll also find that where you measure temperature matters a *LOT*. The temperature you really care about is on top of the board being reflowed, and that will be an estimate at best.

Author: brettski74
Content: Right now while I'm still working through designs, I do reflow by hooking my hotplate up to my lab power supply and that works well enough.

Author: derspatz
Content: Here's a preview for what I am currently working on. PCB design is done, I am just working on the schematic annotations to make it easier for someone who would won't to write the firmware for it, as I can't do that.

Author: derspatz
Content: the second device is a small table with the same height as the reflow solder table, but with a pwm controlled 60x60x10mm 5V fan underneath, to cool the boards down faster. it is powered with a cable from the reflow table

Author: brettski74
Content: Interesting trace layout. Are the cutouts there to help relieve stress from thermal expansion? I'm guessing that you have a cool zone along the diagonals from the shape of the traces and the extra copper there.

Author: derspatz
Content: the cutouts are there to break each board into three pieces that fit together to form that table style shape

Author: derspatz
Content: the cutouts in the heat plate are where the base pcbs fit in

Author: brettski74
Content: Ahhh - I see from the other pictures, now. You have pieces that fit into them to put together into table supports.

Author: brettski74
Content: Nice idea.

Author: derspatz
Content: on the cooling table, the small tabs over "EF" from reflow and "60" are where the screw holes of the fan are

Author: brettski74
Content: The higher power spec should probably be enough to match typical reflow profiles for a hotplate that size.

Author: derspatz
Content: there's also a replacable heatplate for 12V

Author: brettski74
Content: I've been working at 12V still, but I generally need somewhere closer to 10A to hit the gradient in most reflow profiles.

Author: brettski74
Content: But hitting those is more of a nice to have than a necessity.

Author: brettski74
Content: Not convinced on the cooling fans, though. If you want to match the number on reflow profiles, then you'll need it but that's the part of the reflow profile I care about the least. From my understanding, the most important part of cooling down is that you don't cool too rapidly. They're usually specified as something like 6 C per second (max). So I'm fine if it takes 5-10 minutes to cool down without forced ventilation.

Author: derspatz
Content:
there's a small IR proximity sensor under the hole in the middle of the heatplate, this way, you should be able to work through batches a lot easier.
you place a pcb in the middle, the buzzer beeps, the pcb heats up, when the target temp is reached, the buzzer beeps again, you slide the pcb over to the cooling fan and place the next pcb in the middle of the heatplate, and when this is done, the pcb that was on the cooling table should be cool enough to be taken away safely, the rest of the cooling can happen somewhere else

Author: brettski74
Content: Ok. Fancy!

Author: derspatz
Content: (i have a tendency to feature creep, but in this case, sensor, buzzer and fan table are purely optional, and don't add much to the cost)

Author: derspatz
Content: there's also two current sense circuits, one to monitor the overall power draw to regulate the PWM, the other one to measure the actual current flowing through the heat plate to calculate the heat plate resistance, and thus the temperature

Author: brettski74
Content: I am curious what the thermals look like, though. I suspect that you are going to see cooler temperatures along those diagonals due to the way that the power density varies in that region and the table supports are going to draw heat down and away from the hotplate in those areas, too. If you push it hot enough, it probably won't matter but if you're at kinda borderline reflow temps, you may have areas of the board that reflow and others that don't.

Author: brettski74
Content: Damn you!

Author: brettski74
Content: I've been working on temperature sensing using the heating element as the sensor, too.

Author: brettski74
Content: It tends to be a lot better than using commercial sensors. You end up with an average temperature across the whole board rather than some value off to the side or underneath or something.

Author: brettski74
Content: And surprisingly accurate - probably not as good as I can get with an NTC thermistor or similar, but more than good enough for this purpose.

Author: brettski74
Content: I've actually been using a DPS5020 power supply module and controlling it over USB via a perl script. The sample time is way too slow to do PID control, but it works pretty well and the temperatures are pretty close to real - within a couple of percent or so.

Author: derspatz
Content:
Here's an image without the silkscreen, so you can see the traces a bit better: i hope this pattern is better for a more ven heat ditribution.
I assume the best way would be thinner traces closer to the edges, so these areas get hotter because they're more resistive

Author: derspatz
Content: my design also has two normal analog temp sensors, but these would probably most useful to determine when the heat plate is at room temp, for calibration purposes. but the placement of the sensors (the small via connected extra areas under the board) should already give better readings

Author: brettski74
Content: I have been tossing up whether to put an NTC thermistor underneath the board, although so far I haven't bothered. My thinking was that I would have the firmware measure the resistance of the heating element on startup and assume that we're at room temperature. Not entirely sure how I would make that go, but one thought was to store the resistance in non-volatile memory and if it's markedly different on startup, report an error and prompt for a new calibration. The user would just need to verify that the hotplate is at "room temperature" and assume that somewhere close enough to 25 celsius.

Author: derspatz
Content: electronic cigarettes (vapes) use the internal resistance of the heating coil to measure the temperature, so this concept seems to be pretty easy and reliable. i think this is the best way to measure the temps. and for the correct ambient temp, a normal sensor is good enough: just assume when the board is below 30¬∞C, it was probably not hot shortly before, because cooldown takes a lot longer than heating up. so we can be sure that 30¬∞C was not actually a "hotspot" and the rest of the board is 20¬∞C

Author: brettski74
Content: Agreed on best way to measure the temp.

Author: brettski74
Content: What are you using for measuring current? I was tossing up between a current sense amplifier or building an instrumentation amplifier using some jellybean op-amps.

Author: brettski74
Content: Regarding even heat distribution, my current design does exactly that - thinner traces near the edge. I've gone through several revisions trying to figure out how best to even out the temperature variation. I currently generate the hotplate layout using a perl script. That makes it a lot easier to mess with parameters and then generate a new board, rather than manually trying to lay it out each time. It also means that I could generate one in pretty much any size in a matter of seconds, which is nice.

Author: derspatz
Content: as board space is pretty limited (it does not look that crowded because of the wide high current traces), and I make sure all parts can be bought at LCSC, i have chosen two TI INA180A2.

Author: derspatz
Content: https://www.ti.com/lit/ds/symlink/ina180.pdf?ts=1661970451398

Author: derspatz
Content: and nice idea with the perl script!

Author: brettski74
Content: Do you have precision problems at low power levels? That was one of my issues. At high power levels, it's great you have all the resolution you need. At low power levels, it's tricky. Maybe this will be less of an issue with the real control board. With the DPS5020, the round trip time is about 1.3 seconds to read the registers so you get current and voltage and then to update them to adjust the power output. It will often overshoot enough that it wants to effectively shut off power completely. I programmed it to not go below 100mA output current, but I only get two decimal places for the voltage, so at 100mA, the resolution is terrible. I have a design using an INA381 current sense amp, but it's not yet working. I figured redesigning it using an LM324 and resistors to build an instrumentation amp, I could have more control over the gain and more flexibility to resolve these kinds of issues.

Author: brettski74
Content: Maybe this will be less of an issue with the faster sampling I should be able to do on a purpose designed control board. Or maybe I can put in some heuristics into the code to prevent PID from going nuts...

Author: derspatz
Content:
the design currently only exists as a KiCAD file, so I can't actually talk about precision. to be honest, I don't even think I will be the one to build this, as I already have the other heat plate, and a pinecil, and a hot air soldering station
but I would also assume that a program should work more like this: apply pwm at a level that doesn't overload the PSU for a short time, disable pwm to measure the resistance, then reapply full power again, and repeat until target temp is reached

Author: brettski74
Content: My intention was to build the driver more like a buck converter - inductor and capacitor to smooth the power into the heating element so that it's effectively DC and take samples for voltage and current at the same point each cycle using timer interrupts.

Author: derspatz
Content: according to my simulations, without pwm, the system settles after 5ms or less, so 10ms should be sufficient wait time, and the actual heatbed current at full power (which is needed for the resistance measurement) should also be measured after 100us or something, so full current is flowing (it has ramp up because of the heat bed inductance), but the current is still coming from the caps, not yet from the PSU

Author: brettski74
Content: Interesting...

Author: derspatz
Content: https://tinyurl.com/2z8rxyox

Author: brettski74
Content: 10uH of inductance in the hotplate? Seems like a lot.

Author: derspatz
Content:
I've chosen a higher value on purpose, to account for worst case scenarios
lower inductance causes less problems of course

Author: brettski74
Content: Fair

Author: brettski74
Content: So you could do 40ms of PWM at whatever duty cycle, 10ms of 100% duty cycle while you make some measurements and then let your PID algorithm adjust the duty cycle for the next 40ms period. Is that the plan?

Author: derspatz
Content: to simluate the resistance measurement, click on the inrush current limiter button, wait until the input current is settled (<20mA), set the gate control to static and off, then turn the gate control on. you can see the input current and the output current rising, but the input current rises slower because of the caps. then you'll need to find a moment where output current is settled, but input current is below the PSU's power limit

Author: brettski74
Content: How much is each division in the time domain?

Author: brettski74
Content: Ok. found it. 5us.

Author: derspatz
Content: 40ms at the max PSU power duty cycle, turn off and wait 5 ms for the power caps to charge fully, apply 100% pwm (or no PWM, just full "on"), measure after 50us or so, then give the system a few ms to relax after full power, then repeat

Author: brettski74
Content: Wouldn't it be 40ms at whatever duty cycle your PID is telling you that you need?

Author: derspatz
Content: yeah, but with such short times (i guess even half a second would be okay), i assume you could just go full power und check the temp afterwards, the overshoot should not be that much

Author: derspatz
Content: one full cycle (power, settle, measure, relax) could be 250ms or something. that's only a little energy put into the board at each cycle

Author: brettski74
Content: Half a second seems too slow. Hard to say for sure, but certainly when I'm limited to more than 1.3 seconds between samples, PID control is poor. My goal was to be able to sample at least 20 times per second, although that's just an educated guess at this point. At the moment, the only working control is using perl on a Raspberry Pi 4 controlling my lab power supply with it's painfully slow round trip time and sample and update.

Author: brettski74
Content: I guess you could do PFM rather than PWM. So, you turn the MOSFET on for some fixed period of time and sample the resistance during that time, then you just turn off for however long you need to get the desired duty cycle.

Author: brettski74
Content: That does resolve the precision issues at low current levels and should obviate the need for an inductor on the control board.

Author: brettski74
Content: Of course, I've already bought the inductors at this point... Seems a shame to waste them.

Author: derspatz
Content: The actual timing should of course be tested on the real device, but I think with pwm and input power measurement (which allow limiting the power input to safe levels for a longer time) on one hand, and the pretty short times needed for measuring the resistance on the other hand, you can have a wide range possible timings

Author: derspatz
Content: Pfm (with full power, which is needed for simultaneously measuring the resistance) would only work for very short periods of time before you overload the psu

Author: brettski74
Content: PFM at a x% duty cycle should be no different from PWM at x% duty cycle provided that your caps are sized appropriately for the on time.

Author: brettski74
Content: Ahhh... but 10ms is a long time I guess. I may need to figure out how big those caps would be...

Author: brettski74
Content: My gut is starting to tell me, "Very big"

Author: derspatz
Content: The max capacitors I can fit on the board (with 35v and sufficient ripple current) is 5x220uF

Author: brettski74
Content: My current design was based on an operating frequency of 32-ish kHz, so 10ms of on time would be a lot longer than I've currently sized my caps for.

Author: derspatz
Content: the max current through a cold heat bed is ca. 8A

Author: derspatz
Content: feel free to adjust my simulation to your design. my simulation is basically a very simple design: inrush current limiter (could be left out), voltage divider for the adc, power caps, different heat bed ins different temps, mosfet with driver (the zener diode determines the gate driver voltage, you could of course also do something transistor based)

Author: derspatz
Content: anyways, I need to got to bed now üòâ

Author: brettski74
Content: I hadn't seen that simulator before. I've used LTSpice in the past but I find it a bit frustrating to use.

Author: brettski74
Content: I also need to go. Big day to tomorrow and I need to pack the car.

Author: brettski74
Content: Later...

Author: derspatz
Content: Laterz...

Author: derspatz
Content: this simulator is much less powerful, but also much easier to use

Author: derspatz
Content: and it is good enough for rough estimations

Author: derspatz
Content: have fun tomorrow!

Author: derspatz
Content: you can find most necessary documentation in the schematic (also available as pdf)

Author: derspatz
Content: if you have any more questions, feel free to ask me!

Author: derspatz
Content: also: who would want to test and write the firmware?

Author: derspatz
Content:
Here's some more info:
This is a major overhaul of my first design, the main principle is the same, but almost everything was changed under the hood:
- new MCU that is cheap and available (STM32G030)
- USB C and barrel plug input (12-24V)
- replacable heat beds (different sizes and different voltages)
- table design with interlocked PCBs
- dual current measurement (one for monitoring the filtered input current, one for monitoring the unfiltered output current for resistance measurements)
- heat bed temperature is calculated by heat bed resistance
- sufficient capacitors with inrush current limiter
- dedicated gate driver
- analog temp sensor on the underside of the heat bed
- OLED display
- dual color LED
- three buttons (less hassle)
- proximity sensor under the heat bed, for easier automation of soldering process
- acoustic alarm
- cable connector to power fan table

Author: derspatz
Content:
But generally, I assume we should not worry too much about heat dissipation from the top plate to the main board: this device is best used with low temp solder paste, and the heat transfer between plate and the pcb that needs soldering should be far better than between plate and main pcb, so the when the main pcb is soldered with normal solder, the low temp solder paste should melt much earlier than the main pcb.
Only critical point might be the solder connection to the header, but in use the header is held in place, and this part is cheap to replace, just keep a spare header and heat plate pcb in your drawer

Author: probably_erwins_cat

However, heating and cooling cycles can stress the material and the placement of the connector right now could be optimized. Similiar to the video but with proper strain relief and temperature control.

Author: derspatz
Content: By measuring the voltage and the current of the heat bed. The resistance of the heat bed depends on its temperature, so by knowing the resistance of the heat bed @20C and the specific coefficient for copper, we can estimate the temperature at different resistances

Author: azab2c
Content:
Hello!  Interesting project!  Discovered via Great Scott content.  Curious what's the latest greatest design folks are gravitating towards building?

Noticed https://github.com/AfterEarthLTD/Solder-Reflow-Plate hasn't been updated in a while, but am seeing a bunch of forks actively being progressed.

Planning to place a small jlcpcb order soon.  Would be funny to include an order for this hotplate project as part of that order, to help me assemble my own project.

Curious if there's a ESP8266/ESP32 (or some Wifi capable) version of this project with the hot plate portion separate from the controller parts.  Seems like the hot plate portion will atrophy faster than the controller.  Would be nice to decouple controller from hotplate (use Alu?).  Would help with replacing/iterating hotplate board design faster, help controller longevity if only the hot plate (and thermistor) is housed.  Entire hotplate could be 100mm x 100mm while taking advantage of jlcpcb's cheap pricing.  Alternative/forked hotplate designs could be swapped out and used.  Expect heavy gauge wiring and connectors between controller and hotplate boards.

Anyway, I know nothing, and just joined.  Look forward to learning how the  community has progressed this project, and will try to help.  Cheers!

Content: Thoughts on using Alu for the hot plate board.  Coating underside with thick insulating layer of high temperature sealant (e.g. stove gasket sealant, or 3M fire block?

Author: probably_erwins_cat
Content:
the issue will be which material of that compound will be the weakest link. there is copper, alu, glue(!), silkscreen, ...
If I am forced to make a bet, it will likely be the glue or coating that will make trouble first. I would guess that a ceramic PCB would be best because It has the highest heat resistance and least number of heat critical materials

Author: probably_erwins_cat
Content: ceramic boards can be manufactured with direct copper plating or silver metalization and then covered with glass passivation. then not a single material is used that cannot withstand higher temperatures for ages. however, those pcb would be expensive as hell if not orderen in huge quantities

Author: probably_erwins_cat
Content: best insulator would be simple double-walled construction with non-convective air in between. cheap and effective

Author: derspatz
Content:
For me, the main advantage of the design with a pcb as heat plate ist still that it is very cheap, with a replaceable heat plate even more so. IMHO, all tricks to increase the longevity of the heat plate only drive up costs.
If you really need a more reliable design for more than a few prototypes a year, there are many better solutions (mains powered heat plate with relay, small oven etc.) that also cost more but the additional cost is distributed more evenly over the whole design.

Author: azab2c
Content:
LOL, I'm no "Cody's Lab", am not going to be depositing copper traces onto ceramics.  Sorry I wasn't clear, will try again...

Am thinking of using these cheap throw-away priced PCBs as heat plate, but suspend and insulate (enclosed air gap underside) with ceramic/porcelain tile left overs.   Keeping the controller board located close, but far away enough to remain thermally cool.

Author: probably_erwins_cat
Content: that makes more sense. yes, any second layer with small gap so air can not follow free convection is a good insulator.

Author: derspatz
Content:
the problem is:
every part of the heat bed will eventually heat up. the copper will transfer the heat anywhere on the pcb. routing thinner traces to the connector does not solve the problem, as this raises the resistance at these points, causing more heat
that's why wide connections are actually better
my 1.27mm header solution is far from optimal, but it is cheap, easy to solder, does not interrupt the heat plate, and it is held in place by the other part of the connector, so even of the solder connection does melt (which it shouldn't), there's no instant catastrophic failure (I would even assume that molten solder is far more resistive than solid solder, and this jump in resistance could be measured and cause a emergency shutdown in softrware)

also, I'd remove the capacitor in parallel to the heat bed, add a lot more filter capacitance to the main power rail, add a proper driver for the main mosfet, and the 22uF in parallel to the 300k on the DC-DC output makes no sense, CC1/CC2 pulldowns are missing, and what does GPIO29_ADC3 do?

Author: derspatz
Content:
I would recommend to always read the specs of a standard you are using, or at least the Wikipedia article for it.
Same goes for datasheets: stick to the parts values given in the datasheet, unless the datasheet specifically allows changing the values (or you know exactly what you are doing). 
So generally, rtfm! üòâ

Author: derspatz
Content: Yeah, I understand, even though I'd assume this is an error in the article

Author: y2k
Content: Heh, fair enough, ive kinda always been under the impression that more capacitance = better even tho that probably doesn't make any sense. Ill go back and make some changes or hell might just redo it, unsure. Thanks again!

Author: derspatz
Content:
In some cases, more capacitance is better, even though there's also a limit (inrush current, Max capacitive load etc.)
But usually, if there's a capacitance in the range of picofarads to a few nanofarads, it is usually better to stick to the exact value

Author: derspatz
Content: As a very general rule of thumb (with many grains of salt), capacitance between voltage rail and ground can have more variation, if it is not part of a circuit that works in the frequency domain (filters etc.)

Author: .spelter666
Content:
one thing I don't like is, when you solder a terminal onto the board, you have to secure it against the heat. if solder gets warm or the pcb expands, the solder will crack when it gets cold again. when we talk 3D printer buildplates, we talk 100C, maxium of 120C, and it happened there too. that's the reason, aluminium buildplates are a thing and the silicone heating pad is not getting that hot, it relies on the heat transfer of the aluminum.

Author: azab2c
Content: My fault, I assumed they'd assemble per part datasheet recommendations.  I didn't rtfm for max reflow temp of LED datasheet, and didn't rtfm temp of jclpcb assembly service.  The cheapest/default assembly option reflows with 255c peak.  LED says to peak at 240c.  I should have selected "Standard" assembly. More details at https://forum.v1engineering.com/t/pcb-design-good-or-bad-idea-to-use-multilayer-gnd-pads-to-stitch-plane-and-connect-led/34635/7?u=aaronse

Author: brettski74
Content: I've done some work on how durable PCB hotplates are. There is some discussion further back in the channel history, but the main points are that PCBWay boards are better suited to the thermal cycling than JLCPCB. JLCPCB boards show deterioration of the silk screen and solder mask well below 200 celsius and above 200 celsius, expect lots of smoke. PCBWay boards typically show the similar signs at about 80-100 celsius higher temperatures than JLCPCB. I really like JLCPCB's service, but for hotplates, I only order from PCBWay now.

Author: brettski74
Content: Mask colour doesn't seem to matter much, although I've only worked with green and black solder mask. It's possible that different colours might handle the temperature better, but I have my doubts. I expect that the base resin is the same. It's just a matter of different pigments added to the base resin to get the colours.

Author: 50ohm
Content: Is the solder mask helping to spread the heat more evenly? I would remove it, so that any part which is getting hot, is not getting in contact with the solder mask.

Author: brettski74
Content:
I would recommend against removing the solder mask. I'm assuming your reasoning is that having the solder mask burn off is undesirable. But if you don't have solder mask over it, then what?

Nothing? Bad idea. Copper oxidizes. This is slow at room temperature, but happens faster at elevated temperatures. You'll may shorten the life of the heating element or change it's operational characteristics over time. That may happen anyway, but I'd rather slow that as much as possible.

HASL? This is a solder coating. On a heating element designed to melt solder. You could end up with your reflowed board stuck to the hotplate.

ENIG? Why pay the higher cost for what might be a wear item anyway? We don't know how well PCB hotplates stand up over time anyway. Why pay ten or more times the price for ENIG when you can get something else for like $2 for 5 hotplates?

Any metal finish, including ENIG and HASL? You also run the risk of pads or other metal elements on your reflowed board shorting tracks in you heating element. This will give you hot spots and cold spots and could risk burning out portions of the heating element.

Standard $2 for 5 prototype boards from PCBWay work pretty well and withstand temperatures for standard 63/37 Sn/Pb solder quite well. Even lead free alloys like SAC305 might be ok, although that is pushing close to the limits from my testing, although I don't really work with lead free solder, so your mileage may vary. JLCPCB boards are less resistant to high temperature, but if you're willing to limit yourself to lower temperature SnBi alloys that melt around 140 celsius, you can probably get pretty good mileage from those as well. Those are the only two fabs I've used. There may be other manufacturers who have similar or better results with their materials.

Author: alexm3020
Content: I would also advise against removing the solder mask purely because you have atleast 10Amps of current flowing through the traces and if you were to accidentally short a trace on the board you are trying to heat up on the exposed copper traces, you would immediately fry the trace. Solder masks is capable of of handling over 255 C (491f) so it shouldnt be a problem

Author: alexm3020
Content: again this isnt meant to be a reliable and constantly reuseable reflow pad. This is meant more for small appliations where the cost doesnt justify spending the money on an actual pcb heater.

Author: xchrismas
Content: Quick and dirty circuit to monitor the approximate actual heatbed temperature

Author: liftyee
Content: What MCU 's on that little PCB?

Author: sy321_alpha
Content: I looked over the circuit the other day, any idea what the on-board temp sensor is for? Because to me, it made more sense for it to be touching/mounted on the hot plate itself..or have i missed something?

Author: xchrismas
Content: Its a ATtiny841 that's on a custom little breakout board with an 3.1V LDO

Author: xchrismas
Content:
Personally I think the og creator didn't really know which temp sensor to choose so they took what they knew best. 
The Temp sensor thats on there is too far away and doesn't really work if you dont know the Delta between actual temp and compensate for it in software. My hotplate for example gets stuck at around 80C (when trying to reach for 90C, which is the first stop in the temperature curve) because its not compensated for in software, so it never finishes the temp-curve. 
According to my little temperature monitoring circuit the hotplate reaches 130C when the Onboard sensor senses 70C, the Delta gets larger over time and therefore the onboard sensor is very inaccurate

After two to three minutes my circuit reaches about 145C and hovers there, which i assume is the maximum temperature the heatplate can achieve at 12V5A, but I wouldn't count on the exact value since my circuit (thermistor) is only capable of showing about 150C. 
This is enough for for my solderpaste, which requires around 130C. Another thing to keep in mind is that the copper underneath the soldermask is probably still significantly hotter - like 160-180C. So that is that.  

I think my method of monitoring is superior to the onboard sensor is  but not necessary to reflow your boards if you just cancel the process manually once your solder flowed

Author: xchrismas
Content: So yeah a simple 100k ntc thermistor that can go up to 150C, which you tape on the front of the heatplate would be better suited to do the temp monitoring

Author: sy321_alpha
Content: The temperature delta makes sense, not the best when it comes to programming so no comments on the software correcting this delta. Regarding the 'max temp is 145C'(I am aware this may be limited due to the sensor you're using, would a board with 2oz of copper at 0.8mm thickness allow for higher temps?

Author: sy321_alpha
Content: have my a-level mocks and stuff right now, but when my schedule gets a bit more relaxed, was thinking about tinkering with the circuit to make it THT(for first time builds), and adding the suggestions in #og-srp, and as suggested might look into whether mouser has any high-temp temp sensors to give a direct reading of the plate temp that coders can use.

Author: xchrismas
Content: I dont know if you would reach any higher temps by just changing the copper, but you certainly can by upping the Amps. Though i would not advise on doing so since the PCBs degrade fast enough with the kind of stress we are putting through (like i said the internal heat is likely a lot higher than my surface mount reading and considering there is basically no regulation due to the lacking software) and a good solder paste will flow well enough with the current setup.
