There is a partially complete BOM with Digikey and Mouser part numbers at in my github repo at https://github.com/brettski74/Solder-Reflow-Plate/blob/main/Board%20Versions/70mm%20by%2050mm%20Ver3.0%20ATmega4809/Board%20Files/BOM_SRP%2070_50mm_Release_2022-03-04-digikey.csv

Author: brettski74
Content: That said, I used the original design a handful of times and have since moved on to better options. These days I mostly use a hotplate of my own design driven by my lab power supply.  My power supply allows for remote control via USB and since it also displays current and voltage, I can use that to make temperature measurements of the hotplate. I have a bunch of perl scripts to control it all which work reasonably well, but still working through some bugs. I also have a purpose built controller designed but not tested. In theory it would provide tighter control of the temperature of the hotplate than my lab supply, but frankly, the results with my lab supply are pretty good already, so my motivation to build and test the dedicated design are rather low.

Author: brettski74
Content: Regarding 2.4 software on V3.0 hardware... no. You need V3.0 software to work with the V3.0 hardware. That's also in my repo, although my repo is a fork of a fork. Most of the fixes come from the vonryan fork. I added a few more fixes to the UI and documentation that is mostly correct for the V3.0 hardware.

Author: brettski74
Content: One of the frustrating things about this discord is that it's effectively unmanaged. Everyone with admin privileges doesn't really come here any more. I'm not criticizing you, but a lot of these questions come up again and again and are many of the same questions that most of us had when we first came here, but it's not exactly easy to find those answers in the months and months of chat history. We really need stuff collected into a FAQ. I could add that to my repo, and while I see a few people have found it and used it, I'm not sure that's the most accessible place for it to be. Ideally, we would have a proper FAQ on here somewhere so people could find the answers to these questions without them needing to be asked and answered again and again. I'm not overly familiar with Discord. This server was my first and only exposure to discord but I'm assuming that someone with admin privs would be able to organize things better here. Every so often the discussion here tends towards moving somewhere else where someone active could actually administer and/or moderate things but I haven't seen anything materialize yet.

Author: brettski74
Content: There are a number of issues with the original solution that I wanted to address. The hotplate is just a hotplate, but I also have variable track geometry to try to distribute the heat more evenly across the entire area.

Author: brettski74
Content: There are no components mounted on it, which let's me maximize the area available for heating/reflow and stay within the 100mmx100mm limit for cheap boards from the chinese fabs.

Author: brettski74
Content: The original intention was that the power and control circuitry would be a separate board connected by wires. This also makes bootstrapping the system easier.

Author: brettski74
Content: I figure if I'm building a reflow hotplate, it's because I want to do SMD and I want to reflow my boards, not hand solder them.

Author: brettski74
Content: So I see the redesigns that use larger components for easier hand soldering or THT designs as missing the point. If you have a decent lab power supply, you can just hook it up to the hotplate directly and reflow the original power/control board that way. That's what I effectively did with the original design as well. I just soldered some wires onto one of the spare boards and used it to reflow the one that I built. I mentioned this in my build instructions.

Author: brettski74
Content: The design also included current and voltage sensing on the hotplate so that I could calculate resistance in real time and use the hotplate itself as the temperature sensor.

Author: brettski74
Content: But once you're doing that and hooking up the hotplate to a digital power supply that already does voltage and current sensing and is remote controllable via USB or bluetooth, then you start wondering whether you really need a purpose built power/control board, or whether you just need a USB cable and some scripts to control it.

Author: brettski74
Content: My early attempts at control tried to use PID, but the round trip communications time was way too slow. I think I can only reliably read the registers and write an update to the power supply about once every 1.5 seconds. So my current code uses some estimates of the properties of the system like the thermal resistance to ambient of the hotplate and it's heat capacity. It then looks at the current temperature and the temperature it needs to get to by the next sample time and how much power it should need to get there and just commands that amount of power. It's not exactly open loop as there is some feedback going on, but it's not exactly adapting to changing conditions like a PID system might, either. As a technique that works remarkably well - far better than you really need. For hobby purposes, you're probably going to be just as well off with assuming that you need X watts/amps/volts for reflow and setting your power supply to do that for a few minutes until you see the components have all reflowed.

Author: brettski74
Content: Script-wise, I'm sorting out a few bugs. Hardware wise, I've been through about 6 iterations and while it's better than a uniform track design, there are still some things that could be better, but again, it's a matter of how picky do we really need to be. I can reliably reflow SnPb solders and if I order my hotplates from PCBWay, they seem to deal with the heat ok. It comes down to how picky we want/need to be. For hobby use, the difference between 95% yields and 99.999% yields doesn't matter that much and a much more primitive approach with these boards like the aforementioned constant power and watch it reflow approach is probably going to exceed most people's expectations.

Author: brettski74
Content: If I recall correctly, I think I'm seeing about 20-30 celsius difference in temperature between the hottest and coldest portions of my latest hotplate. It's been a few months since I've looked at this seriously. For a hotplate with uniform track widths of similar size, you're looking at 60-70 celsius deltas between centre and edge at an average temperature of 220 celsius - again going from memory, but I'm pretty sure the data I captured were somewhere in that ballpark.

Author: brettski74
Content: Copper laid out evenly is the default position for most designs and exactly what V3.0 and V2.4 boards from AfterEarthLtd do. What you need is variable geometry tracks. Thicker tracks in some places. Thinner tracks in others. Heat dissipation across the board is not uniform. You lose more heat at the edges than in the middle, which makes the edges colder by a surprisingly large margin. So the tracks at the edge are thinner than in the middle. You also lose more heat toward the corners of the board, so the outer tracks are not a uniform width all the way along, either. You also lose more heat at corners in the tracks, so you might want to do something different there, but that's probably getting more picky than I really need to be.

Author: cobalt6700
Content:
Ha, fair. A bit annoyed that I made such a schoolboy error.  

It is a model railway locomotive wireless DCC controller - it allows me to use either a standard RC Tx and Rx OR my own design nRF24 based controller as control input, then 'build' a DCC signal. This signal is fed to a motor board which in turn drives the DCC decoder. 

Reason for two MCU's - my coding knowledge is basic, so I am using some available code (DCC++EX) running on one MCU. The creation of DCC signals is very timing critical, so running other software on that MCU requires specific libraries + interrupt setups. 

To make things easy, I run my code on the other MCU, and then send serial commands to the other (this is an availbe feature of DCC++EX). 

The many connectors are for Servos, smoke unit connection, and then a few extra incase I have a new idea and want an output.

Content: I generally prefer to use SnPb solder, which is doable on FR4 boards depending on where you get them from. PCBWay boards seem to deal with the heat better than JLCPCB, so I would recommend PCBWay for your hotplates if you plan to use SnPb solder. If you're willing to work with SnBi only, then JLCPCB are fine. SAC is "possible", but don't expect your hotplate to last very long. That's pushing the material properties just a bit too far.

Author: brettski74
Content: The spiral design... There are some reasons you might consider a spiral layout for the heating element, but I prefer a bifilar layout. The spiral design will increase the inductance of the heating element. I guess that could be desirable depending on how you intend to drive it, but it also creates a problem with how you get the power to the centre of the element. It can be done, but then you need vias or something which introduce new elements to complicate things and/or fail over multiple heat/cool cycles. The bifilar layout gives you the symmetry advantages you might get from a spiral layout but it gets both ends of the heating element to the outside making power connection trivial and the magnetic field mostly cancel out reducing the parasitic inductance of the heating element.

Author: brettski74
Content: The tracks look fairly widely spaced. I think it would be better if the spacing between the tracks were less. I'd expect more even heating and less stress on the overall assembly.

Author: brettski74
Content: I use a USB controlled power supply module to drive mine. The round trip comms time is about 1.3 seconds. To be safe, my scripts sample and update every 1.5 seconds and I still get excellent tracking. I have done some calibration, so I do some estimation and prediction of what the future temperature will be given a particular power level, but even with just bang-bang type control, you'll be more than close enough for most practical purposes.

Author: brettski74
Content: I would suggest that you use the heating element itself as your temperature sensor. If you can measure current and voltage, you can calculate the temperature of the heating element.

Author: brettski74
Content: Using external temperature sensors like thermistors are nice as a sanity check, but getting good coupling can be a challenge and you also get variation in temperature across the surface of the hotplate with temperatures in the centre typically being quite a bit higher than at the edge.

Author: brettski74
Content: That sounds like waaaay too much effort to reflow a board. If you're going to go to the trouble of implementing some kind of thermistor or RTD based temperature measurement system, why not just implement PWM, set it to some sane power level and wait until you see the solder reflow to turn it off? For a 100x100mm hotplate, you don't need more than about 60-80W.

Author: brettski74
Content: You could make 50W work. Use a smaller hotplate. Maybe use low temperature (SnBi) solder paste. Don't care as much about following a strict solder profile. The main goals of solder profiles are 1) avoid heating or cooling too quickly to reduce stress on components and 2) limit the amount of time at reflow temperatures to be long enough to ensure good joints but no longer. 50W should be able to get you to 170 celsius or so, especially if you have a smaller hotplate. That's plenty for reflowing SnBi.

Author: h0oni
Content: What are the considerations for designing the hot plate? should I go for a bit higher resistance? I am planning to run it with either 12V 10A psu or another 20V 5A psu. What should be the trace resistance for each of the psu for optimum performance?

Author: brettski74
Content:
Start with how much power you need the hotplate to output. This will be dependent on how large your hotplate is, what temperature you want to be able to reach and how fast.

For max temperature, use about 30 celsius above the melting/liquidus temperature of the solder alloy you want to reflow, so about 170 celsius for SnBi or 210 for SnPb.

For your hotplate size, start with your desired dimensions, do the calculations and if the power requirement is too high, then adjust. My current design has a heating element that is 85mm x 88mm, which fits nicely on a 100mmx100mm board with some space at the edges to allow for mounting, power connection and some spaces for recording parameters like the hotplate resistance at 20 celsius. For my 85x88 mm board, the area is 7480 square mm.

To get an estimate of how much power you need, take the area of your heating element in square mm and multiply it by 0.00032. This will give you an estimate of the thermal resistance to ambient air of your hotplate in K/W. For my example 7480 square mm board, this gives me a thermal resistance of about 2.4 K/W.

Subtract typical ambient temperature (eg 25 celsius) from your maximum temperature to give yourself a temperature delta in Kelvin. Assuming low temperature SnBi solder, I get 170 - 25 = 145 K.

Take that temperature delta and divide it by the thermal resistance you estimated above - 145 / 2.4 = 60.4W. This is the absolute minimum power you'd need to hold the hotplate at 145 Kelvin above the ambient air. In reality, you'll need more than this if you hope to get to your target temperature in a reasonable amount of time. From my experience, adding an additional 30% is a good lower limit that will let you follow a reflow profile reasonably well, so 60.4 x 1.3 = 78.5W. So you probably want about 80W of power. If your power supply can provide that, then happy days. If not, adjust something and try again.

Author: brettski74
Content: Once you have the power requirement, you can figure out resistance based on the capabilities of your power supply.  You need a resistance that can dissipate the power required while staying with the voltage and current limitations of your supply. I'd err on the side of keeping current lower and maximizing voltage, but also keep in mind that the heating element resistance may be something like 50% higher at reflow temperatures than it is a room temperature. I'd check that you can meet your power requirements at both temperatures for best results, otherwise you may struggle to keep up as the heating element gets warmer.

Author: brettski74
Content: Once you have resistance, you can then design your board. You can estimate track resistance based on the length of the individual paths, the thickness of the trace (maybe 30 microns or so) and the width, along with the resistivity of copper.

Author: brettski74
Content: Fun times!

Author: brettski74
Content: I'm thinking for my next iteration altering the design to work better with typical laptop power bricks, which typically run at 19V. I want it to be able to reflow SnPb solder, so I'll be aiming for about 100W. I don't necessarily need that for my power supply, but it will work for me and should also work well for USB-PD at 20V or for laptop power bricks at 19V, so seems like a better design choice than the higher current hotplates I'm using currently.

Author: brettski74
Content: The other thing that can sometimes be frustrating is that the measured resistance of my designs don't always match the predictions that I calculate. You may need to iterate a few times to get the result your looking for and you may need to repeat that if you switch to a new manufacturer. My last iteration I got manufactured by PCBWay but most of the iterations before that came from JLCPCB. I switched because PCBWay boards seem to handle the high temperatures better but the resistance came in about 30% lower than expected. I can still use them because my power supply is pretty beefy and can do up to 20A, but I expect most people would struggle to drive enough current into them. I'm not sure if PCBWay is giving me thicker copper (doubtful) or I just messed up the calculations somewhere (possible) or I've missed something entirely, but there it is.

Author: brettski74
Content: I typically use 63/37 SnPb solder. The solder profile I use tops out at 210 celsius which has been working quite well for me.

Author: brettski74
Content: I don't think PCB hotplates are a realistic solution for SAC305 and similar alloys. The temperatures are too high and I don't think a PCB heater will last very long being cycled to the necessary temperatures. SnPb is doable, but if you want to have a hotplate that lasts, you need to be selective on where you get it made. PCBWay boards seem to handle these temperatures much better than JLCPCB boards.

Author: brettski74
Content: A couple of suggestions for your design... Avoid soldering onto the hotplate board. Mechanical connections are a better idea IMHO. You already are using screws and stand-offs in your mounting solution. Leverage those. I use ring connectors and have large pads around my M3 screws to provide connection to the board. That avoids the challenge of soldering those wires on and any concerns about them coming off under heat. That should also allow you to get rid of the long air-gapped piece that seems to serve no purpose except for isolating the power connections from the heat. Use silicone insulated wire for your power connections and you should be fine.

Author: ovilers

Author: brettski74
Content: With the miracle of Google and the internet, you can read for hours and hours on the pros and cons of various solder alloys. For most purposes, any of the commonly used alloys will work fine and you probably won't notice a difference. I personally prefer SnPb solder, because it's the alloy that we have the most experience with, it has good wetting characteristics, good mechanical properties and reasonably good conductivity. Also, if you get the eutectic alloy (63/37), it has a single, actual freezing point rather than a liquidus/solidus temperature range and this makes it easier to get good joints when hand soldering. I tend to avoid SAC alloys because of the higher temperature and the liquidus/solidus temperature range means that you end up with poor joints if there's much movement while it's freezing. I have some SnBi solder paste, but I rarely use it because the conductivity is lower, the joints are more brittle and if you use the cheapest finish on your boards (HASL with leaded solder) you risk forming SnBiPb intermetallics in the joint which may have liquidus temperatures below 100 celsius. That said, for most purposes you probably won't notice much difference and I'm probably overthinking it.

Author: solexious
Content: Anyone had an issue with the mosfet desoldering and letting out its magic smoke? I bought a v2.4 premade kit off a UK ebay seller, it worked well for about 6 or so uses, but then I did a run of 5 reflows back to back doing a short production run and the fet started to desolder and let out its magic smoke and now won't heat any more. The board seemed well made and I couldn't find any issues with it. Has anyone else experienced this? (I was using a 12v 5a psu off amazon for it and when heating it went down to about 11.1v)

Author: brettski74
Content: It's a resistor. Just select one that's the same package size (0805) and resistance (1k) and it'll be fine. I'd probably stick to 1% tolerance as well because they're still very cheap and more accurate than you need for most purposes.

Author: brettski74
Content: Which firmware are you using?

Author: brettski74
Content: There are a number of design issues with the v2.4 and v3.0 designs. I've not heard of this particular problem before, but it also doesn't surprise me. While the board design does incorporate some air gaps to thermally isolate the electronics from the hotplate, the MOSFET is right next to the hotplate and virtually without any air gap to isolate it. It wouldn't surprise me if successive cycles without enough time to cool down could eventually get it hot enough to reflow its solder and at those elevated temperatures the chance of keeping the junction temperature under load low enough to avoid damage might also be compromised.  I guess we can chalk this up to another weakness of the design. A lot of the people on here have moved on to other designs.

Author: brettski74
Content: Better for several reasons is to have the hotplate completely separate from the driver circuitry.

Author: brettski74
Content:
Just order it and see what happens and be prepared to may have to pay a bit extra to get your stuff free after it lands. In my experience, one of three things will happen: 
1. Your stuff will just arrive and you don't have to worry about anything either because the amount is too small or the seller arranged to pay customs and/or tax  for you on your behalf.###
2. The carrier will take care of the customs stuff and will then collect customs fees, taxes and brokerage fees from you when they deliver your stuff. +++
3. Your stuff will get held at a post office or depot of some sort and you'll get a notice telling you to come and pick it up after paying customs fees, faxes and brokerage fees. +++

### Technically, things like sales tax, GST and VAT are often the responsibility of the buyer to pay but when the amounts are so small, the labour spent in collecting and account for it costs more than the amount collected, so for small purchases you're likely to just have your stuff let straight through.
+++ Carriers like Fedex, DHL and UPS typically have options to allow you to pay the fees owed up front via their website. You can often find out how to do this via the tracking function on their website although some are better at this than others. Fedex could learn a thing or two from DHL in this respect.

Content: Do you have the right firmware? What pin is driving the MOSFET in your source code? Look for the definition of the mosfet macro.

Author: sanzang3597
Content: Hi, guys. How is this getTemp() formula calculated? I have checked the LTM85LP datasheet, but still have no idea. Can anyone explain this step by step. Thanks.

Author: rubacava
Content: There is nothing special here. Just averages and converts to Celsius

Author: kanken6174
Content: the LTM85LP  is quite simple, unlike a regular NTC thremistor, it outputs a *linear* voltage curve that is directly properotionnal to the temperature

Author: kanken6174
Content: so here they're just reading that analog voltage value and converting it back to the actual temperature

Author: brettski74
Content: That question has been asked a lot of times and I haven't seen a good answer. I'm assuming you're good with the oversampling part. The rest looks like a two-point linear approximation but I'm not sure if there's any combination of points from the datasheet that would arrive at those numbers even after you factor in the ADC gain. Maybe it's wrong or maybe I am. I think we'd need Chris to explain how he arrived at those numbers but I've never seen him on here. Most of us that have gone on to do much work on reflow hotplates aren't using Chris's design any more so I don't think explaining and/or testing that code has been a high priority for anyone.

Author: brettski74
Content: Actually, I did see Chris on here a couple of time last June or July, but he's not around much any more. I guess he's either busy or moved on to other projects.

Author: brettski74
Content: Probably the best and most complete design that's been shared on here is the one by @derspatz  and others. There have been numerous others that people have shared images of or spoken about as either being worked on or working, including my own, but I haven't seen designs shared. I personally am using a hotplate that I drive directly from my lab power supply under USB control by  scripts I run on a raspberry Pi, so my focus has been on making the hotplate as good as I can and on getting the software working as well as it can. Most new people coming to this Discord are arriving via Chris's Github repo and so that's the thing they're initially trying to build. It's not a bad place to start and learn some things about reflowing PCBs with a hotplate,. It will do the job provided you have a suitable power supply but it does have some issues and there are better solutions out there.

Author: sanzang3597
Content: Ok, I know a good power supply is one thing and I do have one can support 12V@20A. What are some other known issues and things to look after for the first build? I really appreciate your good information and help.

Author: brettski74
Content: People have used much less capable power supplies, but I suspect that they've been highly reliant on the output capacitance of the supply to avoid overloading it. The v2.4 and v3.0 designs have insufficient input capacitance to buffer the load of the heating element at the rather low PWM frequency that the stock firmware uses. Changing the register settings to use a higher PWM frequency would help a little. The max you can get is about 63kHz but even at that much higher frequency, 100uF of input capacitance is far too low for the load. If you make a few assumptions like trying to limit the input current to about 7.5A average and 10A peak, then you still need somewhere around 1320uF of input capacitance. The @derspatz design uses roughly double that. Check out my fork. I've forked the vonryan fork which had some of the v3.0 fixes plus a few more v3.0 fixes of my own and also updated the documentation both for accurate v3.0 build information as well as some of the issues with the design as is. It's been linked here often lately, so I won't link it again. Scroll back up a page or two and you'll see a link.

Author: brettski74
Content: Not at all. The first board I reflowed on a hotplate was my v3.0 hotplate, which was the first one I built. I included instructions to do this when I updated the documentation to be accurate for v3.0. The main PCB manufacturers don't just give you one board. If you have an appropriate power supply, hook up some wires and use one of your other boards to reflow your first hotplate. It won't be as pretty or convenient, but it's a one-time effort and it's still way easier than trying to hand solder. Ovens and skillets and toaster ovens can work as well.

Author: brettski74
Content: I'm not sure what you mean by "i don't see the updi port on the nano but i see d6"

Author: brettski74
Content: The nano doesn't have UPDI.

Author: brettski74
Content: But if you load the JTAG2UPDI sketch, you're essentially programming it to act like a UPDI programmer and the D6 pin is what is used for the UPDI data output line in JTAG2UPDI.

Author: justmattchu
Content: Gotchya, I followed all of that and I still cannot get it to upload

Author: brettski74
Content: So you would use the standard Arduino Nano board definition to program the Nano with JTAG2UPDI. Once you've done that, you can connect it's D6 line to the UPDI pin on the hotplate board. You also need to connect ground to ground. You can also need power to the MCU on the hotplate board.

Author: justmattchu
Content: wait so the hotplate needs to be powered by the 12v while doing this? I thought you only needed updi and grd connected when uploading

Author: brettski74
Content: That can be done by either connecting 12V and the 5V LDO will supply power to the MCU. Alternatively, you can connect the 5V line of your Arduino Nano to the 5V pin on the 3-pin UPDI connector on your hotplate board. That can also supply 5V to the MCU. Pick one or the other. Don't do both.

Author: brettski74
Content: 12V is one way. The 5V pin on the UPDI connector is the other option.

Author: .ngeran
Content: Noob question - how can I verify if    The programming was successful- I have 4 boards with the same issue. Program uploaded successfully according to arduino ide  but the screen stays black. Thank you in advance

Author: brettski74
Content: I'd start with the most basic stuff. Can you rule out a faulty screen? EIther by plugging in another screen if you have an extra one, or if you have some other device that uses a similar screen, maybe verify the screen works with that other device. Is the pinout of your screen the same as the pinout of the header on the board? After that, I'd probably look for any soldering issues - particularly around the MCU. When I built mine, I had a couple of solder bridges I needed to fix on the MCU. That seems like the most likely issues I can think of. If you're still not having any luck, you'll need to start troubleshooting the circuit - checking things like you have 5V to the MCU, 5V to the screen. If you have appropriate tools, see if you have any signal on the SCL and SDA lines to the screen, etc.

Author: brettski74
Content: Sure - I expect the problem is with your reflow hotplate board, too. I don't know whether anyone here is an AVR or UPDI programming guru. A few things I can say for sure:

Author: brettski74
Content: Despite the flaws in the v3.0 design, people - myself included - have built one and had it work.

Author: brettski74
Content: There were some typos and other errors in the instructions I had in my repo. I've updated to address those, but that's mostly to try to cut down on questions. This isn't a great design and my focus is elsewhere.

Author: brettski74
Content: More than likely you have some issue on your board. If it was me and I was keen on getting it working for the learning experience or whatever, I'd be doing the same stuff I suggested to @ngeran , above. Check supply voltages and ground connections are good. Check for signals in appropriate places - in this case the UPDI pin - and checking for soldering issues like dry joints, bridges or anything else that looks suspect on your board.

Author: brettski74
Content: When I built my board, this was the first serious SMD board I'd ever built and despite using a stencil and a hotplate to reflow the board - a fairly reliable process - I sucked at it and I ended up with solder bridges and had to mess around with it for a day or two with flux and desoldering braid and a soldering iron trying to figure out how to remove those bridges. In the end, I learned a few things. Maybe you're not looking for that. There are better designs out there if you want to build your own. There are also commercial units out there and if you're looking for turnkey solutions and aren't constrained on cost, that may be a better route for you.

Author: brettski74
Content: I'm happy to provide what help I can, but my guess is that you likely have some problem on your hotplate board. How did you build it? Did you hand solder it? Reflow it in an oven or on a hotplate or with hot air?

Author: brettski74
Content: Maybe share some photos showing how you have it hooked up to be programmed then we can confirm that the connections look correct.

Author: brettski74
Content: If that checks out, maybe some hires photos of the board - particularly around the MCU where I think you're most likely to run into problems - and we can see if there looks like any issues there.

Content: Are the buttons in the right way?

Author: brettski74
Content: Of the six pins in those buttons, 4 of them are connected to one side of the switch, and the other two to the other side. The two pins closest to the MCU are supposed to be the two pin group. If you put them in the wrong way, then it's basically the same as if you're holding down the buttons all the time instead of pressing and releasing them and hence, they won't work.

Author: brettski74
Content: I've been playing around with some simulations for the last few days. That hot input capacitor problem has been bugging me and I have finally realized why it happens. The circuit design is totally wrong. He's employed a PWM design that works perfectly fine for low power devices like LEDs, but for high power devices like a 60W heating element, it's entirely impractical.

Author: brettski74
Content: I was also looking at whether there's any way to retrofit something to fix the problem - such as maybe putting an inductor in series at the input, but that doesn't work either because again - circuit is all wrong. What should be happening is something more like this:

Author: brettski74
Content: There really is no way to prevent large ripple currents in the capacitors unless you have an inductor to smooth out the current, but that inductor must also be able to discharge into the heating element when the MOSFET is off - like a buck converter does. With the MOSFET situated like it is in the AfterEarthLtd design, even if you connect the power supply through a series inductor, there's nowhere for it to discharge when the MOSFET goes off except into the capacitor, so based on the simulations, adding a series inductor with the current design makes the power dissipation in that input capacitor worse, not better.

Author: brettski74
Content: Making the input capacitor bigger doesn't make much difference. Ripple currents into the input cap remain about the same.

Author: brettski74
Content: Looks like the DerSpatz designs have copied this fault as well. The bigger input caps may help ever so slightly, but only because they're bigger and able to dissipate more power. My guess is that they still get pretty hot.

Author: brettski74
Content: I'm curious if anyone has built the DerSpatz design and can comment on how hot the input caps get.

Author: brettski74
Content: Full schematic for my simulation circuit - in case the above snippet is a little confusing.

Content: Not odd. I lowered the PWM frequency to the default value of 490Hz, so the caps don't get hot. Technically, the vonryan fork lowered the frequency in the V3.0 firmware. I lowered it in the v2.4 firmware in my repo.

Author: brettski74
Content: Basically, because there's nothing to smooth out the current, the ripple current into and out of the input caps is rather large with every cycle. The higher the frequency, the more often this happens per second, leading to higher power dissipation in the caps. Something like a buck converter solves this by using an inductor to smooth out the current, which reduces the ripple current into and out of the cap, lowering power dissipation in the cap.

Author: brettski74
Content: My guess is that the inductor is vibrating because we're essentially switching the load on and off almost 500 times per second. We've basically punted the current smoothing problem back to the power supply, but it's not really designed to operate at such low frequencies.

Author: brettski74
Content:
If you want to see the input caps get hot on a v3 board, add the following line in setup():

`  TCA0.SPLIT.CTRLA = TCA_SPLIT_ENABLE_bm;`

Author: brettski74
Content: That's what I did to replicate the problem on my v3.0 board.

Author: brettski74
Content: Gives you around 63kHz instead of 490Hz. That's about as high as you can go without sacrificing PWM resolution.

Author: brettski74
Content: I don't recall my MOSFET getting particularly hot. Which MOSFET did you use? Did you use the one from the LCSC BOM - UMW30N06 - or the one from my digikey BOM - MCU80N03?

Author: brettski74
Content: The digikey part I spec'd has a much lower on resistance, so maybe that made enough of a difference. Looks like maybe 1W in the LCSC part versus about 0.2W for the digikey part. You could always up-spec the LCSC part. There are beefier MOSFETs available at LCSC, too. You'd just need to select one in a DPAK package that can operate with logic-level gate drive - something like CMD05N03A.

Author: brettski74
Content: 1W in a DPAK package will give you around 65 celsius of temperature rise, so that's pretty warm. That's not accounting for switch losses which could increase that by a bit - especially if the gate drive is weak - which it is. The gate will switch slower meaning higher losses during the switching. A larger drain pad would improve this, but there's not really the space to do so on the board and you're probably getting some heat from the hotplate fed back up the track as well.

Author: brettski74
Content: MOSFETs are cheap. Easier to just use a higher spec part.

Author: kanken6174

Author: brettski74
Content: I'm sorry to tell you, but that one is worse in almost every respect. 40 milliohms is the drain-source resistance when the device is "on". We want that to be lower, not higher. Also, the thermal resistance from the junction to the case is higher, meaning that in addition to dissipating more power at the same current levels, it also be slightly slower at getting that heat out, meaning higher temperatures. Gate charge is higher, too, so it will switch slower and lead to higher switching losses. All of that means hotter.

Author: elitesennabubble
Content: yeah if your rdson is high more power is dissipated by the transistor and it gets hot

Author: brettski74
Content: The most important parameter is the Rds(on) value. You want that to be as low as possible. The other parameters will make some difference, but Rds(on) should be the most impactful.

Author: kanken6174
Content: hence the 'but' i'm aware that a higher gate-on res is worse üôÇ

Author: kanken6174
Content: but yeah the other parameters described in the datasheet aren't great

Author: brettski74
Content: I have the same board with my digikey part. It doesn't get that hot. Basic thermal calculations tell us that with the UMW30N06 we should expect about 0.725W of power dissipation at 5A. Junction to case thermal resistance is 2.7 celsius per watt. Case to ambient thermal resistance of a DPAK package is about 62.5 celsius per watt. We have minimal pad size, so it's unlikely to help things at all. So we should expect about 47 celsius of temperature rise just from DC resistive losses alone. This has not yet accounted for resistive losses.

Author: brettski74
Content: You will get some heat leaked back up the track from the heating element, but I have the same board with an MCU80N03 on it, and I've never reflowed the MOSFET.

Author: brettski74
Content: Remember that 175 celsius is the maximum rated temperature for the *junction*. The case will be cooler than this, so if the case gets hot enough to reflow your solder, the junction inside is even hotter than this. At SnPb reflow temperatures, you're definitely over the rated operating temperature. For SnBi, maybe you're over, maybe you're not. It's also worth noting that the operating parameters of the MOSFET tend to get worse as it gets hotter. For example, Rds(on) goes up with temperature.

Author: brettski74
Content: For a matter of about 3 more cents, a MOSFET with about 20% of the on-resistance seems like a good move to me.

Author: brettski74
Content: I just ran a heating cycle to "180" celsius on my V3.0 board. My MOSFET did not get very hot. I could put my finger on it at any time during the heating cycle. It felt slightly warm at best.

Author: brettski74
Content: Here's a thermal image. The thing obscuring the upper left corner of the hotplate is my finger touching the MOSFET.

Author: brettski74
Content: That's the difference between Rds(on) of about 5-6milliohms versus about 30 milliohms.

Author: brettski74
Content: It also shows that while a little heat is leaking back up the tracks from the hotplate, it's not that much. Chris did do a reasonably good job of thermally isolating the hotplate from the control circuitry.

Author: brettski74
Content: What specs were you looking for when you picked those parts? Both of them have roughly the same Rds(on) as the original part.

Author: brettski74
Content: I updated the firmware in my repo to use a FAST_PWM macro definition to control whether to use high frequency PWM or not. I've tested it on the 4809 hardware that I have, but I don't have a v2.4 board. I think the changes should work, but if someone has a v2.4 board and could test that it works correctly, that would be great. WIth the code as-is, it should operate at 490Hz which should not result in a hot input capacitor but will likely make some audible sound when heating. If you uncomment the #define FAST_PWM line, it should use 63kHz as the PWM frequency. The main differences are that it shouldn't make an audible sound while heating, but the input capacitor will get very hot within a few seconds of the heating cycle starting. I wouldn't let it complete the cycle. Once I feel that cap get too hot to be touching, I generally cut the power.

Author: bwack77
Content: Conclusion to the video is that derspatz' v.1.1 has way too low  heater bed resistance. The psu is overloaded, only thanks to my lab psu i could continue at 5A in constant current mode, but then only at .. 7-10V from cold to solder hot. Therefor the bed heated too slowly and i got timeouts in the firmware.

Author: brettski74
Content: Yeah - that's something I wrote about on here fairly recently. It was something that people building the v3.0 boards had accidentally avoided, but once I became aware that this was a common problem with the v2.4 boards and I started looking into it, the cause became fairly obvious and it was about that point where I realized that Spatz's solution to this (ie. much more input capacitance) wasn't going to work, but I didn't have a DerSpatz board to test this. It's good to have some confirmation of this.

Author: brettski74
Content: That's exactly what I do. I don't use a purpose designed control board any more. I power my board directly from my lab power supply under USB control. The newer Spatz design is also supposed to use hotplate resistance calculations to determine hotplate temperature. We talked about that several months ago.

Author: brettski74
Content: There are pros and cons. Using hotplate resistance does give a more accurate reflection of the temperature of the hotplate - or at least something of an average across the entire hotplate - but it also requires calibration which I'm not yet sure how acceptable of a trade-off that will be for some users.

Author: brettski74
Content: For the most part, the average hobbyist just needs something that gets hot enough to melt the solder and form good solder joints across the board.

Author: bwack77
Content: Oh. Do you just measure temps manually and shut it off when solder has melted?

Author: brettski74
Content: No. As I said, I measure the resistance of the heating element and calculate the resistance from that.

Author: brettski74
Content: I have scripts that will follow a reflow profile that I can customize. In theory, I could follow an industry standard profile, but from experience, I know that I don't need to follow it precisely to get good results. The reflow profile I use these days has a lower peak temperature than the normal SnPb reflow profile that manufacturers like ChipQuik recommend. They typically have a reflow profile like this - https://www.chipquik.com/datasheets/SMD291AX.pdf - with a peak temperature as high as 235 celsius, but in practice, the solder is usually completely melted before we reach 200 celsius, so I don't see the point of going beyond 200 celsius and I think that's likely to be better for the life of the hotplate.

Author: brettski74
Content: The biggest challenge with using my power supply as part of the control system is the speed of the USB interface. PID control isn't feasible, so my scripts also have estimates of the thermal resistance to ambient of the hotplate and it's thermal capacity. So using that, plus the reflow profile, we know what temperature it is now and what temperature we want it to be by the next sample, so we can calculate how much power should be required to produce that much temperature rise in that much time. It works well enough and tracks with the expected temperature quite well.

Author: bwack77
Content: Not sure what you mean about USB control. The calc sounds interesting, but also daunting. Ok so find thermal R to ambient, thermal mass, then by looking at the current temperature apply an amount of energy (effect plus time) based on a calculation. Then after a while you measure again and repeat?

Author: brettski74
Content: USB control means exactly that. My lab power supply has a USB interface that allows it to be controlled via Modbus protocol. I can read the current state of the output and send commands to change the current settings. Since I can read the output voltage and current, I can estimate the resistance of the hotplate and then I can alter the current and/or voltage settings to send a certain amount of power into the hotplate. Round trip times are around 1.3 seconds, so I typically have my scripts set to sample and update every 1.5 seconds. I typically set the output voltage relatively high - around 20V and use the current limit to control how much power I'm sending into the hotplate, so it's never actually outputting 20V and is generally always operating in constant current mode based on whatever the last update was. I also have minimum current limits in the scripts so that I always have some current going into the hotplate, otherwise I can't calculate resistance and therefore can't calculate current temperature.

Author: brettski74
Content: For calibration, I wrote some code. I can estimate the resistance of the leads by shorting the heating element and sending some known test currents through it. I then remove the short and apply a constant power output to the hotplate until the temperature plateaus. That plateau temperature gives me an estimate of the thermal resistance to ambient. Once I have that, I can look at the slope of the temperature curve to estimate the thermal capacity of the hotplate assembly.

Author: bwack77
Content: Thanks a lot for the write up. Will read more after work.

Author: brettski74
Content: In theory, the calibration cycle should also be able to estimate the resistance of the hotplate, but that has always given me results that are about 15% higher than my bench meter which does a pretty accurate 4-wire resistance measurement and the bench meter results tend to work better for getting accurate temperatures. I'm not quite sure why that is, yet. Then again, I did notice that the temperatures being displayed in my output are low on some recent reflow cycles (ie. the hotplate was much hotter than the calculated temperature suggested) so maybe I have it backwards. Something I'll need to look into.

Author: brettski74
Content: I think my impression of the resistance measurement from the bench meter working better mostly comes from relatively low temperature readings. Using the resistance from the bench meter typically gives better results at the beginning of the cycle during preheat when temperatures are still relatively low, but I suspect that during the reflow stages of the cycle,  the hotplate is hotter than the calculations suggest. One issue is that you need to account for the resistance of the leads. That can be enough to throw the temperature calculation off by a fairly large margin, but maybe the lead resistance is inaccurate, or maybe the leads are warming up enough that it's throwing off the calculations. Ideally, it would be better if my power supply had remote sensing and then I could ignore the leads, but unfortunately it doesn't and can only tell me the temperature at the output of the power supply PCB.

Content: hi and thanks for the video!!

Author: brettski74
Content: 12v 10A power brick should probably be fine. I don't expect disaster, but bear in mind that this is not a guarantee of anything.

Author: brettski74
Content: You don't necessarily need something this powerful. With a higher resistance heating element, the current requirements will be lower, so you could use one of the lower power options they have with an appropriately designed hotplate.

Author: brettski74
Content: Also bear in mind that this is a partial DIY setup. You still need to provide it with a DC input from somewhere and you need to put it in a case yourself. They do sell cases that fit it if you don't have or want some other option.

Author: brettski74
Content: The AC-DC conversion you need to figure out, but there are various power supply modules that you can buy online, including on AliExpress, Amazon, BangGood, etc. I would recommend trying to get something that does at least 36V for the most versatility, because the DPS modules are buck converters and will only step down the voltage. They also sell similar modules that are step-up/down - the DPH series - although they are generally less compact and don't support the higher currents that some of the DPS series can.

Author: brettski74
Content: There are other manufacturers selling somewhat similar looking modules. FNIRSI is one such brand that I've also tried. I wouldn't recommend them. The RD Tech modules tend to be pretty accurate and reliable. I have several DPS and one DPH module and they've generally been quite good for several years now. The FNIRSI module I bought has been a little flakey and isn't very accurate. As far as I'm aware, the RD Official Store on AliExpress is the actual manufacturer of these. There are a lot of other sellers on AliExpress that resell their stuff, but I would suggest buying directly from their official store.

Author: brettski74
Content: If you have one lying around, an old laptop power supply is also not a bad option for powering one of these DPS modules. They usually run at 19V and provided it's a reasonable sized one like 90W or more, can probably provide 4.75A or more at 19V. Probably not great for a DPS-5020, but something like a DPS-3005 would be a good match for such a supply.

Author: brettski74
Content: 3D printers generally use a thermistor, which is fine, but getting good thermal contact with a meaningful portion of the hotplate is the challenge. You're better off using the heating element itself as the temperature sensor. That way you know you're measuring temperature across the heated region of the board. The caveat is that you need to calibrate your heating element to use it as a temperature sensor, but that's easy enough to do.

Author: brettski74
Content: I've used these before: https://www.digikey.ca/en/products/detail/eaton-electronics-division/NRBG504F3950B1F/15927320 pretty easy to use. You just set up a voltage divider across a known reference voltage with the thermistor on one side and then read the voltage with an ADC. The datasheet contain tabulated data for temperatures from -40 to 300 celsius, although for most purposes, you can use a two-point linear approximation unless you need stupid levels of accuracy/linearity. The challenge as always is where to mount the sensor to get good thermal contact with a relevant part of the hotplate. I only used these as a calibration check for my resistance based temperature measurements. Ultimately, accurate temperature measurement in this context is poorly defined at best and not really necessary, anyway. You really only need a ballpark type approximation of temperature to get excellent results - at least from my experience so far.

Author: brettski74
Content: For an FR4 board, or pretty much any board with the heating element on top, solder mask is absolutely needed. Without solder mask, you risk your board shorting traces during reflow, creating hotspots, overheating or other issues. You run the risk of passing current from the heating element through the board and components being reflowed, risking damage to them. You will also experience corrosion of the copper, which will slowly reduce the performance of your hotplate. Copper oxidation in air is fairly slow at room temperature, but elevated temperatures will accelerate that process. If you use HASL finish on your board or have pads with vias, you also run the risk of your reflow become solder-welded to the heating element. The solder mask provides an important barrier between the heating element and the board being reflowed. You absolutely want it there.

Author: brettski74
Content: I guess HASL finish can stop the corrosion and if you put your heating element on the bottom of the board, but I don't think that's a good option for FR4.

Content: Precision does suffer a little at low current levels, but to work around that, I have limits on the output current so that it won't drop below 3A during heating, even if the control calculations suggest that it should. Better to have a small amount of overshoot than to drop the current right back, get an imprecise current reading and have that throw things all over the place.

Author: brettski74
Content: 120W is more than enough to get a roughly 100x100 hotplate to reflow at a fairly quick rate. Here's another graph of reflow output versus temperature. The Power line is a moving average over a 6 sample window to give you a more realistic idea of how much power is being used at any point in the cycle. The only time we need 100W or more is in that pretty rapid pre-heat stage at the beginning. The calibration cycle estimated the thermal resistance of the hotplate to ambient air at around 2.4 K/W. So, 120W without any kind of control applied should be able to comfortably get a hotplate of around that size to over 300 celsius - more than enough to properly melt nylon. I've 3D printed nylon (line trimmer line) at 260 celsius.

Author: finn2708
Content: What resistance do you aim for in your plates? I would like to use a 24V supply to not have super high currents. I went for 6 Ohms to get roughly 4A / 100W

Author: brettski74
Content: I think I wrote a fairly long spiel on my thought process for an ideal hotplate a while back. I feel like rather than putting that in here again, maybe I'll write something up in markdown and commit it to my repo, so at least I can refer people to that. Stuff in here tends to get lost in history.

Author: brettski74
Content: But basically, you're looking for power per unit area. My next iteration, I want to aim for something that someone could power using something like a 90W laptop power supply or USB PD or something of that nature. Those all run at around 90-100W and 19-20V.

Author: brettski74
Content: 90W is a good amount of power for a roughly 100x100mm hotplate.

Author: brettski74
Content: So... 90W from 19V means about a 4 ohm hotplate element.

Author: brettski74
Content: You also need to remember that your hotplate resistance will be about 50% higher at reflow temperatures, and it's probably most important to ensure that you can maintain the power you need at the top end of your temperature range, so 4 ohms will be the resistance when "hot". Your resistance at room temperature will be about 2/3 of that, or around 2.7 ohms.

Author: brettski74
Content: If you're planning to run from a 24V power supply, then you can probably use a slightly higher resistance. You can probably nudge that target power level up a bit to git yourself some headroom. 90W should work ok, but I'm using that as a limit because it's a common power output capability of a lot of laptop power supply bricks, so it seemed like getting something at that power level would be useful for more people.

Author: brettski74
Content: So if you instead aim for 120W from 24V, then you'll and up with 24 x 24 / 120 = 4.8 ohms as your "hot" resistance and your room temperature resistance would be around 3.2 ohms.

Author: brettski74
Content: If you were aiming for 100W, then you're aiming for about 5.8 ohms hot and about 3.8 ohms at room temperature.

Author: brettski74
Content: Ovens typically work via convection or at higher temperatures, radiation. When the PCB being reflowed is in contact with one of your heating elements, the primary heat transfer process in play is conduction, so it seems more like a covered hotplate than an oven to me. I think that 90% or more of the heat that gets into your PCB will come from the bottom hotplate that it's sitting on.

Author: brettski74
Content: If you scroll back through the history, you'll eventually come across some thermal images. At that point, you'll realize that "accuracy" isn't really a thing with these devices. Besides, you don't need that kind of accuracy. You need it to get hot enough to melt the solder and form good joints. Ideally, you also don't want to get so hot that you fry the components or burn down the neighbourhood or whatever, but that part is easy. There's a very wide margin between "hot enough to melt solder" and "bad things" so it's very easy to hit requirement 1 while still avoiding bad things. If you're +/- 5 celsius, who cares?

Author: brettski74
Content: If you spend enough time trying to get "accurate" temperatures, you'll also start to realize that the number you get matters a lot about where you took your measurement. And that's not just about where within the area of the hotplate, but also, are you measuring on the top of the hotplate, on the underside, on the top of the board being reflowed. Next to that large inductor that's sucking up all the heat or on the other side of the board near a few 0603 caps and resistors.

Author: mike_3834
Content: so i bought these thermistors since they are rated for 300C and today they arrived, so i'm gonna try hooking one up to see how well it works, i assume best placement will be on the bottom middle of the pcb, i just hope the fr4 material won't hinder the heat transfer too much

Author: brettski74
Content: The underside of the board is, in my opinion, the best place to mount any kind of commercially calibrated temperature sensor. Heat transfer to the underside of the board is good and relatively quick, Make sure you have good thermal contact with the hotplate when you mount it and you should have good heat transfer into the sensor. Also keep in mind that the temperature that we really care about the most is the temperature on top of the board being reflowed. That also has one thickness of an FR4 board between it and the hotplate and probably has much lighter contact with the hotplate than your sensor will have, so...

Author: brettski74
Content: I'm not convinced that the centre of the board is the best place for this sensor. My thinking is that somewhere closer to the edge, although not right on the edge is better. Your temperature will be highest in the centre of your hotplate unless you have made design modifications to address this. With that in mind, you want to make sure that the entire board being reflowed reaches reflow temperatures for at least a few seconds to ensure good solder joints are formed. You're unlikely to damage anything if you hit 250 celsius, but if you only hit 175 celsius (assuming SnPb solder), then you have a problem because those areas won't reflow. Therefore, you want to be measuring temperatures on the lower end of what your hotplate is doing and aiming for around 20-30 celsius above the melting/liquidus temperature of your solder alloy to ensure good repeatable results. I would suggest mounting the sensor in a corner, around 10-15 mm in from the edge of the heating element. If you're hitting good reflow temperatures there, you should be pretty good across the entire hotplate.

Author: brettski74
Content: I did do some refactoring of the code last night to allow for more flexibility in thermal sensor setup and to make it relatively simple to configure a different sensor. Thermistors are great, but there's so much variability in the specs of the particular thermistor that you might pick up and also in how you set it up on the board. The code isn't really well tested. I have tested it with an LMT85 and that seems to be giving accurate numbers based on external measurements taken near the sensor, but I am getting anomalous thermistor results at the moment, which seems to be a hardware problem. The thermistors I have are 50k, but is mearuring closer to 2.5k in circuit at room temperature, so something's not right and I need to go over my connections some more to figure out why. Because it's not well tested, I don't really want to commit it to main, but I could commit it to a branch if you want to try it out.

Author: mike_3834
Content: I used 18b20 digital temp sensor but realized it would be useless because it can only handles temps around 130C max and i didn't want to use it in that more crude way where it sits next to the board and only measures ambient air, thus having massive offset from the real temperature. the thermistors are ntc 3950

Author: brettski74
Content: If you can get a proper datasheet for the actual thermistor, with tabulated resistance data over a large temperature range you'll get more accurate results. The published beta value is typically calculated using the Steinhart-Hart equation using the resistance at 25 and 50 celsius - typically. Sometimes you'll see B25/85 or B25/100 published instead, but B25/50 seems most common. The thing is, the further you get from those two temperatures, the less accurate you get. As an example, for an Eaton NRBG104?3950B1* thermistor, if you use the published B25/50 value of 3950K, then you'll be off by about 8 degrees by 200 celsius - ie. when your measurement tells you it's 200 celsius, it'll actually be closer to 192 celsius. If you have the full tabulated resistance data, you can calculate a more appropriate beta value to use. For example, B25/200 for the same thermistor is about 4079K. If you use that, your maximum calculation error over the range from 0 to 225 celsius is about 1.9 celsius, as opposed to about 12.4 celsius if you use the B25/50 value of 3950.

Author: brettski74
Content: And unfortunately, you can't assume that every 10k B=3950K thermistor will be the same. I looked at a few different manufacturers that publish resistance tables. For the same nominal resistance and B value, they're close within the 25-50 celsius range, but they can deviate a bit as you get further away.

Author: mike_3834
Content: Well i have one of those laser gun things that measure temperature so my plan is simply measure the temp with it to make my own small lookup table

Author: mike_3834
Content: And see how well it correlates to the official lookup tables

Author: brettski74
Content: There are caveats with all temperature measurement options. I use a thermal imager as well, but I don't know that I'd trust it to be that accurate. I wouldn't expect it to be more accurate than just using the published beta value. In my experience, thermography is good for getting a rough idea and for relative measurements within an image, but if I want accuracy, I use something in good thermal contact with the target. Precision is more important. If your sensor is precise, you can adjust for inaccuracy and a decent thermistor placed appropriately should give you good precision. From there you can adjust your profiles to get good reflow results and then you're set.

Author: brettski74
Content:
The AfterEarthLtd designs (also referred to as v2.4 and v3.0) don't use PID control. They have a very simple control scheme which basically just applies power until the temperature sensor reports a given temperature, then it stops. I think the firmware for the DerSpatz design may have PID control, but I haven't used it. Someone posted a graph not too long ago that was from a DerSpatz design which nicely followed a reflow profile and was said to be using PID control. Not sure how he produced that graph.
I have posted several graphs. That was from my own software that controls a bare hotplate PCB from a DPS-5020 power supply using Modbus control over USB. I have perl scripts that handle the Modbus comms to sense voltage & current, calculate temperature and then update the power supply output to follow the reflow profile. Those scripts spit out CSV data which I then pull into LibreOffice Calc to produce those graphs.

D2 is Zenner Diode or Normal rectifier/schottky diode? 
Because in boom file  D2 is MM1Z24 = 24v Zenner diode

Author: brettski74
Content: Take a look at the schematic. It's a 24V zener. I seem to recall Chris writing somewhere that he was seeing  voltage spikes when the MOSFET switched off due to the parasitic inductance of the heating element. He added a zener to clamp those to a safe voltage. Whether that's the best solution... not sure. A schottky diode placed in the same orientation to let the current free-wheel might be better, but I doubt we have very much inductance there, so I don't know how much energy there is to dissipate and how much difference that would make.

Author: brettski74
Content: Actually, looking at it, I'm thinking that the zener is wrong. It's probably just acting as a slow freewheel diode and it's breakdown voltage is irrelevant.

Author: brettski74
Content: So a schottky probably is better. Feel free to try it out and let us know what you find.

Author: brettski74
Content: If you were to use a silicon diode, it should probably be a fast recovery part, not a general purpose rectifier or zener but it seems that the zener is doing the job well enough to protect the other components.

Author: brettski74
Content: If you don't want to have to change the layout, something like an SS1040... part should work. It's a 40V 1A schottky diode. There are several variants, though. Digikey and Mouser only carry the Panjit parts, which should all work - they're all SOD123 or SOD123FL, which are compatible enough.

Author: brettski74
Content: Solder mask is probably the most important element in the assembly and the first significant element to fail. Silkscreen also breaks down at lower temperatures, but doesn't really impact anything if/when it does. If solder mask disappears, that can cause problems. That said, PCBWay's standard materials seem to be good enough for SnPb reflow temperatures. If you want to do SAC, then you're kinda on the cusp. JLCPCB's standard materials are less heat resistant. I wouldn't recommend anything higher than SnBi on a JLCPCB manufactured hotplate using their standard process. Something more heat resistant may be better. I haven't done any flex work, so I don't know what the standard materials are like under reflow cycling. If you try it, let us know which manufacturer and options you used and how it works out.

Author: brettski74
Content: You have a couple of options with NTC thermistors, each with varying degrees of accuracy. The absolute best accuracy will come from using tabulated temperature versus resistance data from the datasheet, although not all thermistors have that - especially if you don't know the part number or have the datasheet. Next best option is to take the known resistance at two temperatures - preferably near the upper and lower ends of the temperature range you care about most - and use that to calculate a beta value and then use the Steinhart-Hart equation to calculate temperature from the resistance. If you don't have tabulated data, you can use the published beta value, although this is often calculated between 25 and 50 celsius, so the error could be as much as +/-10 celsius by the time you get to 200 celsius.

Author: brettski74
Content: If you don't have a datasheet but you have some reasonably accurate way to measure temperature, you could do that second option. For best accuracy, I'd suggest giving the sensors plenty of time to soak and reach a stable value before recording any measurements. One temperature should be room temperature, since it's pretty easy to get that measured from a steady state. For the upper temperature, maybe you can use a hot air stations to set a constant temperature. That'll be a lot faster to get to steady state. Alternatively, maybe tape the two sensors down to a hotplate and run it at a constant power until you see steady state - something like no increase in 60 seconds is probably close enough to steady state to take a measurement. Now you have your two points, you can use Steinhart-Hart equation to calculate a beta value and you're good to go.

Author: brettski74
Content: Beta calculator if you don't want to do the calculation yourself: http://www.learningaboutelectronics.com/Articles/NTC-thermistor-beta-calculator.php

Author: brettski74
Content: I'm not going to claim to be an expert, but as far as I'm aware, programming a 328p is typically done via serial upload to the USART using a standard in-system programmer (ISP). Take a look at the programming instructions and the board layout for the v2.4 board. Beyond that, there should be plenty of stuff online if you google a bit.

Author: brettski74
Content: You don't need to cool down fast. What's important is that you don't heat or cool too quickly so that you don't thermally stress components and damage them. If you take a brittle component and make one part of it significantly hotter than another, the expansion/contraction may crack the part. Cooling down more slowly than specified is generally fine. I'm also curious about the flat section in the middle. That would be your soak stage. You generally want soak to end just around the melting point of your solder alloy and you want it to be long enough to get everything - board, components, flux and solder - to be right around the melting point so that when you ramp up the temp in the reflow stage, everything is on the verge of reflowing and forms good solder joints. I'm assuming this is for SnPb solder. I would suggest your soak stage should ramp up slowly to about 180 celsius over a period of about 120 seconds. If you don't soak long enough, you may have unreliable results around larger components that take longer to heat up.

Author: bwack77
Content: The second graph sheet, is where I had the PID controller feed by the IR Temp. It actually shows before and after burning the fuse bits. That is why the first graph is showing that the profile is too short/quick. The second graph, the orange line, is following the target quite nicely, though I'd wish it would come up to the soldering temperature (highest temp) a bit quicker, but for that I guess I'd hae to get a stronger power supply than 12V 5A. Or maybe it is just a matter of adjusting the integral constant. I'll have a try soon. Also I removed bits form the code that seemed to wait for the temp to get within a threshold before going to the next step in the profile. If the PID is well tuned, it shouldn't be needed. Also, in each next step, the start temp was set to current temp, I don't know that it was there, but I changed the code for the target temperature (cuirrent set value) to follow the profile instead of relying on values from current temp. (start temp is a figure in the code that is used to calculate the slope of profile). Seems to work well with the IR sensor.

Author: brettski74
Content: I wrote up a bunch of stuff about hotplate design based on the data I've collected through my own prototyping at https://github.com/brettski74/Solder-Reflow-Plate/tree/main/Board%20Versions. As a general rule of thumb, I would suggest you want around 1.2-1.5W per square centimetre of hotplate area in order to have plenty of power available to stay with the more aggressive stages of a reflow profile. The AfterEarthDesigns boards have a hotplate area of about 35 square centimetres, so for something that size, you want to be able to pump somewhere around 45-50W into the board to be confident of staying with your reflow profile. If your heating element is larger than that, then scale those numbers up to about 1.2-1.5W per square centimetre. Whether 12V 5A is enough to do that will depend on your heating element resistance and your maximum duty cycle that you allow in the firmware. If you're already able to pump that much power into your heating element, then it may well be software or PID tuning hold you back, as you alluded to.

Author: brettski74
Content: How did you tune your PID? Was it just manual, trial and error tuning? Or have you implemented Ziegler-Nichols or some other autotuning algorithm? If you don't have autotuning, I'm pretty sure someone implemented their own design with Ziegler-Nichols autotuning included in their code.

Author: brettski74
Content: My personal opinion is that the best sensor is the heating element itself, but you do need to calibrate it. That gives you a value that's representative of the entire area of the hotplate. I also like the fact that it requires no additional equipment attached to the hotplate, so that keeps it very clean which is operationally good, but also makes it more of a consumable item should you wear out a hotplate. You have no components to remount on the new replacement hotplate. You just hook it up, calibrate and off you go.

Author: brettski74
Content: Aside from that, I'd say I like NTC thermistors. They're easy to use. They respond to change pretty quickly and are pretty cheap. I would recommend mounting on the underside of the hotplate, closer to the outside, about 1/4 of the way in from the edge to the centre.

Maybe something @bwack could play with and let us know? What happens if the IR sensor is pointed at a shiny piece of aluminium or stainless steel? Does it still sense accurate temperatures?

Author: bjkayani
Content: What do you all think about adding a temperature offset to compensate for the temperature delta of the measurement location and the location we can more about?

Author: bjkayani
Content: Like if I run some tests and determine that the temperature on the top surface is always 15 degrees lower than the location (botton of the panel) where I am measuring, I just compensate for it in software?

Author: brettski74
Content: It's never that simple. Reflow is a pretty dynamic process. That delta will change over time. It will change at different temperatures. It will change depending on the load you're placing on your hotplate. A small board with a few small components will be affected differently than a larger board with large filter caps and inductors and other large components that need a lot more energy to warm up.

Author: brettski74
Content: Better to have a reflow profile that works reliably based on real temperatures you can actually measure. At least that way you won't confuse yourself or anyone else who builds your design as to what the numbers actually mean.

Author: brettski74
Content: I suspect that may have been what Chris did with his design, because the formula for the temperature in the code doesn't seem to correspond remotely to the information on the datasheet for the LMT85.

Author: brettski74
Content: So if  you have a profile that goes to 100 for preheat, 180 for soak, 210 for reflow and whatever and it seems like it's not getting quite hot enough on top of the board, adjust the profile temps up to compensate. So you set up your profile to maybe preheat to 110, soak to 190 and reflow up to 225 or something. I think that's going to be less confusing. The other thing you can tweak is the duration of the different profile stages. I actually prefer to make the reflow temperature a little lower - around 205, but I make it a little longer just to be sure there's enough time for larger components to form good joints. That said, I generally do a long soak - around 120 seconds. By that time, most components are almost at temperature to reflow, so the solder typically reflows before we get to peak temperature, anyway - even around the larger inductors and such that tend to be a little slower to reflow.

Author: bjkayani
Content: That makes sense and I was thinking that as well. The design that I am working on has the ability to modify the profile on board and have as many profiles as needed. So that should allow to set the off set as needed.

Author: bjkayani

Author: bjkayani

Author: brettski74
Content: People have tried both. The IR sensor seems like a nice idea. I'm less convinced of a conductive sensor that you can place on top of the board. It means that you have to have a suitable location to attach it to your board being reflowed, which won't always be possible. I think you're better to keep the design independent of any particular attributes of the board being reflowed.

Author: brettski74
Content: Having done a lot of temperature measurement on reflow hotplates with a number of different sensors, it's quite common to get different temperatures in different locations. You would want to rule that out before writing off your IR sensor data. It may actually be getting it's information from somewhere that is cooler.

Author: brettski74
Content: The other thing I would note is that while there seems to be a proportionality factor in play, the shape seems to track pretty well. So long as you can get precise data from it, you can make that work. Accuracy is less important than precision.

Author: brettski74
Content: I primarily use my heating element as the sensor, so no mounting necessary. I wouldn't recommend using a thermocouple. They're more complicated to use than a thermistor. I would only use them for higher temperatures where NTC thermistors are no longer practical or possible to use. That's where I see their strength.

Author: brettski74
Content: I haven't used an IR sensor, but I do have some experience with thermal imaging which I believe relies on similar physics. It's a known issue that shiny metal surfaces do not give good temperature readings on a thermal imager and that the emissivity of the surface you're imaging will affect the results. Thermal imagers allow you to set the emissivity to use in calculating temperatures on the device. I'm expecting similar issues with an IR temperature sensor, but I could be wrong. Which IR sensor are you using?

Author: bwack77

Author: brettski74
Content:
Emissivity is a thing. From the datasheet: As a standard, the MLX90614 is calibrated for an object emissivity of 1. It can be easily customized by the customer for
any other emissivity in the range 0.1‚Ä¶1.0 without the need of recalibration with a black body.

Author: brettski74
Content: That's pretty typical. Thermal imagers usually default to using an emissivity of one or close to it like 0.95 or something. This is reasonable for most objects, but is terrible for shiny metallic surfaces.

Author: brettski74
Content: It looks like a good sensor. You just want to make sure it's pointed at something darker and close to the surface of your board so you get good temperature readings from it.

Author: bwack77
Content: ok. When I think of it, the PCBs do have a lot of shiny surfaces thouhg  Thinking about the pads and solder points.. Not sure how that affects it.  One can also get IR sensors that focus on a small area. Maybe that is better.
