Author: brettski74
Content: I wouldn't worry too much about pads and solder joints. This can affect the reading for sure, but most of your pads will be covered and I think solder joints would be a smaller proportion of the image - maybe 30% or less. I'm pretty sure that emissivity affects the temperature reading in a nonlinear way, so unless the emissivity goes down by a pretty large margin, it'll still be close. From memory, I think changing the emissivity setting in my thermal imageer between 1.0 and 0.7 didn't change the temperature readings by that much, but I can't say I've played with or tested that extensively. I might be wrong. Do some testing with some different targets and see what the results look like. Use one or more other sensors as a point of comparison. I've used K-type thermocouples with my multimeter, kitchen thermometers and sensor rigs I've built with NTC thermistors. That was probably overkill, although it did give me an appreciation of how temperature can vary between locations. If you can show the results are reasonably consistent when a more trusted sensor is also consistent, you should be able to work with that. Like I said, precision is more important here than accuracy. It would be nice if the board was actually at 200 celsius when you sensor says it is, but so long as it's at roughly the same temperature any time it says 200 celsius, then you can make it work, even if that temperature happens to be 150 or 250 celsius or whatever.

Author: elitesennabubble
Content: have any of you guys messing with oled screens seen this before?

Author: brettski74
Content: What library are you using to drive it? If I recall correctly, the last time I saw something like that, I had neglected to clear the screen on startup, so I think the screen had random noise all over it. Some screens do not guarantee any specific state of the buffer memory on startup. The other thing I've seen with libraries like the Adafruit library is to look at what drawing mode you've configured. When drawing text, I think it defaults to only drawing the pixels that need to be turned on, assuming that you'll clear the space before writing, so you end up with an effect of text being drawn on top of the previous text rather than replacing it.

Author: brettski74
Content: A lot of libraries use double buffering as well, so you need to remember to tell it to display your updates after sending them to the screen. For example, the Adafruit library has a display() method that you need to call after calling methods like drawLine or print or whatever. The same applies after calling clearDisplay. clearDisplay will clear the display in the buffer, but it won't go to the screen until you call display().

Author: brettski74
Content: The main problem with both the AfterEarthLtd design and also the DerSpatz design is the power design. The way the MOSFET is placed and controlled works fine for something like a low power indicator LED, but when you're pushing around 10s of watts of power, it really needs to be more like a buck converter with an inductor, capacitor and either a freewheeling diode or a synchronous MOSFET design. At the moment, both designs cause large ripple currents in the capacitors due to nothing but parasitic inductance to smooth out the currents.

Author: brettski74
Content: So you want to run the device at high frequency to minimize impacts on the upstream supply, but when you do, the input caps gets really hot because of the huge ripple current in and out of the caps.

Author: brettski74
Content: That's probably the most important hardware improvement required.

Author: brettski74
Content: Software... the main thing I think we need to look at there is modularizing the design.

Author: brettski74
Content: And making it more configurable.

Author: brettski74
Content: There have been lots of different designs over the past couple of years with people choosing different sensors, different microcontrollers and different UI designs.

Author: brettski74
Content: I think we can separate out the various parts into separate heater control, UI and sensor modules.

Author: brettski74
Content: And use macro defs to make it easier to support different hardware.

Author: rubacava

Author: rubacava

Author: brettski74
Content: I wouldn't be too worried about it.

Author: brettski74
Content: 20 Hz is pretty low fequency.

Author: brettski74
Content: The default PWM frequency for Arduino code is about 490Hz.

Author: rubacava
Content: yeah frequency doesn't really matter for a resistive load

Author: brettski74
Content: But... when you say "5A current" and "20Hz pwm", does 5A refer to the peak current or the RMS current or the mean current?

Author: brettski74
Content: Purely resistive loads don't exist in the real world.

Author: brettski74
Content: But the heater inductance is pretty low.

Author: brettski74
Content: Not high enough to fulfill the filtering role required.

Author: rubacava
Content: I use pwm solely to limit current so duty cycle is dynamically adjusted based on MAX_POWER value and the reading from the battery voltage

Author: rubacava
Content: which corresponds to about 5A for 2S battery and 1Ohm load

Author: rubacava
Content: My software is pretty extensive but limited to stm32 HAL framework

Author: brettski74
Content: If you have a 2S lithium ion battery into a 1 ohm load, you're going to be pulling more than 5A peak.

Author: rubacava
Content: For 100% duty cycle yes

Author: brettski74
Content: But at 20Hz, you will actually draw 7-8A or so while your switch is on, depending on the SOC of the cells.

Author: brettski74
Content: Ideally, what we want to do is to smooth out our current draw on the upstream supply. If we're trying to draw about 35W from a 7V supply, ideally you'd want to make it look as much like a 5/7 ohm resistor as you can. Batteries may be more forgiving than other supplies, but if you don't have appropriate filtering built into your design, you're offloading all of that onto the upstream supply, which may not deal with it as well.

Author: rubacava
Content: My power supply also reports 5a as intended when replaced instead of battery so that means my actual output current is lower?

Author: brettski74
Content: Yes - but I doubt your power supply is reporting faster than 20 times per second, so it's showing you an average reading.

Author: rubacava
Content: I may not be noticing since the batteries can output 15A sustained and maybe it could be a problem with a weaker psu as i understood

Author: brettski74
Content: If it's working and you're happy with it, I'm not going to get overly critical, but generally speaking when designing the input for a device, you want to avoid pushing noise and other effects back to the upstream supply. You may cause problems for the supply or for other devices that may be sharing the supply.

Author: brettski74
Content: A well designed device should have appropriate input filtering and other design elements that smooth out the input power drawn as much as is practical. We generally do that using passive filtering components - capacitors and inductors. We generally like to use high frequencies for things like PWM because higher frequency means smaller filter components.

Author: brettski74
Content: For low power stuff, you can probably ignore, but these hotplates aren't really what I'd call low power devices.

Author: rubacava
Content: How about soft starting Does that help with the input current

Author: rubacava
Content: and a low frequency pwm

Author: brettski74
Content: What you really want is high frequency PWM with appropriate filtering built into the design. Soft-start is for solving a different problem.

Author: brettski74
Content: Soft-start designs usually use a MOSFET that operates as a resistor for a few milliseconds to limit inrush currents until the input caps are sufficiently charged up. The design specifically dissipates power in that MOSFET, but the design expects that this happens very infrequently so we can mostly ignore the power dissipation in the MOSFET as a result. If you suddenly expect that cap to do the same job 20 times per second instead of once every few minutes/hours/days/etc, those assumption may no longer be valid and your soft-start MOSFET may get warm/hot/desmokified.

Author: brettski74
Content: The DerSpatz design has a soft-start MOSFET included in it, doesn't it?

Author: brettski74
Content: It does, but the time constant of the gate circuit is designed to be pretty slow, so even at 20Hz, it's likely to stay fully on throughout the whole cycle unless the input voltage gets pulled really low.

Author: rubacava
Content: yeah a proper gate driver would be way to go

Author: brettski74
Content: A gate driver will help lower switching losses, but that doesn't address the ripple current problem. I posted some example circuits a while back: https://discord.com/channels/949124073164787732/949124076142751777/1079244021005824120

Author: brettski74
Content: What's missing is the RL filter as part of the heater control circuit.

Author: brettski74
Content: The AfterEarthLtd and DerSpatz designs both assume that the input caps will somehow do all the filtering, but they can't in part because we need inductance to do the job properly. But we can't easily retrofit a power inductor in there without redesigning the board.

Author: brettski74
Content: DerSpatz tried to fix the input filtering problem by making the input caps much larger, but we don't need huge capacitance. A modest sized power inductor fixes the problem properly and doesn't need much more capacitance than the original AfterEarthLtd design had so long as the inductor and capacitor are in the right place.

Author: brettski74
Content: The component values are all part of the design, which includes the firmware. What capacitance and inductance we need is dependent on how much power we're planning to drive through the heater and the PWM frquency that we use.

Author: brettski74
Content: I would probably put a 100uF input cap in front of that, possibly with a 100nF ceramic to help with higher frequency noise. Then you're RL filter for the power stage will probably be somewhere in the order of about 10-100uF and 10-40uH depending on what limits we want to set for the design.

Author: brettski74
Content: To do the design properly, we would want to look at what power supply we want to support - is it the same 12V supply that the existing designs used or do we want to using something higher voltage like a laptop power brick @ 19V or USB-C @ 20V.

Author: brettski74
Content: The calculations aren't difficult, but we do need to make a few choices around what power supply we use, how much power we want to push into the heater and how much voltage and current ripple will be acceptable. From there, you go shopping for parts and see how that looks. If you're happy with the design and the cost, happy days. If you can't find the parts you need at a cost you find reasonable, then you make some compromises...

Content: Looking at a 7805 in DPAK package, you have about 92 celsius per watt thermal resistance to ambient and a maximum operating temperature of 150 celsius. At an ambient temperature of 25 celsius, we can dissipate about 1.3W max without additional heat sinking.

Author: brettski74
Content: Alternatively, use a switching supply, but a linear supply would be nicer from a noise perspective.

Author: brettski74

Author: brettski74
Content: I guess it depends. I'm looking at it from the perspective of a power supply that someone might already have either for other purposes or just lying around in their junk box. If you're going to buy a brand new supply, a 12V 10A power brick can be bought on Amazon for about the same price or maybe a little less than a 130W laptop power brick.

Author: brettski74
Content: If you look at lab supplies, though, which is how I power mine... 3A and 5A lab power supplies are pretty common. So I was wanting to design something that wouldn't need more than 5A, so 20V gives me about 100W to work with, which is good for a modest size hotplate. 12V only gives 60W, which limits the hotplate size a bit if you want good performance.

Content: I found out why the capacitors are electrolytic instead of solid. Electrolytic capacitors have higher ripple current ratings at low frequencies

Content: What do you mean by "solid"? Aluminium-poly?

Author: honvl
Content: Ceramic or aluminum polymer

Author: brettski74
Content: Not sure where you're getting this higher ripple current rating idea from... For ripple current, the main factor that affects how much ripple current a cap can handle is the ESR, which will determine how much heat the cap has to dissipate due to ripple current and both Al-poly and ceramic generally have lower ESR than Al-electrolytic. Al-electrolytic caps are usually selected because they offer high capacitance and low cost.

Author: brettski74
Content: DerSpatz is designed to run at approximately 63kHz. I haven't seen analogWriteFrequency before. It's not mentioned in the Arduino reference. It seems to be a non-standard function defined in some other non-Arduino board definitions like MegaCoreX - https://github.com/MCUdude/MegaCoreX. The definition there says that the number is an approximate value in kilohertz. The 64 value will give you around 62.5kHz for the standard 16MHz clock speed.

Author: brettski74
Content: Regarding ripple currents, I don't know whether you can generalize that much. I did some quick searches on Digikey for a 680uF 35V capacitor in Al-elec and Al-poly and selected the cheapest in-stock part that specified an ESR.

Author: brettski74
Content: For Al-Poly, this was https://www.digikey.ca/en/products/detail/panasonic-electronic-components/EEH-ZS1V681UP/14324340 with an ESR of 11 milliohms, ripple current rating of 700mA at 120Hz and 3500mA at 100kHz and above. It also costs CAD$4.65 per piece for 1-9 pieces.

Author: brettski74
Content: For Al-elec, this was https://www.digikey.ca/en/products/detail/cornell-dubilier-illinois-capacitor/687RZM035M1320/5413317 with an ESR of 341 milliohms, ripple current rating of 913mA at 120Hz and 1100mA at 100kHz. It costs $1.72 per piece for 1-9 pieces.

Author: brettski74
Content: The Al-elec part is a little better at 120Hz but massively worse on ripple current at higher frequencies, which is exactly where Al-poly are supposed to shine. At 62.5kHz, the Al-poly part would handle the ripple currents much better, but it's around 3 times the price.

Author: brettski74
Content: The coefficients drop off at lower frequencies, but since Al-poly caps typically have much lower ESR to begin with, even with the low frequency correction factor, they still end up in a similar ballpark to Al-elec at the same size.

Author: brettski74
Content: You just don't buy them because they're expensive and don't provide any/enough benefit for the extra cost at low frequencies.

Author: brettski74
Content: If anyone wants to take a look, the repo is https://github.com/brettski74/Modular-Solder-Reflow. Bear in mind that I haven't built this yet. There is an LTSpice model and I do have part numbers for most of the important parts included in the KiCad design for both LCSC and Digikey. I was going to include Mouser part numbers as well but curiously, I had trouble finding suitable parts on Mouser. The one that comes to mind immediately is the barrel jack. Mouser has board mounted 5.5 x 2.5mm barrel jacks, but none rated higher than 5A, whereas LCSC and Digikey had 7A and 8A rated barrel jacks and I don't feel comfortable specifying a barrel jack for this kind of device that is only rated for 5A.

Author: brettski74
Content: I've ordered boards from JLCPCB. The gerber files I used are in the repo as well. I'm going to add more documentation about the design and how to use it over the next week or so.

Author: brettski74
Content: The other thing to bear in mind, this is not a complete solution. This is the power section only. To use this, you'll want to hook it up to some kind of MCU board like an Arduino, Xiao, Blue Pill, or whatever.

Author: brettski74
Content: What this design mainly addresses is proper buck-inspired design, manageable ripple currents and current sensing built in.

Author: brettski74
Content: If you do build it, I strongly recommend ordering a stencil with your boards. I've designed this to be reflowed. Minimum part size used is 0603. Also the kelvin connections on the current shunts aren't really practical to be hand soldered. I'll put more material together on how to get started if you don't already have a working reflow solution. Bootstrappability is a goal of the overall design.

Author: brettski74
Content: Feedback is welcomed. If you have any problem with the KiCad project or the LTSPice model, let me know. There were a few custom footprints I used, but I think I've got them all included as project local models, so they should be fine, but if  I've missed something, let me know. We are missing 3d models for the barrel jack and the two inductors. Models are available online, but I'm not sure of the licensing of those at the moment, so don't want to include them in the repo unless/until I'm sure that I'm allowed to do so. I might put a script in there to retrieve the models from their online source instead.

Author: brettski74
Content: I've added some more information on usage to github: https://github.com/brettski74/Modular-Solder-Reflow/tree/main/Hardware/PowerSection#how-to-use-this-module

Author: smint9414
Content:
Hi there! 

I'm designing my own hot plate and I had a few questions concerning the desired resistance of hot plate. My hot plate only has to heat up to like 50 degrees so I guess that the resistance isn't that important cause I can always just limit the power through software, but I tried to calculate it either way, I even made my own Kicad Plugin to Calculate it for me! And the results are very similar to your hot plate designs, my design has a trace width of 1 mm, a height of 35 ¬µm and a length of approx. 3 m, so this results in a hotplate resistance of approx. 1.5 Ohm. Which is a bit high for the power supply I am using right now ( 12 V, 5A max) but it'll still manage because of the relatively low temperatures. 

The thing that I don't understand is how it is possible for heatbed's of 3D printers to have a similar resistance?! Their traces are way way longer (the one used on the Prusa 3D printers is more than 30m!) while only a tiny bid wider, so the resistance should be way higher as well then right? Or am I missing something? 

Some advice on the matter would be greatly appreciated!

Author: brettski74
Content: I have a prusa hotplate here - not an authentic Prusa, but a chinese manufactured one using his design. The tracks appear to be about 3.8mm wide and the total resistance being 4.5ohms, with each of the two legs being about 2.25 ohms each. When you say 50 degrees, is that the temperature you want to reach, or is that the delta about ambient temperature (ie. you want to hit about 75 celsius, which is about 50 degrees above ambient)? I'm assuming 50 celsius is the absolute temperature you're aiming for.

Author: brettski74
Content: The temperature delta is not too big, so you can probably ignore resistance changes for the most part.

Author: brettski74
Content: The resistance is too low for that power supply. 1.5 ohms will draw 8A from a 12V supply, so you're power supply will likely do one or more of  limit the current - hence you don't get 12V any more - , shut down or release it's magic smoke. If it doesn't have current limiting, it may go into a cycle of shutting down and heating up repeatedly until the magic smoke is released.

Author: brettski74
Content: It's good practice to try to design these things to be fail-safe than to rely on software alone to prevent a catastrophe. If your heating element is capable of drawing 96W at 12V and your software or hardware has a bug or some manufacturing or assembly error or whatever, you may end up blowing up your power supply which is a more expensive mistake than you want it to be.

Author: brettski74
Content: A better approach would be to design it so that your heating element can't draw more power than it should, even if your control system completely fails. If that's not possible, then put other protection devices or circuits in place to prevent this.

Author: brettski74
Content: How big is your hotplate?

Author: brettski74
Content: 50 celsius is only about a 25-30 kelvin delta. For a hotplate that fits within the 100x100mm limit of the cheap PCB manufacturing options with about 7mm margin on all sides for mounting hardware would only need about 10W to maintain that kind of temperature difference. If you want to be able to get there quicker, you might increase the power requirement to something like 15W. Any more than that would seem like overkill for something of that size. For something like a 215x215mm area like a Prusa heat bed. That's designed to operate on about 130W to get it comfortably up to around 100 celsius - around a 75 kelvin delta - roughly 3 times your needs, but with only about 40% more power than you're currently planning. For something around that size, I expect you probably are looking at something like 40-50W, depending on how fast you want to be able to get there. This also seems to track reasonably well with my data - about 4 times the area should need about 4 times the power for the same temperature delta. It will be less than linear because as you get larger there are limits to how easily it can bleed off heat into the environment - smaller hotplates lose heat more easily. You probably can't go much bigger than that Prusa heat bed with the power supply you have.

Author: smint9414
Content:
This is what I have so far! The outer square is 150 x 150 mm and the inner one is 70 x 70 mm, so it's quite large compared to the solder reflow plates! The traces on the outer square have a width of 1.5 mm and the ones on the inner square have a width of 1 mm. The spacing between the traces is 1 mm for the outer square and 0.5 mm for the inner square. So to get the resistance up I could make the traces and the spacing smaller so that I can increase the length, but not sure what the limits are for this cause 0.5 mm seems pretty small already to me....
P.S. I just noticed that the Prusa heatbeds use multiple tracing circuits in parallel... this is of course the reason that the overall resistance is so low! Had to open the opensource files of the heatbed in Kicad to realise that.

Author: smint9414
Content: I calculated the power requirements and they are 20 W for the inner square and 50W for the outer square!

Author: brettski74
Content: What is your goal with this?  You have roughly 2.5 times the power density in the centre as compared to the outside. Couple that with the fact that the centre of the hotplate is less easily able to lose heat I expect that your centre square will get significantly hotter than the outer area. I'd expect 3-4 times high temperature delta in the centre square as compared to the outside area. Is that what you're aiming for?

Author: smint9414
Content: To achieve 2OW and 50W I'd need a resistance of 7.2 Ohm and 2.9 Ohm respectively, the 2.9 Ohm for the outer square isn't the problem, the 7.2 for the inner one is...

Author: brettski74
Content: So for example, if you get the outer area to an average temperature of 50 celsius, I expect the centre will be closer to maybe 120 celsius or more.

Author: smint9414
Content: Both area's will be controlled by their own PID controller to get a uniform temperature gradient

Author: smint9414
Content: Goal is to get an uniform temperature gradient  across an aluminium base plate! Cause I'm making a guarded hot plate measurement device for the measurement of thermal conductivity of insulating samples. So the areas need to have the exact same temperature cause that will ensure a steady state condition in the sample area under the inner heater. So the idea was to control them both independently with their own PID controller en own thermistors. Any suggestions?

Author: brettski74
Content: I would probably design for thermal resistance of about 1.5K/W in the centre and about 5K/W for the outer region. Parallel connection of the two areas makes that make a little more sense, especially with independent control.

Author: brettski74
Content: How precise do you want the uniform temperature to be?

Author: brettski74
Content: I think you may want to consider making the centre section larger. Temperature gradients are most pronounced near the edge - or to be more precise, nearer to cold regions. You may want to consider encasing the entire assembly in some kind of insulating material that covers the bottom and sides such that the heating element and the aluminium heat spreader on top of it are recessed into the insulation material.

Author: brettski74
Content: You'll want the insulation material to have low thermal mass if possible. I'm thinking of things like insulating fire bricks like they used in kiln - the really light ones that are full of air, not the heavy bricks you put around yoru fireplace - or maybe some kind of rigid rock wool or ceramic wool product.

Author: brettski74
Content: The more you can keep the edge closer to the temperature in the centre, the easier if will be to keep the temperature uniform.

Author: smint9414
Content: Goal is to get within 0.5 degrees of each other! I already made a prototype with 5 independent film heaters which worked oke. And everything is insulated as you suggested!

Author: brettski74
Content: And if you change the areas as I suggest, the thermal resistance numbers I gave you above will also need to change. I did a few postage stamp calculations based on area with some fudge factor for non-linearity in how these things tend to scale. If you make the area bigger, you need more power to maintain the same temperature delta (ie. thermal resistance is roughly proportional to area - not really but good enough for prototyping)

Author: smint9414
Content: The temperature of the inner square has to be uniform, that‚Äôs the only purpose of the outer square, to ensure that happens! I want the heat flow from the inner square to go perpendicular through the sample underneath it, so the outer region just ensures that that happens

Author: brettski74
Content: 0.5 celsius delta across a 150x150mm area is a challenging goal. I would suggest looking at the entire assembly to contribute toward that. Like I said, the more you can limit the non-uniform heat loss that occurs at the edges, the easier the rest should be.

Author: brettski74
Content: If you only care about the inner square, why make the outer area so big?

Author: brettski74
Content: If uniformity only needs to apply in the centre area, then I would make the outer area  narrower.

Author: brettski74
Content: If it's independently controlled and held at the same average temperature as is required in the centre region, it shouldn't be too hard to keep it uniform - at least that's my hypothesis based on what work I have done.

Author: brettski74
Content: On a perfectly uniformly laid out hotplate, you get temperature gradients because a point on the edge of the hotplate more easily loses heat to the surroundings because it can lose heat at top and bottom and also to the side. A point just inside of that will be able to keep a little bit warmer, but since it's joined to a cooler portion of the board, it will lose heat a little quicker than points further toward the centre. If you have an independently controlled section around the outside that you can keep at the required temperature, then keeping the centre uniform should be much easier. You have effectively removed the main cause for temperature gradients on such a hotplate.

Author: smint9414
Content: The ratio of inner/outer heater is determined through a thermal study in Solidworks, it has to be a:2a:a, so basically half the size of the inner square on each side. Only this ratio will ensure steady state heat transfer through the measured sample. Hopefully this graph helps:

Author: smint9414
Content: My main question is how to design the traces on the inner square/ main heater because of the limited space and high required resistance‚Ä¶

Author: smint9414
Content: The PCB heater will be mounted with thermal grease on a 3 mm thick aluminum baseplate, this will also improve the homogeneity  of the temperature gradient

Author: brettski74
Content: Fine-tuning the resistance is a bit of a black art. It really just comes down to tweaking track width and track pitch until you get what you're looking for. Even then, the numbers that come out in CAD aren't always the same as the numbers you get after it's manufactured. Interesting things happen at corners, so more corners might make your simple model of track resistance less accurate. What I generally do is that I try to keep the gap between the track constant while I reduce track width, That generally gets you a slowly increasing resistance as the track gets narrower and if you hit the number you're looking for this way, then happy days. Eventually, though this approach gets you to a point where you can fit another track in the space and the resistance jumps up. If it's still below your target resistance, just keep going, but if it's now above your target resistance, then go back to the point just before you could fit in another track. From there, continue making the track narrower, but this time keep the track pitch constant, so whatever you subtract from the track width is added to the spacing between the tracks. This should allow you to get to the resistance you're after.

Author: brettski74
Content: It takes some trial and error, which is why I stopped manually laying out hotplate tracks a long time ago. I have scripts and templates to do the work based on parameters such as track width and track pitch, so I can run it a bunch of times to zero in on a target resistance value.  I haven't released those scripts yet, but those will be coming soon. My hotplate design will be the next thing I release in the Modular-Solder-Reflow repository. It will include the scripts used to generate it so other people could use them to generate different hotplates for different requirements - different sizes, different voltages, etc.

Author: smint9414
Content: Oke I will keep on trying then! Are there any limits or things that I should avoid? like is there a minimum tracer or spacer width?Thank you for all the information, really appreciate it! Wasn't expecting such a fast response so thank you for that as well!

Author: brettski74
Content: The gaps between tracks - just go by what your manufacturer gives you. I typically try to work to about double what the minimums are. PCBWay's minimum track spacing is 4mil and I see that I have my scripts set to default to a minimum track spacing of 8 mil, so that seems to check out.

Author: brettski74
Content: As for minimum track width, I've never really gotten down anywhere close to the minimums so I can't say for sure if anything weird might happen. I expect that the risk of hotspots might be higher with narrower tracks. I can't find any information at JLCPCB or PCBWay on track width tolerance, but I expect that's got to be much smaller than the minimum track width, so if you're at least 4 or 5 times the minimum track width, hopefully the track width tolerance doesn't affect the local resistance per mm to change enough to be a problem. Given that minimum track widths are around 0.1mm, that gives you a 0.5mm track which it still pretty damn narrow.

Author: brettski74
Content: Not sure how thick your heat spreader is, but I imagine that you probably want a millimetre or 3 of thickness, but probably not much more, but this is just me speculating. I haven't experimented much with heat spreaders. I imagine that there's an optimal thickness where going either thicker or thinner could make it less effective.

Author: brettski74
Content: The design is on github, so you could build your own if you like. The construction is neat, but there's really no attention to safety in the design. That's not to say you will burn your house down. If it's used sensibly and under supervision, you'll likely be fine. There's no input buffering or anything to help control current rippple from PWM, so the burden is all on the input power supply. At low temperatures it looks like your peak current could exceed 5A you may have a 1.5 ohm load with both top and bottom traces energized. At high temperatures, though, you'd be fine. Maybe the software does something to help limit the input power? To be safe, I'd want to power something like this with a 8A or better power supply.

Author: brettski74
Content: The design is very simple, though so could probably be built fairly cheaply. I like the AtTiny. I looked at an AtTiny-1616 a while ago as a more appropriately sized microcontroller for this device.

Author: brettski74
Content: The hotplate is smaller than I'd like, but probably big enough to have reflowed virtually every board I've done on my own hotplates in the last year, so maybe bigger isn't necessary?

Author: brettski74
Content: Interesting PWM strategy. Using a timer interrupt to increment a variable and using digitalWrites in the main loop to set pins high or low depending on that variable. Not sure why you wouldn't use hardware PWM. As-is, the PWM frequency would be about 10Hz, which is pretty low. Definitely need more than a 5A supply.

Author: brettski74
Content: Temperature measurement using trace resistance measurements - my preferred method, although control algorithm is well not really there. Looks like it just estimates some duty cycle  based on your target temperature and then does some bang-bang control around your set temperature.

Content: Hi! I'm new here but I just spent about 30 min reading the chat for the past couple months. I'm keen to make one of these with a two part system (heater plate + control and power board).

Author: melon220
Content: This looks awesome! I'd love any updates on how well this works, and if it fixes the ripple current issues.

Author: melon220
Content: Also, just in general, how well do these DIY PCB hotplates hold up? (how many heating cycles are you guys able to get out of them?

Author: brettski74
Content: Reasonably well. I've no doubt that they will wear out eventually, but so far I've not been able to destroy one from normal use. I don't know how many thermal cycles I've put them through, although I've been testing a number of different hotplate designs, different control approaches and different software over the last year, so there have been a lot more cycles than I've had board to reflow. That said, I've also swapped new hotplate designs in every so often, so it's hard to say, although I'd guess that some of my board may have had somewhere in the range of 50-100 cycles over the course of their use and they're still usable today.

Author: brettski74
Content: The things that will destroy them are generally things I would consider abuse of the hotplate. Putting water or food on the hotplate can create enough thermal stress to delaminate and/or destroy the solder mask around it. overheating the board will also damage it, and even though I recommend against JLCPCB boards for anything hotter than SnBi solder reflow work, I haven't destroyed one from going up to SnPb reflow temperatures. They do tend to smoke at those temperatures, though, whereas PCBWay boards don't, so I prefer them for hotplates now.

Author: rubacava
Content: make sure to avoid significant temperature changes in short time and they will mostly be fine

Author: rubacava
Content: My stm32 ported designs wil arrive in probably 1-2 weeks if you want to wait for an alternative

Author: brettski74
Content: Although words like "significant" and "short" are pretty relative. Some people might consider 200 celsius in 2 minutes to be significant and short. üôÇ I think the point is to make sure that any part of the board is not at too different a temperature from nearby regions of the board. That's what I think causes the damage when you try to do things like boil a few drops of water or cook food on the board. I expect that excessive power could do the same thing if the heat doesn't get enough time to spread out into the rest of the material. Typical reflow profile speeds don't seem to be a problem.

Author: brettski74
Content: You can push past the glass transition temperature. Virtually everybody who builds one of these is doing it regularly.

Author: brettski74
Content: Keep in mind that this it the glass transition temperature of the resin, not of the glass fibres embedded within it. It will still have plenty of rigidity above the glass transition temperature. I wouldn't be putting lots of weight on it, but my current hotplate has been to well above 235 celsius on numerous occasions and it still as flat as it was when I first busted it out of the vacuum sealed package it was shipped in.

Author: brettski74

no damage to it, it is 1.6mm jlcpcb aluminum pcb with white silkscreen

Author: brettski74
Content: That's true. I have some boards that have been that hot and don't appear to have been damaged apart from some disolouration, but I do have some boards where you can see some delamination of the solder mask in places. It was still "intact" as in not cracked or flaking off or anything else that might expose the bare copper.

Author: brettski74
Content: Here's an example from one of my earlier iterations. It's hard to capture early stage delamination of the solder mask, but this is about as good as I could get without spending too much time on lighting and camera angles and such. This particular board version had too much power towards the outside of the board and developed hotspots around the outside centre portions of the board. You can see some blistering of the solder mask below the word "SURFACE" on the silk screen. There's also some blistering of the solder mask along the tracks above the "Resistance @ 25" as well. It's difficult to say exactly how hot these tracks got, and this is a fairly old board, so I can't remember exactly which tests or temperatures I subjected it to, but this was a problem with some of my earlier attempts to smooth out the temperatures by using variable geometry tracks. I have a few others with this kind of blistering of the solder mask from hotspots on the board.

Author: melon220
Content: Also, has anyone tried circular hotplates? Could have some advantages - higher area/perimeter ratio, so maybe better for heat losses to the environment (though most PCBs aren't circular, and also it might be harder to find an aluminium heat spreader that is circular)

Author: brettski74
Content: I and others have separate PCB hotplate designs. I haven't shared mine yet. I'm doing a bunch of cleanup on the design and testing a few enhancements. I'm hoping to publish my design in the Modular-Solder-Reflow repo in about 1-2 weeks. Other's have also done standalone hotplate PCB designs, but I haven't seen any shared, yet. That doesn't mean that they haven't, but I can't recall seeing a link to one yet.

Author: brettski74
Content: One of the design parameters I've used for my hotplate designs is to maximize the use of the area available in the discount offers from places like PCBWay (and JLCPCB and Elecrow and...) A circular hotplate would reduce available area because a 100x100mm square board costs the same as a 100mm diameter circular board, but the square has more usable area.

Author: brettski74
Content: That said, I have seen a video with a circular hotplate design about a year ago.

Author: brettski74
Content: Heat spreaders can be whatever shape you want, so circular, rectangular elliptical or whatever isn't a major issue. There are a bunch of companies online that will do laser cut sheet metal in whatever shape you want. I used SendCutSend. There is a minimum order amount, so I ordered 9 of them because it was virtually the same price as ordering 1. LaserBoost was another one that seemed like reasonable value and might make more sense if you're in Europe. There are a raft of others you can find on Google and depending on where you live, possibly a few local businesses who can do small batch laser cut metal parts as well. Komacut and Xometry were another couple of these services that I looked at but SendCutSend and LaserBoost seemed like better value. PCBWay do this too, but their pricing was rather expensive. They want to charge about the same for one piece as I paid for 9 of them from SendCutSend  and PCBWay's pricing doesn't go down that much for more pieces.

Author: rubacava

Author: rubacava
Content: PWM duty cycle is limited to 5.5A and adjusted according to temp

Author: brettski74
Content: Limited how? I haven't seen the firmware, but based on the hardware design, I can't imagine him being able to doing any reasonable current measurement and certainly not average or RMS current measurement. That just leaves duty cycle limits, but if you double the voltage you're also going to double the current because the heating element is essentially a fixed resistance.

Author: brettski74
Content: So you're just left with PID control keeping the duty cycle low enough based on the power needs for following the reflow profile.

Author: brettski74
Content: Generally, if I design for a higher input voltage, I'll want to use a higher resistance heating element. Technically I don't need to - especially with a buck-derived control circuit driving it - but it's an extra element of safety that I won't overload my supply and/or won't catch on fire and burn down the house. The higher resistance gives me a harder limit than anything in software ever will.

Author: brettski74
Content: Spatz was a big believer in that as well. If you go back about a year, you'll see him making some of the same criticisms of Chris's design and the heating element resistance being too low.

Author: rubacava
Content: You don't really need to measure current though since you already know the source voltage and the plate resistance changes predictably with temperature

Author: rubacava
Content: and the control doesn't have to be very precise for this application

Author: brettski74
Content: Yes - you could estimate it.

Author: brettski74
Content: Do you need to change the voltage divider?

Author: brettski74
Content: Doubling the input voltage might put you out of range for the ADC measuring the input voltage.

Author: rubacava
Content: I use 390k to 100k voltage divider so about 16.5V max for adc

Author: brettski74
Content: The whole sensor setup on Chris's designs are hokey. The sensor at the sensor is markedly different even from the edge of the board just a few millimetres away - that alone can be a temperature differential of 20-30 celsius. From there to the centre of the board might be another 50 celsius. Questions about the code for computing the temperature come up semi-regularly and the best any of us have come up with is that maybe Chris developed his own formula based on some measurements because what's in the code doesn't correspond even remotely to what's on the LMT85 datasheet. Chris's design works, but barely. There are some better designs like the Spatz design, but it still suffers from some of the same hardware flaws as Chris's designs. It does have better attention to sensor setup, firmware and safety, though.

Author: brettski74
Content: I'm getting a little frustrated with PCBWay... I submitted designs to them last Friday and still waiting on one of them to be approved so I can pay and get them into manufacturing. The second design is really just a mechanical piece I designed to hold a heat spreader in place over the hotplate. They originally rejected it because there was no copper layer - I'm assuming they thought this was a mistake. When I confirmed that it wasn't and resubmitted it with a token copper layer (just contained text saying "There is no copper") they've now been going back and forther asking whether I want solder mask or no solder mask, silkscreen or no silkscreen, etc. I've told them it doesn't really matter either way. I'd like the top silkscreen layer. The solder mask is immaterial. Include it or don't, doesn't matter. Whatever's easiest. What's annoying me at this point is they haven't raised any issue for why it can't be manufactured as submitted, so why all the questions? Why not just manufacture what I submitted? In the meantime, I figured I'd also give Elecrow a go since I haven't tried their boards as hotplates yet. See how they compare to PCBWay and JLCPCB. They're already in production and they didn't ask any questions. Just seem to be making what I submitted.

Author: brettski74
Content: At this point I might do a JLCPCB order as well, just to see how easy it is to get it manufactured there. I don't really need the extra boards, but I am kinda interested to know how easy it will be for anyone else to get my design manufactured.

Content: Finally got approved!

Content:
re: https://github.com/Berkays/ReflowPlate that's awesome, hoping to try it myself.

Apologies, a bit new to ordering a board presoldered / assembled (only just started ordering PCBs recently and this is my first having it be pre-assembled vs buying the components separately and soldering them). 

I managed to import the BOM and PNP.
I see:
Total  32 parts detected 27 Parts confirmed, 2 parts Inventory shortage, 3 parts not selected 

2 of the shortage appear to be just female headers which I have plenty so not worried there
The caps are just the ones mentioned as being not included to reduce costs right? So will source those separately.
Could you speak to what the SHORTING_LINK is? Will I need to just short that?

What else should I pick up?
- 4010 12v cooling fan
- 128x64 0.96" OLED display
-  Rotary encoder module
- 1 1u diameter 3 capacitor
- 4 680uF diameter 10 capacitors
- 2 NTCs (any models you'd suggest here? not too familiar with these)

Then should be set aside from the need to 3D print the enclosure, program the microcontroller, and put it all together? Thanks for the assist and the neat project.

Author: rubacava
Content:
You can follow the oshw link instead of importing the files manually. It will open the project which you can click order smt assembly and automatically import.

You need 4 680uF 10mm dia 16Vmin caps
1 1uF 3mm dia 5Vmin cap
Oled display
rotary encoder
7A 6125 fuse
Any ntc that can withstand the temperature. I use a rather expensive interchangeable ntc with curve fitting but steinhart approximation is supported too so you can use any ntc since it doesn't have to be very precise. 2nd slot is not used in the firmware atm.
You don't really need the fan either. If you want you can use it to cool the caps.

Author: rubacava
Content: Shorting link is for connecting pads internally without losing the port names in the editor. You don't have to do anything about it and don't select it

Author: rubacava
Content: Also STLink is required to program

Author: brettski74
Content: This is why we need a proper FAQ. I usually use the heating element as the temperature sensor. Works great, but you have to be able to measure voltage across the heating element and current through it reasonably accurately. You also need to calibrate it.

Author: technick14
Content: Yes, something a bit more formal would be helpful for ppl like me lol. Oh, heating element to measure temperature, that is an interesting idea! So, how did you go about calibrating and measuring voltage and current in circuit?

Author: rubacava
Content: external sensors have the ability to attach directly to target as an advantage. So you can measure the reflowed IC instead of the plate to be more accurate

Author: rubacava
Content: but measuring current is convenient at the expense of slight cost

Author: technick14
Content: When you say you can measure the reflowed IC, do you mean some random IC on whatever PCB you are attempting to solder? I fail to see how that would work without an infrared temperature sensor, nor why going to that depth would really be necessary?

Author: brettski74
Content: I like the "slight cost". All temperature sensors cost money. A current sense amplifier and a shunt is no more expensive than most temperature sensors. Most cheap MCUs have plenty of ADC inputs to measure voltages.

Author: brettski74
Content: Several people have implemented various remote sensors that can be placed on the board being reflowed. If you have something like a thermistor or thermocouple that isn't fixed in place, but at the end of a cable, then you can place it on the board being reflowed and measure the temperature there. In theory, this is more relevant, since that's where you actually need the heat.

Author: brettski74
Content: Someone also implemented an IR sensor that looks down at the hotplate, thereby measuring the temperature of whatever is on top - typically the board being reflowed.

Author: brettski74
Content: There are pros and cons with all of these.

Author: rubacava
Content: For jlc assembly, even¬†3 extended parts mean 10$ extra. You can source and solder those but any ntc is fine since accuracy is not that crucial

Author: technick14

Content: No you don't. My profiles use 205 celsius as the peak temperature and they work just fine with standard SnPb solder.

Author: brettski74
Content: That's not how things work. I mean, sure, you'll need to put energy into the aluminium to heat it up, but that will be true of any base material. All that really matters is the temperature you get to. That said, from data that I can find online, the specific heat of aluminium and FR4 are close enough and most of the energy at higher temperatures will go toward replacing losses to the surrounding environment rather than heating the base material.

Author: brettski74
Content: I have found myself wondering about high-heat enamel paints. You can get high-heat enamel paints here at most hardware stores and the like that resist heat up to 650 celsius. I have wondered whether you could buy a bare board and then apply a coating like that yourself. That said, I find that the smoking under normal circumstances hasn't been a huge issue. The first time you use a new board a little bit of material burns off but after the initial cycle, I haven't really noticed any smoking or fumes, so it's probably a lot easier to just stick with the solder mask and do an initial burn-in of new hotplates in a well-ventilated area if this is a concern, but let me know if your experience has been different.

Author: guardians_projects
Content:
Probably a good way to use @everyone 

But does anyone know how to get in contact of @chrshlsll 

It‚Äôs been almost a year of me trying, through multiple avenues. 

We are considering moving the server. We can‚Äôt promote new mods here. Or make cool changes to development a community, which this place desperately deserves. 

Please let me know what you want from the server moving forward in the #suggestions page. Thanks for reading, as we both have interest in making this place more useful and easier to find for everyone!

Author: guardians_projects
Content: They seem to be a ghost online (Which I can understand and respect) when searching with public information as a last resort. Please don‚Äôt harass Chris out of this. They deserve the respect and recognition for all of this amazing collaboration work

Author: brettski74
Content: My suggestion would still be that you request Discord to transfer ownership to you. I enquired about that a month ago after several attempts to contact Chris failed. We met all the criteria except for one - I wasn't a mod or an admin. You're a mod, so you can probably meet that requirement, then we can build a moderation and admin team here. The biggest challenge with moving to a new server is that the community is here and the traffic is being driven here. I suspect that most of that is from Great Scott's video, but maybe there's other places. We can still make Chris an admin and we can still transfer ownership if/when Chris comes back, but my position is that the community is here. Rather than try to move it somewhere else, we should try to manage the community that's already here and we can welcome Chris back if/when he wants to come back. Moving the server means also moving everything out there in the internet that drives traffic here or building something better that will more effectively drive traffic to the new location. That can be done and I was working on some of that, but personal circumstances are getting in the way of that again, so not sure how quickly I can get content out and even then there's the question of how effective I or others may be.

Author: brettski74
Content: Has anyone messaged Great Scott? Chris emailed him and that was part of what prompted himito make his DIY or buy video, so he may have Chris's email address or some other way to contact him. Failing that, if we were to move to a new server, it would make sense to maybe contact him to see if he'd be willing to update the links on his video to point to a more current, actively maintained fork on github and the new Discord server or whatever other service we end up using.

Author: brettski74
Content:
After some previous attempts to contact Chris failed, I contacted discord in April to ask what can be done. They said that if a server is abandoned by the owner the ownership can be transferred, but you need to meet the following criteria:

1. The server is a public server.
2. It has at least 100 members.
3. The current owner has not accessed their account for at least a month.
4. The new server owner has moderator or admin permissions on the server.

We met every requirement except the last one. The request must be made by the new server owner. It can't be made on behalf of someone else. From the other information they provided, it also sounds like they also attempt to contact the existing owner before making the transfer because they also mentioned that they don't transfer ownership if the current owner declines the request. That sounds like they would also attempt to contact the server owner before making the transfer and would only do it after they either agree or don't answer within some time period, but I'm speculating. They didn't explicitly say that, only that the transfer could be declined by the current owner. If nothing else, maybe it would be another way of getting in touch with Chris if he's still interested in playing a role here.

Content: I'm also thinking that this may be a good reason to consider using the heating element as the temperature sensor. At least that way if you have a hot spot under the board or something, that will influence the temperature reading and help avoid overheating any part of the board.

Author: brettski74
Content: I've mostly powered my hotplates directly from my lab power supply. It has a USB interface that allows me to read voltage and current out and modify the voltage and current set points. So I know the resistance of the heating element at room temperature and the thermal coefficient of resistance for copper, and based on the voltage and current out reported by the power supply I can estimate the temperature of the hotplate.

Author: brettski74
Content: It's not perfect, as I have to make some corrections for the resistance of the leads, but it works more than well enough and can follow a reflow profile reasonably well even though the read/write cycle time over the USB interface only manages about one read every 1.5 seconds.

Author: brettski74
Content: The power module I shared a couple of months back has a shunt and a couple of current sense amplifiers built into it to allow current measurements, so when I finally build my standalone unit, it will use the same approach.

Author: brettski74
Content: What exactly do you think needs to be "better" about the MOSFET? Also, what are you talking about it being high side? The AfterEarthLtd design MOSFET is low side. It's source is connected to ground.

Author: brettski74
Content: The biggest problem in its power design is that it has nothing for reducing current ripple, which is why the input filter cap gets so hot.

Author: brettski74
Content: With a good gate drive design it should make little difference to the thermals whether you use a high side or low side MOSFET, but as I noted before, the AfterEarthLtd design already has a low side design.

Author: brettski74
Content: 20mŒ© versus 29mŒ© isn't going to make much difference. Maybe a few 10s of milliwatts at best. There are more fundamental problems with the design. Capacitances are all bigger, so I expect your alternate part to switch slower with the same gate drive circuitry which is kinda what you expect for a larger MOSFET. Slower switching may increase your switching losses. That said, I think either MOSFET will work perfectly fine. You're welcome to try it, but I don't expect the results to be noticeably different. Maybe I'll be wrong.

Author: brettski74
Content: I suspect the PWM freq is fairly low. The resistance seems consistent with my expectations.

Author: brettski74
Content: There's no real step down required. The power supply could happily supply the heating element at 100% duty. High frequency PWM under those conditions is just going to waste power.

Author: brettski74
Content: That's one of the flaws of the AfterEarthLtd design. If you're using a 5A supply as suggested, you really need to step down the voltage, which needs high frequency, which then needs a design that controls current ripple. You can use a simpler design if you offload that problem onto a beefier power supply and design the heating element accordingly.

Author: brettski74
Content: ESP32 is  a decent microcontroller.  I haven't really used them, but it should work fine. As for faster PWM, it all depends on what you're trying to achieve and whether the rest of the hardware is designed to take advantage of a higher frequency. The power design for the AfterEarthLtd versions and similar designs like Spatz aren't really designed well for high frequency, so running the PWM even faster isn't really going to help. I would expect it may make power losses in your caps worse, which means they will get hotter, which is bad. Higher frequency PWM will need some means to control current ripple - ie. an inductor.

Author: brettski74
Content: I think that may depend on switching time and frequency. From some of the comments I've seen Chris make in the past, it seems he fried some components due to voltage spikes and putting that diode in there fixed his problem. I think there's possibly enough parasitic inductance in that heating element to cause problems if you can switch the MOSFET off fast enough.

Author: brettski74
Content: You don't want to jumper it. That's just shorting your heating element. You can remove it, but shorting it is absolutely the wrong thing to do and a good way to either overload your power supply or blow up the MOSFET from overcurrent/overheating.

Author: rubacava
Content: There should hardly be any magnetic fields due to snaking of the plate traces as it cancels itself. Also it probably needs at least hundreds of mhz to even have a negligible effect

Author: brettski74
Content: The inductance should be roughly equivalent to a loop around the hotplate. I agree that it's theoretically small, but Chris did report that he fried some MOSFETs due to apparent voltage spikes and adding the diode fixed it. Granted, it's a zener and not a schottky or fast switching diode so I'm not convinced that he truly understood what was happening. I've no reason to disbelieve that he fried some MOSFETs and there's no reasonable explanation I can see for any voltage exceeding 30V at the MOSFET except for stray inductance somewhere.

Author: brettski74
Content: The effect is not dependent on frequency. It's dependent on the rate of change of current, which would be determined by the magnitude of the peak current and the switch off time. For high frequency you will need a faster switch off time, but it doesn't need to be high frequency to have a sharp switch off response and a large peak current makes a "large" voltage spike more likely.

Author: brettski74
Content: Some back of postage stamp calculations make it seem unlikely - I'd expect switch off time would need to be better than 50ns or so, which is pretty brisk and probably faster than an MCU GPIO pin is capable of. All I know for sure is that Chris reported that he had problems with MOSFETs being fried apparently by voltage spikes, that adding that diode seemed to fix it and that I don't see any other reasonable explanation for such voltage spikes other than stray inductance from the heating element or elsewhere in the circuit.

Author: fireflyjar
Content: how hard is it to convert the firmware to ATMega328P?  is it simple as reassigning the pins?

Author: gabu6113
Content: I don't know much about the ATMega line so I'm not completely sure but in theory yes. I'm assuming that both chips have a similar number of GPIO pins with similar capabilities, and further assuming the board isn't using more than a few of them. If it's using most/all of the pins things might be trickier, but from what I recall looking at most of these plans they usually call for like 2 or 3 analog pins, and maybe 4 or 5 digital pins, which is usually well within the capabilities of most MCU.

Author: gabu6113
Content: The biggest consideration for the MCU used seems to be around the quality of the ADC/DAC and the VCC of the chip. The ATMega designs are 5V VCC while ESP32 and STM32 based ones are of course using 3.3V VCC.

Author: gabu6113
Content: also I'm assuming there's no major differences in the pin outs and footprint between those two chips, but once again I'm not really familiar with the ATMega line so I don't know how different they are.

Author: mafiltenborg
Content: @TAKUMIIII what a nice, modular design. Being new to hotplates, I've just learnt that the plate itself is a consumable, especially if it's made using FR4 which - I now know - sports a measly 150C Tg. I've just attempted to assemble the AfterEarth hotplate and found it extremely difficult hand-soldering all those 0402's. So, I'm looking for a more assembly-friendly design with a replaceable hotplate - and whatever other features the designer includes (screen, LEDs, fuses etc.). Your design fits the bill perfectly, and I'd be much obliged if you would share your work.

Author: takumiiii.
Content: I haven't tested it yet and the firmware needs to be re written

Author: brettski74
Content: To some extent, yes the hotplate is consumable, but they're more resilient that you might think. Also, FR4 is not a single material with a single set of characteristics. There are numerous different resins that can be used as the bulk material in FR4 which can give varying degress of heat resistance. The same applies to the solder mask and silk screen materials. So expect to wear out your hotplates eventually - especially if you do silly things with them - but if you treat them well, they will last quite a few reflow cycles. I use JLCPCB for most of my boards, but I use PCBWay for hotplates. Their standard (ie. cheap) materials seem to be more resilient to thermal cycling and high temperatures than JLCPCB's standard materials - at least as of July this year. I assume their materials are still the same.

Author: brettski74
Content: Which version have you built? If you're talking about the AfterEarthLTD designs or any of the forks based on them, technically you shouldn't need the screen for them to work, but I don't think it's going to be very easy to control without a display telling you what it's doing. I guess if you modified the firmware to control it via a serial connection or something, maybe, but otherwise for all practicaly purposes I'd say no.

Author: gabu6113
Content: could also pay a bit more and get an aluminum PCB for the hotplate. I noticed some discussion of that with Rubicava and he seemed happy with the result

Author: brettski74
Content: Rubacava seems to have done ok with aluminium boards, although IMHO, the aluminium is mostly useful as a heat spreader. you still have a thin layer of resin and adhesive between the aluminium bulk material and the copper traces. You still have a solder mask on top of the traces. Both of these can still break down over time with thermal cycling. I think the better approach is to have the heat spreader separate from the board.

Content: I ordered it. I did some jewing and managed to get it to a single layer. Bascially instead of the throughhole components being both sides they still go through but the connection pad is only on the top solder mask and since they are all connected you can just dump a bunch of solder and bridge them from the top

Author: takumiiii.

Author: takumiiii.

Author: takumiiii.

Author: takumiiii.
Content: I made it to have 6 NTC's. 4 to put on different parts on the plate and 2 to put on the actual PCB being reflowed so you can get an actual PCB temp rather then a hotplate temp

Author: takumiiii.
Content: Oh and i put in an actuall current sensor, so we have better feedback of how much current is being used

Author: brettski74
Content: Multiple sensors are mostly useful for redundancy unless you're going to have separately driven heat zones. Bare FR4 will have large thermal gradients across the surface of the hotplate. By far the simplest and most effective way I've found to mitigate thermal gradients is to use a heat spreader. Mine is an aluminium plate that sits on top of the FR4, but if you use an aluminium PCB you essentially have a heat spreader integrated into the hotplate. Once you have a decent heat spreader, thermal gradients aren't much of a problem any more, so you can measure the temperature anywhere and it's fairly representative of the whole hotplate. My current design - which I haven't actually had time to test yet - uses an NTC as a backup sensor for some safety features. The primary sensor for control purposes is the heating element itself.

Author: takumiiii.
Content: I am just saying because of depending on the PCB being soldered the actuall mass off the PCB at difference places might be different and have cold spots

Author: takumiiii.
Content: for example a power area of a pcb being soldered can have a lot more need for higher temp, its just a more reliable way

Author: brettski74
Content: A few people have made designs with a provision for temperature sensing on the board being reflowed. It's a nice idea, but I'm not convinced it adds enough value to warrant the extra design effort and the messing around placing the sensor on the board every time you reflow. It also assumes that the is a place you can place the sensor. On a densely packed board, it might be difficult to find a place. It's never been an issue for me in the past 18 months or more. Maybe your mileage will vary.

Author: takumiiii.

Author: takumiiii.

Author: brettski74
Content: Current sensing is very useful. If you have accurate current sensing through the heating element and accurate voltage sensing across the heating element, you don't need an NTC at all.

Author: takumiiii.
Content: I havent played with this current sensor before but I looked over the datasheet and integrated it

Author: brettski74
Content: So current sensing is good to have. I do current sensing. I also have voltage sense connections at the heating element terminals so I can calculate the resistance of the heating element at any given moment.

Author: brettski74
Content: And from that I can determine its temperature.

Author: takumiiii.
Content: I am more of a direct measure kind of guy. Doing stuff by "theoretical ideals" always leaves me wanting more

Author: takumiiii.
Content: Its never as accurate as its supposed to be in my experience, maybe I am just doing it wrong

Author: brettski74
Content: I don't get what you mean by "direct measure" versus "theoretical ideals". What do you think you're doing with an NTC?

Author: takumiiii.
Content: Good point

Author: brettski74
Content: An NTC thermistor is just a device whose resistance varies with temperature and you have a model of this variation specified in a datasheet. You then set up some means of deducing it's resistance in your circuit and use this to get an approximate value of it's temperature.

Author: takumiiii.
Content: I do the Steinhart-Hart Equation using a reference resistor for measuring NTC's

Author: brettski74
Content: A copper trace is also a device whose resistance varies with temperature. Not much different.

Author: brettski74
Content: Of course. So do I and many others. Steinhart-Hart is an approximation. It's a good approximation and more than sufficient for a wide range of purposes which is why it's used.

Author: takumiiii.
Content: Does the copper trace react the same way as an NTC? I havent read up too much on it

Author: brettski74
Content: Some NTC thermistors come with just a few parameters on the datasheet. Others come with an extensive table of measured resistance at different temperatures. If you look at the datasheet of one of the latter devices and create a Steinhart-Hart approximation of temperature based on two points from the table, you can see the variation between real temperature and predicted temperature using Steinhart-Hart. It's most accurate near the two data points used to set up the equation and reasonably accurate between those two values. This is typical of the former kind of thermistor, too, you just don't have the full table. You only have the data points that they gave you for a Steinhart-Hart approximation of the device.

Author: brettski74
Content: No. Copper - like most metals - have increasing resistance with temperature. Metals, including copper, are often used to make precise temperature sensors called RTD. The resistance of metallic conductors increases somewhat linearly. More precisely, there is a linear region and the proportionality value is called the temperature coefficient of resistance.

Author: brettski74
Content: For copper, the temperature coefficient of resistance is 0.00393 per Celsius/Kelvin degree.

Author: takumiiii.
Content: You would need atleast a 12bit dac then, no?

Author: brettski74
Content: So you need to calibrate your hotplate - ie. measure it's resistance at a known temperature - to be able to determine temperature, but once it's calibrated and provided that you can measure it's resistance reasonably accurately, you can calculate it's temperature.

Author: brettski74
Content: There are some challenges on the accuracy side for sure.

Author: brettski74
Content: But it's worked out reasonably well for me.

Author: brettski74
Content: DerSpatz is a little better than AfterEarthLtd. I think DerSpatz was one of the first people to really challenge Chris on some of the safety problems with his original design, but unfortunately he still copied some of the electrical mistakes in Chris's design.

Author: takumiiii.
Content: Which were?

Author: brettski74
Content: The main electrical problem with Chris's design (and also DerSpatz) is the lack of an inductor to control current ripple.

Author: takumiiii.
Content: One the heating element or the voltage input?

Author: brettski74
Content: It's a design that's fine for something like controlling the brightness of a low power LED, but when you're trying to control a 60-120W heating element, it's wholly inadequate.

Author: brettski74
Content: The problem is that PWM control of the heating element is done to efficiently control the power through the heating element without having to dissipate large amounts of power elsewhere, but PWM creates pulses in both current and voltage that need to be managed. In a low power device, whacking in a few capacitors may be enough to smooth things out enough. In a higher power device, using capacitors alone would require ridiculously large capacitors that would be impractical due to size, inrush currents, charge time, etc. So to keep things practical, you use both capacitors and inductors. The caps smooth out the voltage ripple and the inductors reduce the current ripple. Then your input supply just sees a relatively smooth load based on the average power being fed into your heating element plus a small proportion of losses.

Author: brettski74
Content: If you don't have the inductor, what happens instead is that the capacitors are almost immediately discharged when the MOSFET turns on and the bulk of the current is drawn directly from the power supply.

Author: brettski74
Content: If your power supply can support enough current to drive your heating element if connected directly across it's terminals, then you're probably ok. If not, maybe you will have problems, maybe you won't, but you're really exceeding the design parameters of your power supply.

Author: brettski74
Content: The other problem you have is power losses in the capacitors.

Author: brettski74
Content: But the down side of that is that you're now putting more of the burden on your power supply.

Author: brettski74
Content: Both Chris and DerSpatz assumed that by running at the highest possible PWM frequency, this would smooth out the load on the input power supply.

Author: takumiiii.
Content: isent the freq only 1k?

Author: brettski74
Content: And that is somewhat true, but without controlling current ripple, you have large ripple currents into and out of the input filter caps on every cycle. Even at 63kHz, with the power level of the heating elements we're using, it's essentially a roughly constant amount of energy that gets dissipated in the ESR of your input caps every cycle.

Author: brettski74
Content: So higher frequencies just mean that you have to dissipate that many more packets of wasted heat energy in those caps every second - ie. Higher power loss in the caps.

Author: brettski74
Content: And they get hot.

Author: brettski74
Content: So the firmware in my repo by default disables the register changes to increase the PWM frequency and operates at the standard PWM frequency - which is about 490Hz. Caps don't get hot at that frequency. I have a macro definition in there to enable hot caps, though, if that's what you'd prefer. That basically re-enables the register changes for high frequency PWM, so you operate about about 63kHz, but now your caps get hot.

Author: brettski74
Content: I did post links to an LTSpice model earlier this year which demonstrates the problem. The relevant part of the circuit is almost identical in both designs. DerSpatz uses larger caps and more of them, so that helps a little bit, but several people have reported hot input caps with that design also and the reason is basically the same as with AfterEarthLtd.

Author: brettski74
Content: I've also posted schematics above as to how you fix this with an inductor, but unfortunately you can't reallly retrofit this into either design without redesigning the board.

Author: brettski74
Content: 70mm x 90mm... You won't need anywhere near 700W. Take a look at https://github.com/brettski74/Solder-Reflow-Plate/tree/main/Board%20Versions

Author: brettski74
Content: For a hotplate area of 70mm x 90mm, 100W should be more than enough to follow pretty much any practical reflow profile you're likely to use.

Author: brettski74
Content: So then, when you say 220V, are you hell-bent on putting 220VAC across the heating element? If you really want to do that, I'd suggest looking at something like the base plate of an old iron or a kitchen hotplate or something of that nature. I wouldn't do it with a PCB hotplate. The electrocution hazard would not be worth it. Most people use a low voltage DC supply of somewhere around 12-24V DC. Much safer.

Author: brettski74
Content: You can find plenty of options for 12-24V DC supplies. AC/DC power bricks that can take 90-250 VAC input are pretty easy to find, and cheap. Another option that some people have been using is USBPD. Laptop power bricks can work reasonably well if they can supply enough power.

Author: brettski74
Content: It should work fine, but the centre will be noticeably hotter than the edge. I'd make the margin narrower. The wider it is the more area you have mechanically coupled to the heating element that's doing nothing but conducting heat away from the heating element and bleeding it off into the surrounding air.

Author: brettski74
Content: The better option is to avoid soldered joints completely. Most of these designs are screwed down to some kind of base - typically on stainless steel or brass spacers. Put pads in a couple of the corners and ring terminals on the ends of your wires to connect to the board.

Author: brettski74
Content: Here are two corners of my hotplate. You can see ring terminal connections both at the top and bottom of the brass spacers. No solder required and works great. I also recommend silicone insulated wire due to the potential for high heat hitting those wires.

Author: brettski74
Content: Noise in sensor readings is always a concern, but letting the system settle before taking measurements is probably a good idea. Others have done the same in their designs. The thermal time constant of the system is relatively slow compared to the time for any ringing or other artefacts from switching to settle down. Waiting a few milliseconds after the MOSFET is switched on or off before taking measurements is probably a good idea. That's what I'm planning to do when I finally get around to writing some firmware to drive my power module.

Author: greenbulka
Content: Hi, can someone help me understand what is the resistance of the heating trace of the 70x50mm version? Couldn‚Äôt find that info in the repository, it seems like expected power is around 60W, is it reasonable to assume that the resistance should be in proximity of 2.4Ohm?

Author: brettski74
Content: I guess that depends on which repository you look in. From the measurements on my v3.0 boards I made almost 2 years ago, the resistance of the heating element was about 0.9 ohms - as noted in my fork https://github.com/brettski74/Solder-Reflow-Plate amongst the known issues with that design.

Author: greenbulka
Content: Thanks, I was looking at this repo https://github.com/AfterEarthLTD/Solder-Reflow-Plate. Do you know if there is an updated version available somewhere with at least some of issues addressed?

Author: brettski74
Content: Take a look at my fork. It documents a lot of the shortcomings in the AfterEarthLtd design, fixes the non-functional 4809 firmware and a few minor tweaks/workarounds for a few known issues, but it's mostly just documenting what we've learned of that design.

Author: brettski74
Content: I originally started working on updating that design to address some of the issues, but abandoned that in favour of starting from scratch. The best complete designs I've seen so far are probably the Spatz designs, but those still have some of the AfterEarthLTD issues - particularly the lack of inductance to limit current ripple.
