Author: brettski74
Content: I assume you're talking about ADC accuracy.  This is a common criticism of the ESP chips here, but honestly, I don't think it'll make that much difference. The temperatures don't need to be that accurate and even if you really want accuracy you can tune things to get the most important temperature (ie. the peak) dialled in more than close enough. I haven't used an ESP chip, so I can't talk from experience, but from the datasheet and from a number of ESP users on here, it looks more than good enough for reflow temperature measurements.

Author: darkbeer42
Content: @brettski74 well this is about the pico the atmega has a great ADC not sure about the ESP but i'm still leaning towards modifying it to work with a pico and an external 8 channel ADC from TI.

Author: brettski74
Content: I haven't looked at the pico specs, but I'd wager that the pico ADCs are more than good enough as well. You don't need extreme accuracy here. All you need is precision and even then, if you're within +/- 5 celsius, you'll be able to do just fine.

Author: brettski74
Content: Looking at your board, I only see one inductor and looks like it's probably for some switcher IC to produce your 7.5V rail. If you want to run at high frequencies, you'll want something to control current ripple in the main power stage. The alternative is to have those big caps get really hot due to the ripple currents or run at low frequencies. Most of the existing designs including Spatz and AfterEarthLtd have this same problem.

Author: brettski74
Content: I haven't used the pico, but googling seems to suggest the problem is a noisy supply due to poor analog design. Depending on who you ask, you may only get about 8 or 9 bits worth of precision. That does sound like a bigger problem than the normal complaints with the ESP ADCs. Kinda tossing up in my head whether 8 bits worth of ADC precision would be enough. I'm thinking that's getting marginal at best and would depend on biasing things just right. Seems like too much hassle when you can use an Arduino board that has a 10 bit ADC without those problems. Is it the Pico board that is the problem, or is the noise problem with the RP2040 itself?

Author: darkbeer42
Content: youi'll probably have to look for papers on the topic but i'm just talking about not overshooting target temperatures

Author: darkbeer42
Content: the smoother you make your ramps the better this is true for tempering metal as well especially when you do reflowing during the soak

Author: brettski74
Content: I was looking for papers, but not finding much relevant. I think people overplay component damage from reflow ovens and hotplates too much, though. Maybe if there's some particular component that's particularly heat sensitive, but at that point it'd likely be impossible to hand solder. Soldering irons generally run much hotter than any reflow device. Typical hand soldering might run the iron at somewhere north of 300 celsius to get good joints. Reflow profiles generally top out at somewhere around 250 for SAC alloys, maybe 220 for SnPb and much lower for SnBi. Additionally, the heating is much more consistent across the component which would usually reduce mechanical stress from the heating.

Author: darkbeer42
Content: sure that's true for most parts

Author: brettski74
Content: The way I see it, if you can hand solder a component without destroying it, you're very unlikely to damage it doing reflow, even if you overshoot by 10 or 20 celsius.

Author: brettski74
Content: I have a bunch of the original Seeduino Xiao's that are based on the SAMD21. They were nice little boards. Tiny, and have a built-in DAC and much more power than a typical Arduino board. They've been handy for a number of little test rigs and other tinkering. When I saw the RP2040 version, I picked up a couple to play around with them, but never really found the time. I recently started venturing into STM32 - in part because I have some cheap blue-pills that I found a while back and wanted to try, and the specs are nice, and I have some other hardware here that's STM32 that I have aspirations of maybe hacking one day. Too many shiny things, so I have to pick one or two to focus on or get nothing done.

Author: brettski74
Content: That depends... If you have a 328p lying around that you want to use, then I'd say AfterEarthLtd. The DerSpatz hardware is a little better - especially because it at least has a fuse in it, but there's not that much in it. The software... less sure. AfterEarthLtd is a bit clunky and has some bugs, but still manages to work - barely. I'm hoping that the DerSpatz firmware is better designed and written, but I personally haven't used it. All other things being equal, I'd say DerSpatz, but if you already have a 328p that you plan to use or someone is willing to sling you over a spare board that they have lying around, that would be enough to swing it either way IMHO.

Content: I don't know about Altium. Most of the designs I've seen have been in either KiCad or Easy EDA.

Author: brettski74
Content: The two most common designs with full details that have been shared would be the Spatz design and the AfterEarthLTD designs. Both have their issues, but Spatz is probably better.

Author: brettski74
Content: But what do you need? Do you just want a hotplate that can reflow a board with as little effort as possible, or does it have to be some kind of purpose built device with some chance of following a reflow profile or controlling temperatures reasonably accurately, etc?

Author: brettski74
Content: The simplest option is probably an iron. Place it with the base pointing up, set it to the highest temperature setting, place you loaded board on top and plug it in.

Author: brettski74
Content: If you want something more along the lines of a purpose built device that you build yourself, maybe look at the Spatz design. There are a few other more recent designs that have been posted on here as well but I haven't really had the chance to look at them much. If you look through the pinned messages you'll find a bunch of links to several designs.

Author: biggestsonicfan
Content: I purchased a SRP late last year and I finally sourced all the components for my project. Using 138c paste and a stencil and many placed components later, it looks like the SRP failed to melt almost all the solder. It seems like 150c wasn't hot enough to heat the ground plane, and many 402 components just floated around before the paste could become molten. Any suggestions other than use a hot air gun?

Author: biggestsonicfan
Content: The SRP did fine on a test board for SMT practice, a few leds, caps, resistors and it makes a light ring when power is applied so I thought the SRP would have handled the smaller board (47 x 57mm)

Author: brettski74
Content: Which design? One of the AfterEarthLTD designs? Which version? What firmware?

Author: biggestsonicfan
Content: This one https://www.solderreflowplate.co.uk/product-page/solder-reflow-plate-ver3-0

Author: biggestsonicfan
Content: Let me check firmware

Author: biggestsonicfan
Content: Says Software 1.0 on boot

Author: brettski74
Content: Ok - so you bought a readymade one from Chris's website. I'm not sure what firmware he's using, but the behaviour sounds about right for the versions on github, so I can't imagine the firmware is that far off what's on github.

Author: brettski74
Content: So, there are several issues with the design. It can be made to work, but it's not a great design.

Author: brettski74
Content: The fact that it has an audible hum tells me that it's using low frequency PWM, which mitigates the ripple current issues. The fact that it's failing to get hot enough to melt SnBi solder alloys tells me that it's probably using the same temperature calculation that is on github - which doesn't work.

Author: brettski74
Content: I'm not sure where the formula came from that he used. It doesn't seem to correspond even remotely with the information on the datasheet. Maybe he tried to come up with his own approximation based on testing because the sensor location and layout isn't great for getting accurate temperature readings of the actual hotplate, anyway.

Author: brettski74
Content: When I first built mine, the quick fix was to modify it to have higher temperature options and give it more time. Those changes should be reflected in my fork of the v3.0 firmware on github which I think is what most people on here have been using for the v3.0 boards.

Author: brettski74
Content: Realistically, the firmware isn't great and needs some major rewriting and the hardware has some major flaws as well, but like I said, it can be made to work. Just don't expect it to be a turnkey solution.

Author: biggestsonicfan
Content: That's fair.

Author: brettski74
Content: https://github.com/brettski74/Solder-Reflow-Plate

Author: biggestsonicfan
Content: Just weighing my options to see if investing in a more expensive plate vs trying to fix the current plate and having another board/component loss. A new hot plate might cost less than another failure and attempting a 3rd board.

Author: biggestsonicfan

Author: brettski74
Content: Most people on here after maybe doing some initial tinkering with Chris's designs move on to their own custom designs, although none have gained a lot of traction yet. There have been some better designs along the way. Spatz was probably the most complete and it fixed some of the issues with Chris's designs, but not all of them. The most recent person making a lot of progress is @TAKUMIIII . I've also got some grand plans in the works, but they're on hold for the moment after moving house and having a lot of house projects to get done before I can really devote a lot of time to my electronics hobby again.

Author: brettski74
Content: If you have a lab power supply that can handle maybe 8A or more at 12V, another option is to just solder wires onto it and hook it up to a lab power supply. You'll have to do some trial and error, but that may give you more options. If you have a power supply with remote control capabilities over USB or Bluetooth or something, you may be able to do better that way anyway. That's how I've done most of my reflow in the past couple of years. I have a USB controllable power supply that can do up to 20A, so I can use that to both control the power and sense the temperature based on how the resistance of the heating element changes.

Author: rippanda12

Author: brettski74
Content: Depends on what you mean by newcomers. If you mean newcomers to this discord but not new to electronics, then I'd say the same thing I've said before - Spatz or AfterEarthLTD are the two most complete designs that I've seen shared here. Both of them need some work and improvement, but Spatz has better hardware and probably better firmware so will need less of both. If you're new to electronics, this probably isn't the best place to start - at least not at the moment.

Author: brettski74
Content: If I recall correctly, Chris's design has a 4k7 resistor included in the UPDI programming input (R3) and you only need one, not one in both the programmer and the device, so you can probably ignore it for your immediate needs. I think I did the initial flash with both and it worked but tried it again with a later flash and it worked without the 4k7 resistor in the UPDI programmer since there's one integrated on the reflow hotplate board.

Author: knowyourphone
Content: hey everyone very new to the smd side of soldering but always been interested in this project. currently i only have the soldering skills and stuff for THT soldering so was wondering if it would be at all possible to do or just to spend a bit more on the service from nextpcb to have them assemble it?

Author: brettski74
Content: Of course it's possible to use an assembly service to do it for you. Chris's design was done in EasyEDA, so I expect that it would be easiest to use JLCPCB's assembly service, but I've never used an assembly service myself, so I'm not sure whether everything is already there that you need or whether there's some more work for PnP that might be needed.

Author: brettski74
Content: Alternatively, I went the bootstrap approach. The first board I ever reflowed was the first reflow hotplate I built. If you have 5 boards, you can solder some wires directly onto one of the spare boards to directy power the heating element and use that to reflow your first reflow hotplate board. This assumes that you have a suitable power supply for this purpose. No time like the present to start learning about reflowing SMT boards.

Content: If you can't see it it doesn't exist, right? I've ordered black boards twice in maybe ten different test designs. Most of the time I'm too impatient to wait the extra two days for non-green, so most of my hotplate boards have been green. It will discolor over time, but it holds up ok.

The easiest way I've found is to drop a heat spreader on top. I have a 2mm aluminium plate that sits on top of the FR4, now.

Author: brettski74
Content: What's wrong with 16s?

Author: brettski74
Content: 16s at what current level?

Author: brettski74
Content: All overcurrent devices have time-current curves. Even a plain old fuse may take some time to trip at double the rated current.

Author: brettski74
Content: 16s at double the rated current doesn't seem bad to me, but should be well below 1s at 10 times the rated current. It all depends on what scenario you're trying to protect against.

Author: brettski74
Content: Try a 2-SMD package. Should be close enough to 2920 to fit the same pads.

Author: brettski74
Content: It depends on the level of overcurrent.

Author: biggestsonicfan
Content: Well, if the fuse blew after I applied power once the shorted mosfet was reapplied, it blew probably within less than half a second

Author: brettski74
Content: Yes - but how much current did that shorted MOSFET draw? Like I said, it depends on the level of overcurrent. The higher the current, the faster the device will react.

Author: biggestsonicfan
Content: Ah that's true, forgot about that

Author: biggestsonicfan
Content: I am also not going to measure that

Author: brettski74
Content: I was just looking at a fast blow fuse datasheet. At double the rated current, it looks like it should take about 1 second to blow, but at about 1.8 times the rated current, the curve looks closer to about 20 seconds.

Author: brettski74
Content: https://www.schurter.com/en/datasheet/typ_OMF_125.pdf

Author: brettski74
Content: I'm eyeballing it on a logarithmic scale, but the 20 second point on the time-current curve looks to me to be around 1.7-1.8 times the rated current.

Author: brettski74
Content: It would be difficult to measure, anyway. You likely have a very big current spike when power is connected, which falls off quickly as the PS output caps discharge and the PS reacts to the change in load.

Author: sebbeben
Content:
Am I thinking this wrong?! The mosfets should have the same signal and just handle more current? 
Why should they work independently?

Author: takumiiii.
Content: Each mosfet controlls each zone

Author: takumiiii.
Content: Its so zones can be heated independantly based on the thermistor for that zone

Author: takumiiii.
Content: and there is a central thermistor that reads middle of plate temp

Author: takumiiii.
Content: So each singal is different

Author: takumiiii.
Content: More flexibility this way

Author: takumiiii.
Content: It also allows for different heatplate designs for example a segmented smart heatplate that turns on only the zones you need

Author: sebbeben
Content: Ok I see, I thought the reason for more hot plates was just for bigger pcb‚Äôs

Content: Kind of? I spent a whole day tuning it and it sill sucks ass espressif really dropped the ball on the ADC's

Author: takumiiii.
Content: anything more then +/- 10mV is unnaceptable for me. And its not just accuracy, its non-linearity. Are you telling me I need to further reduce the accuracy of my analog signal by using two 1% resistors to divide the voltage so its max is below 2.5V?? Ridiculous

Author: takumiiii.

Author: brettski74
Content: You need a precise ADC. It doesn't necessarily need to be accurate. My understanding is that the primary issue with the ESP ADCs is some nonlinearity in their response. As long as they're precise, they can be calibrated for accuracy and as I've said before, people seem to overestimate the value of accuracy for this type of device. If you can get within +/-10 celsius at reflow temperatures, that's still more than good enough.

Author: takumiiii.
Content: It needs to be accurate, not precise for proper sthenheart heart equation, it uses the system voltage as a part of the calcuation.

Author: takumiiii.
Content: We are calcuation resistence of the thermistor and based on resistence we are calculating temperature

Author: takumiiii.
Content: To calculate resistence we use voltage divider with known resistor and known system voltage

Author: takumiiii.
Content: the esp's ADC's are off more then +/-10c when using thermistors

Author: takumiiii.
Content: At low temps and high temps are way off

Author: brettski74
Content: I know how thermistors are used for measuring temperature. I've done it many times.

Author: takumiiii.
Content: I understand, its just its not to my satisfaction

Author: takumiiii.
Content: I am not happy with +/-10C

Author: takumiiii.
Content: I average 3 thermistors with 3 different refernce resistors just to get a good temp measurnment across all temp ranges

Author: takumiiii.
Content: With weighted linerization based on most accurate ranges

Author: takumiiii.
Content: There is also the problem when using thermistors mounted on the bottom of the hotplate as there is a difference between heatplate temp on top , temp on bottom and actual PCB to be reflowwed temp

Author: takumiiii.
Content: I did like 20-30 dataruns to measure the relationships between the top and bottom temps

Author: takumiiii.
Content: and ploted that as a temp correction curve

Author: takumiiii.
Content: The most accurate temp is achieved with the said 3 thermistors on the bottom to get a good estimation of the top PCB hotplate temp with 1 sensors held by a pair of helping hands that touches the PCB being reflown that high a higher weighting factor then the ones on the bottom

Author: takumiiii.
Content: that way you get a great actual temp on the PCB being reflown

Author: takumiiii.
Content: The paste goes into a liquid state witn 2-3 degress  on displayed temp of the datasheet

Author: takumiiii.
Content: Results are great, paste I could never get good shiny joints with a hotgun creates great shiny ,strong joints

Author: brettski74
Content: Think about this... 3D printing ABS is more temperature sensitive than reflow soldering and needs to maintain a consistent temperature for hours on end and most 3D printer designs get by just fine with a single thermistor measuring temperature at one point on the bed. Most thermal issues in 3D printing come down to mechanical issues, like using an enclosure, using the right solution for first layer adhesion and the like. I've no doubt that with a more elaborate sensor setup and tuning of the hardware and software you can produce much more accurate temperature readings, but at the end of the day, I only care whether my board is reflowed, that all the solder joints are electrically and mechanically sound and that I didn't overcook my hotplate, the board or any of my components. My reflow profiles for SnPb use a reflow temperature of 205 celsius which has worked quite well. Most commercial reflow profiles use reflow temperatures of around 225 celsius for SnPb and as high as 260 celsius for SAC alloys. I have a datasheet for a SMD LED that I just checked which suggested 230 celsius (SnPb) and 255 celsius (SAC) for reflowing their LEDs. If I can do +/-15 celsius, I could aim for 215, get somewhere within the 200-230 range for SnPb and still be confident of good joints everywhere and be well below the danger zone for damaging my SMD devices.

Author: brettski74
Content: I don't doubt you're getting good results. What I'm saying is that you could still get good joints without needing such high degrees of accuracy. I personally haven't worked with ESP32 but I have seen ESP32 designs that seemed to work well.

Author: brettski74
Content: My biggest concern with an ESP32 design is that the motivation often seems to be WiFi control and logging. In my mind, that's only really useful if I plan to be powering the device while I'm not sitting right next to it and I haven't seen any design that I'd consider safe enough to be using while not sitting there with it - preferably watching it.

Content: Not sure if it's just my poor design or if it's the official design too, but be careful running the mosfet at 100 PWM, it has a very bad day and then dies.

Author: apple.sauce
Content: Well tomorrow me's equally disappointed. At 7v and 30% PWM cycle I can get up to 50c, which is uhh a few degrees too low, and the (replacement) mosfet is already much hotter than the board itself gets.

Author: apple.sauce
Content:
Is measuring resistance on the two sides of C7 a reasonable way to ballpark the resistance of my heating coil? It comes to .8 ohms, which isn't very far off from the Designing a Board's .9 Ohm resistance recommendation.

The fact the documentation says you can run this same mosfet at 100% PWM and 12v and when I did that last night I melted the solder under the mosfet and then melted the mosfet itself makes me feel like I've done something wrong.
